questions.text:
An 11-month-old boy is admitted to the hospital following an episode of seizure. He has a history of delayed developmental milestones. He currently weighs 6.8 kg with a height of 67 cm. His seizures did not recur, and his vitals remain stable. There is decreased muscle bulk, hypertonia, hyperreflexia, and a positive Babinski sign. Funduscopy reveals bilateral optic atrophy and the given finding: 



What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Tay Sachs disease

  • Tay Sachs disease is a rare autosomal recessive neurological condition that progresses over time.
  • Beta-hexosaminidase A deficiency leads to the buildup of GM2 gangliosides, which causes the condition.
  • Classical early signs are mild muscular weakness, agitation, and hypersensitivity to auditory and other sensory stimuli. An excessive startle reaction, also known as auditory myoclonus, is an initial and useful symptom in the diagnosis.
  • A fundoscopic examination will typically reveal a cherry-red patch in the retina.

Option A: Krabbe’s disease

  • Krabbe's disease is an autosomal recessive neurodegenerative condition caused by a lysosomal enzyme defect in galactocerebroside-galactosidase.
  • It is characterised by white-matter involvement and demyelination.
  • Clinical features include generalised seizures, stiffness, opisthotonus, and ocular atrophy.

Option B: Gaucher disease

  • Gaucher's disease is the most common lysosomal storage disorder (LSD).
  • It occurs due to a glucocerebrosidase deficiency.
  • Bone marrow contains Gaucher cells, lipid-laden macrophages that have cytoplasm with a typical histologic appearance of "wrinkled tissue paper" when stained with periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) stain.

Option D: Hunter syndrome

  • Hunter syndrome is a mucopolysaccharidosis disease.
  • Mucopolysaccharidosis is a set of hereditary disorders characterised by glycosaminoglycan buildup in tissues and organs.
  • The afflicted organs and the specific enzyme deficit determine the clinical characteristics. Glycosaminoglycan storage causes anomalies in the connective tissue and bones, coarse facial characteristics, and mental retardation.

questions.text: The life cycle of the tapeworm Diphyllobothrium latum is given below. What form does the organism exist in at stage 6 of its life cycle?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A- Plerocercoid:

  • Diphyllobothrium latum has a complex life cycle that involves multiple hosts.
  • Man (human) serves as the definitive host, where the adult tapeworm matures and reproduces.
  • Life cycle of Diphyllobothrium latum:
    • Unembryonated eggs in human feces → Egg embryonates in water → Coracidium (first larval stage) hatches from egg → Ingested by freshwater cyclops (1st intermediate host) → Precercoid (2nd larval stage) in the body cavity of cyclops → Cyclops ingested by freshwater fish (2nd intermediate host) → Plerocercoid (3rd larval stage) in muscle of fish → Ingested by human → Adult worm in human intestine

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are incorrect, as explained in the life cycle above.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male with a 15-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus presents to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of dimunition of vision in his left eye for the past three months. Optical coherence tomography (OCT) is performed, showing the findings given below.What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Cystoid macular edema :

  • The OCT examination in the above patient shows presence of cystoid spaces filled with fluid . These findings along with the presenting clinical features indicate the presence of cystoid macular edema.

CME (Cystoid Macular Edema)

Cystoid macular edema (CME) is swelling of the layers of the neurosensory retina within the macula. When excess fluid builds in the retina, it typically collects in “pockets,” referred to as “cysts.”

Signs and Symptoms:

  • Slow, painless loss of vision
  • Metamorphopsia (distortion of shape)
  • Micropsia (objects appear small and distorted) or macropsia (objects appear large and distorted)

Diagnostic Tools:

  • Amsler's grid
  • +90 D lens (best instrument to examine CME)

Investigations:

Fluorescein Angiography (FA):

  • Dye used: Fluorescein Sodium
  • Arm retina circulation time: 12 seconds
  • Pattern of leak indicates pathology
  • Limitations: invasive and may cause allergy

Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT):

  • Gold standard investigation for all macular disorders
  • Non-invasive
  • Provides a cross-sectional view of the retina

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Central serous retinopathy: It typically presents with serous retinal detachment and fluid accumulation underneath the neurosensory retina, often occurring in younger patients and often associated with stress or corticosteroid use.

Option C - Retinal detachment : It involves the separation of the neurosensory retina from the underlying retinal pigment epithelium and is associated with symptoms like flashes of light and a sensation of a "curtain" coming down over the vision.

Option D - Age related macular degeneration : It is characterized by the gradual deterioration of the macula, often leading to central vision loss, but it usually presents with drusen and pigmentary changes, rather than cystic spaces seen in CME.

questions.text: A woman is using combined oral pills containing estrogen + progesterone for 2 years regularize her menstrual cycles. The drug also prevents her from pregnancy due to all of the following mechanisms, except?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option D- Stimulation of follicular development:

  • This is not a mechanism associated with COCPs. In fact, the primary role of COCPs is to suppress follicular development and ovulation. Stimulation of follicular development would be counterproductive to the contraceptive effect.

The action of COCPs :

  • Estrogen:
    • Decreases GnRH → Decreases FSH and LH → Anovulation (main mechanism)
  • Progesterone:
    • Thickens cervical mucosa
    • Increases tubal motility
    • Causes atrophic changes in endometrium leading to its thinning and unsuitable for implantation

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B and, C are mechanisms of COCPs as explained above.

questions.text: Which of the following is the tocolytic of choice for preterm labor?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Nifedipine:

  • Nifedipine is the drug of choice for preterm labor
  • First line & safe drug
  • Start 30 mg orally & maintain with 20 mg
  • The incidence of pulmonary edema is very low.

Incorrect Options:

Option B, C, D:

  • These are also tocolytic drugs, but they are not the first-line drugs in the management of preterm labor.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is deficient in Inclusion Cell Disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Deficient N-acetylglucosamine1-phosphotransferase enzyme:

  • The investigations in this child strongly suggest a diagnosis of I-cell disease, an autosomal recessive lysosomal storage disorder also known as type II mucolipidosis.
  • GNPTA gene mutation leads to a deficiency in N-acetylglucoseamine-1-phosphotransferase.
  • Enzyme deficiency → Golgi fails to phosphorylate mannose residues (↓ mannose-6-phosphate) on glycoproteins → enzymes secreted extracellularly → lysosomes deficient in enzymes → cellular debris builds up (inclusion bodies).
  • Clinical features include coarse facial features, gingival hyperplasia, corneal clouding, and hepatosplenomegaly.
  • Investigations reveal ↓ tissue lysosomal activity and ↑ plasma lysosomal enzymes.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Deficient lysosomal acid α-1,4-glucosidase:

  • This enzyme defect leads to Pompe disease, type II glycogen storage disease characterized by cardiomyopathy, hypotonia, and exercise intolerance, and might lead to early death.
  • Enzyme deficiency leads to the accumulation of glycogen within the cells.

Option C - Deficient α-L-iduronidase:

  • α-L-iduronidase deficiency causes Hurler syndrome, an autosomal recessive mucopolysaccharidosis. It leads to the accumulation of heparan sulfate and dermatan sulfate.
  • Due to sharing similar clinical features, differentiating Hurler syndrome from ICD is challenging.
  • A unique clinical feature exclusive to Hurler syndrome is a temporary acceleration of skeletal growth at one year of age.

Option D - Deficient glucocerebrosidase:

  • This leads to accumulation of glucocerebroside, causing Gaucher disease, which is sphingolipidosis. It also presents with hepatosplenomegaly.
  • However, accompanying pancytopenia, osteoporosis, osteonecrosis of femur, and bone crisis are often present.

questions.text:
Match the following organisms with the cultures they are grown in:


	
		
			
			Organism
			
			
			Culture
			
		
		
			
			1. E. coli
			
			
			a. BCYE agar
			
		
		
			
			2. Legionella pneumophilia
			
			
			b. MYPA agar
			
		
		
			
			3. Staphylococcus
			
			
			c. MacConkey agar
			
		
		
			
			4. Bacillus cereus
			
			
			d. Mannitol salt agr
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 1-c, 2-a, 3-d, 4-b:

1. E. coli on MacConkey agar: E. coli ferments lactose, leading to the production of acid and a color change of the pH indicator in the agar, resulting in pink or red colonies.

2. Legionella pneumophila on BCYE agar: Legionella species are highly fastidious and grow on complex media, such as BCYE agar and black-color colonies.

3. Staphylococcus on Mannitol salt agar: Staphylococcus species, including Staphylococcus aureus, ferment mannitol, leading to the production of acid and a color change in the pH indicator in the agar, resulting in small, yellow colonies.

4. Bacillus cereus on MYPA agar: Colonies of B. cereus grown on MYPA (mannitol-egg yolk-phenol red- polymyxin agar ) and pink-orange colonies are seen and are lecithinase positive.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option B for an explanation.

questions.text: A healthy 4-year-old girl is brought to the clinic by her mother for routine vaccination. The child has missed several vaccination appointments. Which of the following vaccines can be administered up to 5 years of age?

choices.text: OPV, Measles, MR vaccine, Vitamin A
MR vaccine, DPT, JE vaccine, PCV

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - OPV, Measles, MR vaccine, Vitamin A:

  • When children are not administered vaccinations according to the recommended immunization schedule, they fail to receive timely protection against preventable infectious diseases at a period when they are most susceptible, and their risk of never fully completing their vaccination course increases.
  • These outcomes compromise a successful immunization program.
  • However, delayed vaccination can be adopted in a number of scenarios based on the child’s age.
  • The vaccines that can be administered up to 5 years of age are:
    • Oral Polio Vaccine
    • Measles vaccine
    • MR vaccine
    • Vitamin A drops

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D:

  • Vaccines that can be given up to 1 year:
    • BCG
    • Rotavirus Vaccine
    • Pentavalent
    • fIPV
    • PCV
  • Hepatitis B vaccine alone can also be given until 1 year
  • Up to 7 years: DPT
  • Up to 15 years: JE vaccine

questions.text: Patient was being treated in ICU for sepsis ABG shows pH=6.9, pO2 =80 mm Hg. pCO2=55 mm Hg, HCO3 = 10 meq/L. Repeat ABG after 2 hour shows pH=6.7, pCO2= 20 mm Hg, pO2 = 100 mm Hg. HCO3 = 5 meq/L. Which is most plausible to explain the change seen in ABG report?

choices.text: Excessive air and less heparin in ABG sample
Excess air and more heparin in ABG sample
Less air and more heparin in ABG sample
Less air and less heparin in ABG sample

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Excess air and more heparin in ABG sample:

 

ABG1

ABG2

Inference and interpretation

pH

6.9

6.7

Heparin excess. Since heparin is acidic pH is lowered

pO2

80

100

Air bubbles in ABG syringe

pCO2

55

20

Air bubbles in ABG syringe and dilution by excess heparin

HCO3

10

Heparin excess

 

Metabolic acidosis with respiratory acidosis

 

 

 

Incorrect Options: 

  • Option A, C & D are incorrect.

questions.text: In a 7-year-old boy presents with generalized edema, albuminuria, and hyperlipidemia . An electron microscopic of the glomerular basement membrane, in this case, is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Minimal change disease:

  • It is a case of a nephrotic syndrome characterized by
    • Massive proteinuria ( > 3.5g/ day)
    • Hypoalbuminemia ( 3g/dl)
    • Generalized edema
    • hyperlipidemia
  • The fusion of foot processes of the glomerular epithelial cells, also known as "foot process effacement," is a characteristic finding in a condition called "minimal change disease" (MCD)
  • Minimal change disease is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children.
  • The common presenting age is 2 to 6 years.
  • It may occur following a respiratory infection or routine immunization, in response to corticosteroids, or associated with other atopic disorders such as eczema.
  • On light microscopy, the glomeruli appear normal. On electron microscopy, the visceral epithelial cells show diffuse effacement of foot processes.
  • Foot process effacement is also present in membranous glomerulopathy and diabetic nephropathy.
  • Most children respond rapidly to corticosteroid therapy.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Crescentic glomerulonephritis:

  • It is a nephritic syndrome characterized by Hematuria, red cells cast in urine, hypertension, and proteinuria. 
  • It is mostly seen in RPGN.
  • Patients typically present with a combined nephrotic nephritic clinical picture.
  • The glomeruli show focal or segmental necrosis and the crescents are formed in the urinary spaces by the proliferation of parietal cells.
  • Composition of the crescents - Fibrin, Leukocytes, and Parietal epithelial (most common) and visceral epithelial cells (least common)

Option C - Acute proliferative glomerulonephritis:

  • It is a type of nephritic syndrome typically characterized by Hematuria, hypertension, and proteinuria.
  • The electron microscopy in this case will show characteristic subepithelial humps.
  • This option is incorrect since the child has presented with nephrotic range proteinuria.

Option D - Henoch-Schonlein purpura:

  • It is a type of IgA nephropathy that shows IgA deposits along the mesangium detected through immunofluorescence

questions.text:
A 10-year-old male presents to the clinic with a history of recurrent nosebleeds and easy bruising. His mother reports a family history of similar bleeding tendencies. Laboratory tests reveal a prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT), while the bleeding time (BT) and prothrombin time (PT) are within normal limits.

Given the clinical scenario consider the following statements:


	The scenario is least indicative of Von Willebrand Disease.
	Bleeding time is a sufficient rule to put VWD as a differential diagnosis.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 1 and 2 are true:

  • 1-The scenario is least indicative of Von Willebrand Disease (VWD) because the bleeding time (BT) is within normal limits, which is more characteristic of hemophilia.
  • 2-Bleeding time (BT) is mentioned to be within normal limits. This is relevant in distinguishing between hemophilia and VWD, as a normal BT is more consistent with hemophilia.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - 1 is true and 2 is false:

  • This option is incorrect because both statements 1 and 2 are true. The scenario is least indicative of Von Willebrand Disease, and bleeding time is indeed relevant in distinguishing between hemophilia and VWD.

Option B - 1 and 2 are False:

  • This option is incorrect because both statements 1 and 2 are true. The scenario is least indicative of Von Willebrand Disease, and bleeding time is indeed relevant in distinguishing between hemophilia and VWD.

Option D - 2 is true and 1 is false:

  • This option is incorrect because both statements 1 and 2 are true. The scenario is least indicative of Von Willebrand Disease, and bleeding time is indeed relevant in distinguishing between hemophilia and VWD.

questions.text: A 75-year-old female is brought by her son with progressive memory loss and difficulty in performing daily activities for almost 2 years. Neurological examination shows a decline in cognitive functions, particularly in short-term memory. Which of the following pathological changes is likely to be observed in this patient's brain?

choices.text: Neuritic plaques composed of amyloid-beta peptides
Increased number of Lewy bodies in the substantia nigra
Microglial nodules with multinucleated giant cells

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Neuritic plaques composed of amyloid-beta peptides:

  • This elderly patient presenting with dementia most likely has Alzheimer dementia.
  • Alzheimer disease is characterized by the accumulation within the brain of cerebral amyloid-β (Aβ), forming neuritic plaques, neurofibrillary tangles, and eventually progressive loss of neurons.
    • Senile plaques in the grey matter have an extracellular β-amyloid core.
    • Neurofibrillary tangles are intracellular hyperphosphorylated tau proteins.
    • Hirano bodies are intracellular eosinophilic proteinaceous rods in the hippocampus.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Spongiform degeneration in the cortex:

  • The pathology in Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease includes vacuolation or spongiform degeneration, most notably in the cerebral cortex, caudate nucleus, thalamus, putamen, and cerebellum's molecular layer.
  • Dementia is rapidly progressive (few weeks to months) with myoclonus and ataxia.

Option C - Increased number of Lewy bodies in the substantia nigra:

  • They are primarily composed of alpha-synuclein protein aggregates.
  • This change is seen in both Parkinson disease and Lewy body dementia.
  • Patients will have motor abnormalities, and dementia is a late feature.

Option D - Microglial nodules with multinucleated giant cells:

  • This is a pathology seen in HIV-associated dementia.
  • It is characterized by cognitive deficits, gait disturbance, irritability, and depressed mood.

questions.text: Most common cause of hypercalcemia in asymptomatic patient is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B  - Parathyroid adenoma:

  • Leading cause of asymptomatic Hypercalcemia= Parathyroid hyperplasia/ Adenoma.
  • Leading cause of symptomatic hypercalcemia where patient will be admitted to severity of primary illness is lung cancer.
  • Squamous cell cancer will produce PTH-related peptide.
  • Other PTH related peptide malignancies can be RCC, leukemia, lymphomas. Option D is usually iatrogenic.

 

Incorrect Options: 

  • Option A, C & D are incorrect

questions.text: A group of students was asked to study about bleeding disorders. The professor comes and asks about the disorder that is associated with a factor that helps in platelet adhesion to the wall of vessels. He also added that the intrinsic pathway is affected in this condition. Which of the following drugs is used in the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Desmopressin:

  • Desmopressin causes the release of von Willebrand's antigen from the platelets and the subendothelium where it is stored.
  • It is the best initial Rx for vWD which affects the intrinsic pathway of coagulation.

  • The three prominent roles of vWF are to:

  • Bring platelets to exposed subendothelium
  • Aggregate platelets
  • Bind to factor VIII.

  • Symptoms of vWD are caused by platelet dysfunction and deficient factor VIII but are milder than in hemophilia. vWD is the most common inherited bleeding disorder.

    Diagnosis

  • Ristocetin cofactor assay of patient plasma
  • vWF antigen level: low
  • Prolonged BT and PTT
  • PT and platelet count - normal

  • Treatment

  • Desmopressin for mild to moderate disease. It helps to release vWF from the platelets.
  • Use factor VII replacement or vWF concentrate for severe disease.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Rituximab

Option B - Eltrombopag

Option C - Romiplostim

  • These drugs are used for the treatment of ITP

questions.text: A patient presents with a single painless ulcer with a clean base and indurated borders on the genitals. Which stage of syphilis does this presentation indicate, and what is the recommended medical treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Primary syphilis, Benzathine penicillin:

  • The presentation of a single painless ulcer with a clean base and indurated borders on the genitals is characteristic of primary syphilis. The recommended medical treatment for primary syphilis is Benzathine penicillin G (2.4 million units), which is administered as a single intramuscular injection.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Secondary syphilis, Doxycycline:

  • Secondary syphilis is characterized by a systemic rash and flu-like symptoms. Doxycycline is the preferred medication to treat cases with severe penicillin allergy.

Option C - Tertiary syphilis, Ceftriaxone:

  • Tertiary syphilis is the late stage of the disease, which occurs years after the initial infection. It is characterized by the development of severe complications, such as gummas (soft, non-cancerous growths), cardiovascular abnormalities, and neurosyphilis. The presentation of a single painless ulcer with a clean base and indurated borders is more typical of primary syphilis. Ceftriaxone is not the first-line treatment for primary syphilis, it is the preferred medication for neurosyphilis in cases of severe penicillin allergy

Option D - Congenital syphilis, Azithromycin:

  • Congenital syphilis occurs when a pregnant woman with syphilis passes the infection to her unborn child. The presentation described in the question is not indicative of congenital syphilis, as it refers to an ulcer on the genitals of the patient.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old male comes to the OPD with swelling and pain in his right knee for several weeks. X-ray reveals the following findings:



A biopsy is performed, and histopathological examination of the specimen shows pseudo-rosettes. The doctor explains the proposed treatment plan comprising chemotherapy, radiotherapy and surgery. Which of the following drugs was mostly recommended by the doctor?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Vincristine 

  • Vincristine is a cytotoxic drug belonging to the class of vinca alkaloids and is used in the preferred treatment of Ewing's sarcoma. (Vinca alkaloids destabilize microtubules).

Ewing's sarcoma:

  • It originates from neuroectodermal cells of bone marrow in the diaphyseal region of long bones. It predominantly affects males aged 5-20 years.
  • It is the most common primary malignancy in children under 10 and the second most common primary malignant tumor overall.
  • It is a radio-sensitive tumor, often arising in the upper tibia and lower femur.
  • The X-ray study shows a periosteum arranged characteristically in layers, giving a typical onion-peel appearance.
  • Treatment modalities include chemotherapy with Ifosfamide, Methotrexate, and Vincristine followed by radiotherapy and limb salvage.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Vinblastine: Vinblastine is also a vinca alkaloid but not used in treating Ewing's sarcoma.

Option B - Vindesine: Vindesine, also called eldisine, is used in the treatment of malignant melanoma and uterine cancers in combination with other cytotoxic drugs.

Option D - Vinorelbine: Vinorelbine is mostly used with other cytotoxic drugs to treat non-small cell lung cancer.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman has been experiencing pain and swelling at the base of her right thumb for the past few weeks. Based on evaluation, a diagnosis is made. Which compartment of the extensor retinaculum do the tendons involved in De Quervain's tenosynovitis pass through?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 1st compartment:

  • De Quervain tenosynovitis is a condition that involves tendon entrapment affecting the first dorsal compartment of the wrist.
  • With this condition, thickening and myxoid degeneration of the tendon sheaths around the abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis develop where the tendons pass in through the fibro-osseous tunnel located along the radial styloid at the distal wrist.
  • Pain is exacerbated by thumb movement and radial and ulnar deviation of the wrist.
  • The condition typically affects women in the late pregnancy or the postpartum period.
  • Compartments of the extensor retinaculum:

Incorrect Options:

Option B - 2nd compartment: The tendons of the extensor carpi radialis longus (ECRL) and extensor carpi radialis brevis (ECRB) pass through this compartment. These tendons are not involved in De Quervain's tenosynovitis.

Option C - 3rd compartment: This compartment contains the tendon of the extensor pollicis longus (EPL), which is not affected by De Quervain's tenosynovitis.

Option D - 4th compartment: The tendons of the extensor digitorum and extensor indicis pass through this compartment. They are not implicated in De Quervain's tenosynovitis.

questions.text:
Work up of a 25-year-old hotel worker shows the following profile:

HbsAg = Negative 

Anti HBsAg= negative 

HbeAg = negative 

Anti Hbe= negative 

Total anti- HBc= positive 

What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Hepatitis B in Remote past:

  • Total Anti-Hbc is most constant marker of exposure ( current or past infection).

Incorrect Options:

Option A: chronic hepatitis B: Needs presence of surface antigen and IgG Anti-Hbc

Option B: inactive carrier: Has circulating hepatitis B surface antigen with normal aminotransferase levels, minimal or no histological evidence of liver injury, undetectable HbeAg and level of HBV DNA undetectable or present at threshold < 103IU/ml.

Option D: Window period: Needs Ig M anti-Hbc for diagnosis

questions.text: The Golgi tendon organ works as the receptor for which stimulus?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Tension:

  • The Golgi tendon organ is a mechanoreceptor for tension stimuli and the receptor for the inverse stretch reflex.
  • It consists of a netlike collection of knobby nerve endings among the fascicles of a tendon. There are 3–25 muscle fibers per tendon organ.
  • The fibers from the Golgi tendon organs are the Ib group of myelinated, rapidly conducting sensory nerve fibers.
  • The primary endings in the spindles and the Golgi tendon organs together regulate the velocity of muscle contraction, muscle length, and muscle force.
  • The interaction of spindle discharge, tendon organ discharge, and reciprocal innervation determines the firing rate of α-motor neurons.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Chemical:

  • Pain is the modality for chemical, thermal, and mechanical stimuli.
  • Polymodal receptors or chemical, thermal, and mechanical nociceptors are involved.

Option C - Touch:

  • Touch is a modality for various stimuli, such as motion, vibration, and pressure.
  • Cutaneous mechanoreceptors mediate these sensations.
  • Receptor cell types involved are the Meissner corpuscle, hair follicle receptors, Pacinian corpuscle, and Merkel cell receptors.

Option D - Thermal:

  • Temperature is sensed by thermoreceptors such as cold and warm receptors.

questions.text: Vasopressin acts on which of the following aquaporins present in the collecting duct?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Aquaporin 2:

  • Vasopressin acts on Aquaporin 2 (AQP2) channels present in the collecting duct. When vasopressin binds to its V2 receptor on the basolateral membrane of the collecting duct cells, it triggers the insertion of AQP2 channels into the apical membrane. This insertion allows for increased water reabsorption from the urine, leading to concentrated urine and water conservation.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Aquaporin 1: Aquaporin 1 (AQP1) is primarily found in the proximal tubules and descending thin segments of the loop of Henle, where it facilitates water reabsorption. It is an ADH-independent aquaporin.

Options C and D - Aquaporin 3 and Aquaporin 4: Aquaporin 3 and 4 are present in the basolateral membrane of the collecting duct, which helps in the reabsorption of water from the epithelial cell of the collecting duct to the capillary blood. Vasopressin does not regulate this channel.

questions.text: In the image shown below, what is the type of joint indicated by the arrow?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Saddle Joint:

  • The joint depicted in the image is the incudo-mallear joint.
  • The incudo-mallear joint is a saddle joint, which starts to move with sounds starting at 2 kHz.
  • The ossicular chain is held in its position by the connections of the malleus handle with the tympanic membrane, the annular ligament of the stapes, and the ligaments of the malleus and incus.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Planar joint: A planar joint, also known as a gliding joint, is a type of joint that connects two bones that are flat and of similar sizes. Examples: intercarpal joints and intertarsal joints.

Option C - Pivot joint: A pivot joint is a type of joint between two bones that is enclosed by a ligamentous ring. It allows one bone to rotate around a single axis within the ring. As a result, pivot joints are classified as uniaxial joints. Example: The atlantoaxial joint between C1 (atlas) and C2 (axis) of the vertebrae.

Option D - Ball-and-socket joint: A ball and socket joint is a type of joint where the rounded end of one bone fits into the cup-like end of another bone. Example: Glenohumeral joint.

questions.text:
Match the following esophageal disorders with their characteristic manometry findings.


	
		
			
			1. Achalasia
			
			
			a. Normal pattern peristalsis with high amplitude (>180 mm Hg) and prolonged (>6 sec) contractions
			
		
		
			
			2. Diffuse esophageal spasm
			
			
			b. Aperistalsis in the esophageal body with increased LES pressure
			
		
		
			
			3. Nutcracker esophagus
			
			
			c. Normal pattern peristalsis with relatively lesser amplitude (>120 mm Hg) and lesser duration (>2.5 sec) contractions
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 1-b, 2-c, 3-a:

Achalasia:

  • Achalasia is an esophageal smooth muscle motility disorder that occurs due to a failure of relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter. This condition causes a functional obstruction at the gastroesophageal junction.
  • Manometry demonstrates hallmark findings of aperistalsis in the esophageal body and failure of the LES to relax with ↑ LES pressure. These criteria can be used to diagnose achalasia in 90% of cases.

Diffuse esophageal spasm:

  • DES is a rare esophageal motility disorder characterized by simultaneous, uncoordinated, or rapidly propagated contractions that are accompanied by dysphagia and chest pain.
  • It is characterized by normal peristalsis but simultaneous contractions of >30% of water swallows. Other associated findings include repetitive (>2 peaks) and >120 mm Hg amplitude contractions that are >2.5 sec in duration.

Nutcracker esophagus:

  • Nutcracker esophagus is the most common and the most painful esophageal motility disorder.
  • It has normal pattern peristalsis and high amplitude >180mmHg with repetitive (>2 peaks), prolonged (>6 s) contractions, and high LES pressure (>40mmHg) on manometry.

 

Incorrect Options: 

  • Option A, B & D are incorrect

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect in relation to the image provided?

choices.text: The indicator used is starch iodide
The color changes to pink during the estimation procedure
It estimates chlorine demand in water
It contains one black cup and six white cups

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - The color changes to pink during the estimation procedure:

  • The Horrocks apparatus is utilized to assess the chlorine demand of water and comprises one black cup alongside six white cups, all of identical size and shape. Starch iodide serves as the indicator, with a color change to blue during the estimation process.
  • Markings are designated on the six white cups at progressively increasing levels. The procedure begins by preparing a solution in the black cup and adding the indicator. Water requiring disinfection is then placed in the black cup, followed by filling the six white cups with water to increasing levels. Two drops of the solution are added to each white cup.
  • The cup that changes color to blue, along with the solution, indicates the chlorine demand. Once one cup changes color, the others follow suit.
  • The amount of bleaching powder needed to disinfect 455 liters of water is calculated as (n x 2) grams, where 'n' represents the first cup to exhibit a color change.
  • Therefore, the statement in option B is incorrect.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - The indicator used is starch iodide:

  • This statement is accurate.
  • The indicator used in Horrock’s apparatus is starch iodide solution.

Option C - It estimates chlorine demand in water:

  • This statement correctly describes the purpose of Horrock’s apparatus.
  • Horrock’s apparatus is used to estimate the chlorine demand in water, which helps in determining the required chlorine dosage for disinfection purposes.

Option D - It contains one black cup and six white cups:

  • This is true about the contents of the apparatus.
  • The contents of Horrock’s apparatus include:
    • 1 black cup with a circular mark on the inside
    • 6 white cups (200 mL capacity each)
    • 2 metal spoons
    • 7 glass stirring rods
    • One special pipette
    • Two droppers
    • Starch iodide indicator solution
    • Instruction folder

questions.text: Which of the following factors is associated with a good prognosis in schizophrenia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Late age of onset:

  • When schizophrenia develops later in life, typically after the age of 40, it is often referred to as "late-onset" or "onset-type" schizophrenia. This late onset is generally associated with a milder course and better prognosis than early-onset schizophrenia. Individuals with late-onset schizophrenia tend to have less severe symptoms, better social and occupational functioning, and may respond better to treatment.

Incorrect options:

Option: B)  Presence of prominent negative symptoms: Negative symptoms in schizophrenia, such as social withdrawal, flattened affect, and decreased motivation, are often associated with a poorer prognosis. 

Option: C) Family history of schizophrenia: Family history of schizophrenia is often associated with a poorer prognosis.

Option: D) Insidious onset: An insidious onset, which refers to a gradual and slow development of symptoms, is associated with a poor prognosis.

questions.text: What best describes the observed phenomenon of apparent lid lag during downgaze in a 55-year-old female with limited right eye movement, ptosis, and a dilated right pupil following trauma?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – Pseudo von Graefe sign:

  • The clinical picture suggests that the patient is suffering from third-nerve palsy post-trauma. In case of surgical or traumatic damage to the third nerve, there can be aberrant regeneration of the nerves, where the nerve supplying the inferior rectus also stimulates the levator palpebrae superioris, which causes lid lag, a pseudo-von-Graefe sign.

Incorrect Options:

Option A – Von Graefe sign: This is a classic sign associated with thyroid eye disease (Graves' disease). It involves a lagging or delayed downward movement of the upper eyelid during an attempted downgaze. This sign is related to dysfunction of the levator palpebrae superioris muscle.

Option C – Bell's phenomenon: Bell's phenomenon is a protective mechanism where the eye rolls upward during attempted eyelid closure. It is commonly observed in conditions causing facial nerve (CN VII) palsy.

Option D – Marcus Gunn jaw-winking syndrome: This is a phenomenon seen in congenital ptosis where there is an abnormal elevation of the ptotic eyelid during jaw movements (e.g., chewing or opening the mouth). It is due to an aberrant connection between the motor branches of the trigeminal nerve and the oculomotor nerve.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old painter, has been working in the construction industry for several years. She specializes in painting and renovation projects for both residential and commercial properties. She starts experiencing fatigue, persistent abdominal pain, and frequent headaches. A physical examination showed the given findings:



Blood tests reveal elevated levels of lead. Which of the following chelating agents cannot be used in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - DESFERROXAMINE:

  • The image given demonstrates Burtonian lines (blue), which is seen in the case of lead poisoning.
  • Desferoxamine is used in iron overload. It is not used in lead poisoning.

Incorrect Options:

Option A/ B/ C - EDTA/ CUPRIMINE/ DMSA:

  • Options A, B, and C are the chelating agents used in lead poisoning.
  • The chelating agents used in lead poisoning are EDTA(Ethylenediamine tetraacetic acid)
  • , CUPRIMINE, DMSA(dimercapto succinic acid), BAL(British anti-Lewisite), and DMPS(2,3-Dimercapto-1-propanesulfonic acid).

questions.text: What is the hallmark feature of Guerin's fracture?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A- Hanging palate and teeth:

  • Guerin's fracture, also known as Le Fort I fracture, is a type of fracture in which the fracture line runs from the floor of the nose to the floor of the maxillary sinus. The hallmark feature of Guerin's fracture is a "hanging palate and teeth." This occurs due to the separation of the hard palate from the rest of the maxilla, resulting in the characteristic appearance of the palate and teeth hanging downward.

Incorrect Options:

Option B- Hanging maxilla: Hanging maxilla is part of the Le Fort II fracture, not in Le Fort I.

Option C- CSF rhinorrhea: Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) rhinorrhea is more commonly associated with Le Fort III fracture, not Le Fort I.

Option D- Epistaxis: Epistaxis is not a hallmark feature of Guerin's fracture.

questions.text:
Given below are various treatment modalities involved in the management of chronic osteomyelitis. Arrange them in the appropriate order as per the preferred treatment protocol

a) Muscle flap and skin grafting technique

b) Nafcillin/cefazolin Antibiotic therapy

c) Ilizarov technique

d) Sequesterectomy and saucerization
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - d, c, a, b:

Chronic osteomyelitis:

  • According to Waldvogel's classification, chronic osteomyelitis is osteomyelitis persisting for more than 4 weeks.
  • Most common cause - Staphylococcus aureus. The same is true in both acute and subacute osteomyelitis.
  • In foreign body implants - Staphylococcus epidermidis or Staphylococcus albus is the commonest organism.

Treatment of Osteomyelitis

  • Treatment is essentially surgical - in subacute and chronic forms.
  • In acute osteomyelitis, the treatment is mainly medical.

The 4 important steps are:

  • Radical debridement
  • Dead space management
  • Soft tissue coverage
  • Antibiotic therapy

1. Radical Debridement

  • This is achieved by sequestrectomy and saucerization.
  • Sequestrectomy is the removal of infected nonviable bone.
  • Saucerization is the conversion of a hollow cavity into a shallower cavity.
  • Any implant like plates and screws should be removed because of the likelihood of biofilm formation (source of infection), antibiotics cannot penetrate the biofilm once formed.

2. Dead Space Management

  • After completion of radical debridement, defects are created in bone and soft tissues - dead space.
  • If the dead space is not treated properly it will lead to early recurrence of infection.
  • The Ilizarov technique is an excellent technique used to treat chronic osteomyelitis.
  • It works on the principle called “Distraction Histiogenesis”.

3. Soft Tissue Coverage

  • In chronic osteomyelitis, there can be extensive scarring of muscles, fascia, and skin.
  • To resolve this, soft tissue coverage is done by creating muscle flaps and skin grafting.

4. Antibiotic Therapy

  • Staphylococcus aureus -IV nafcillin or cefazolin.
  • MRSA (Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus) -vancomycin.
  • Antibiotics are given for 4 to 6 weeks.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D:

A - b,d, a,c

C - c,d, a,b

D - a,c,b,d

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents to the fertility clinic. She has been married for 3 years and is unable to conceive. She is otherwise healthy but has delayed menstrual cycles. An ultrasound for follicle monitoring shows the absence of a developing follicle with evidence of polycystic ovaries. Which drug should be used in the first line in her next cycle for her condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option D: Letrozole

  • It is the drug of choice for induction of ovulation in a case of PCOS.
  • Mode of action:
    • Aromatase Inhibitor
    • Decrease estrogen production → inhibit negative feedback on FSH→ increases FSH → increase stimulation of follicles
  • Letrozole is preferred over clomiphene citrate because:
    • Decreases chances of multifetal pregnancy
    • Increased live birth rate

    • Risk of Ovarian Hyperstimulation Syndrome is rare

  • Given for 5 days (D5-D9)
    • Start with 2.5mg
    • Max dose 7.5mg

Anovulation Treatment:

  • Weight reduction leads to ovulation [in 30% of cases], and loss of even 5-10% weight increases insulin sensitivity and can regularize cycles
  • Aromatase Inhibitors → Letrozole [1st line Drug]
    • It inhibits the conversion of androgens to estrogens. This causes less negative feedback to the hypothalamus, which increases FSH and thus follicular development.
    • Letrozole (vs Clomiphene)
      • Higher birth rate
      • Fewer multiples
      • Better endometrial health (Clomiphene Citrate is anti-estrogenic on endometrium)
      • Better cervical mucous
      • Lesser anomalies
      • Lesser abortions
      • Lesser OHSS
  • Clomiphene Citrate causes ovulation in 80% of cases, out of which pregnancy may be achieved in 40% of cases.
  • Inj Recombinant FSH
  • Inj Human Menopausal Gonadotropin (LH + FSH)
  • Insulin sensitizer [metformin] causes ovulation in 30% of cases, however, it is not a first-line treatment

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Clomiphene citrate

  • Clomiphene citrate has been the most used drug for ovulation induction for PCOD patients with anovulation for other reasons.
  • However, it has now been replaced by letrozole as the drug of choice.

Option B: GnRH agonist

  • GnRH agonists are not the first line for ovulation induction in PCOD

Option C: Combined oral Pills

  • COCs inhibit ovulation.
  • In some cases, these can be used for pretreatment before ovulation induction, which improves success in resistant cases.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication for giving Adrenaline?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Bradycardia:

  • Atropine is given for bradycardia.
  • Adrenaline is used in anaphylaxis undiluted 0.5 mg intramuscular in 1:1000 dilution.
  • option C will require IV diluted in 1:10000 dilution.
  • Option D in ACLS protocol is managed with adrenaline.
  • The objective is to increase coronary and cerebral perfusion pressures and improve flow rates while reversible causes are sought for and managed.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, C, D are incorrect.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old patient presents with complaints of vertigo, particularly triggered by changes in head position. The test performed is shown in the image below.



What is the angle at which the patient's head should hang in the supine position?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C- 30 degrees:

  • The given clinical presentation is suspicion of BPPV, and the test performed to confirm the diagnosis is the Dix Hallpike Test. For the Dix Hallpike test, the angle at which the patient's head should hang in the supine position is 30 degrees.
  • Procedure: 
    • The patient is first made to sit on a table.
    • The patient's head is rotated by 45 degrees either to the right or to the left.
    • Then the patient is taken down in that position with the head hanging from the edge of the table (the head should hang at an angle of 30 degrees).
    • In this position, a displacement of the otolith may cause it to move into the semicircular canal duct, stimulating the labyrinth and resulting in nystagmus, which is the movement of the eyeball.
    • Once the nystagmus and vertigo have subsided, the patient is put back in the neutral position.
    • If the Dix Hallpike Test is positive, i.e., the position change causes nystagmus, and a diagnosis of BPPV is made.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- 45 degrees: This angle is associated with the initial rotation of the head in the Dix Hallpike Test, not the angle at which the head hangs in the supine position.

Option B- 90 degrees: This is not the correct angle for the Dix Hallpike Test; it is too steep. The angle is 30 degrees for the head to hang in the supine position.

Option D- 60 degrees: This angle is not used in the Dix Hallpike Test for the supine position; the correct angle is 30 degrees.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old contact lens wearer presents with sudden-onset severe eye pain, photophobia, and a purulent discharge in the left eye. On examination stromal edema and other features as in image below are note:



 Which of the following statements regarding this condition is false?

choices.text: Pneumococcus causes Ulcer Serpens also called hypopyon corneal ulcer
Hypopyon in bacterial keratitis is a sterile hypopyon containing pus cells in Anterior chamber
Nocardia is a bacterial keratitis that resembles fungal keratitis
Staphylococcus aureus is the most common bacteria causing keratitis in India

questions.solution:
Correct Option D – Staphylococcus aureus is the most common bacteria causing keratitis in India:

  • Staphylococcus aureus is known to cause keratitis, but in the Indian context, organisms like Staphylococcus epidermidis are more commonly associated with corneal infections. The prevalence of causative organisms can vary by geographic region.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pneumococcus causes Ulcer Serpens, also called hypopyon corneal ulcer.

  • True. Pneumococcus is known to cause a type of corneal ulcer called Ulcer Serpens, characterized by a snake-like pattern of corneal inflammation. This type of ulcer is associated with the presence of a hypopyon.

Option B - Hypopyon in bacterial keratitis is a sterile hypopyon containing pus cells in the anterior chamber.

  • True. Hypopyon in bacterial keratitis is sterile; it typically contains pus cells

Option C - Nocardia is a bacterial keratitis that resembles fungal keratitis.

  • Nocardia is a bacterium that can cause keratitis, and its clinical presentation may resemble fungal keratitis. This can make the diagnosis challenging and may require laboratory testing for confirmation. However bacterial keratitis has more symptoms when compared to fungal keratitis.

questions.text:
Match the following degrees of burns with their characteristics.


	
		
			
			1. First degree
			
			
			a. Epidermis + dermis + subcutaneous fat with eschar
			
		
		
			
			2. Second degree
			
			
			b. Skin + underlying structures (muscle, bone & brain)
			
		
		
			
			3. Third degree
			
			
			c. Epidermis + papillary/reticular dermis ± blisters
			
		
		
			
			4. Fourth degree
			
			
			d. Epidermis only, no blisters
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 1-d, 2-c, 3-a, 4-b:

First Degree

  • These burns are also called epidermal burns, as only the epidermis is involved. ·
  • Painful and erythematous without blister formation.
  • Heal without scarring within 5-10 days.

Second Degree

  • Also called partial thickness burns.
    • Superficial burns involve the epidermis and papillary dermis with painful blisters. Heal without scarring in 7-14 days.
    • Deep burns involve the epidermis and reticular dermis without blisters. Heal with scarring in 3-9 weeks.

Third Degree

  • They are also called full thickness burns.
  • Involvement of epidermis + dermis + subcutaneous fat.
  • They are often accompanied by black-colored leathery eschars.

Fourth Degree

  • Involvement of skin + underlying structures (muscle, bone & brain).

 

Incorrect  Options: 

  • Option A, B & D are incorrect

questions.text:
Match the correct images of the crystal to the corresponding ureteral stones.


	
		
			
			1
			
			
			
			
			
			a. Uric acid
			
		
		
			
			2
			
			
			
			
			
			b. Calcium oxalate
			
		
		
			
			3
			
			
			
			
			
			c. Cystine

			 
			
		
		
			
			4
			
			
			
			
			
			d. Struvite
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 1-b, 2-a, 3-d, 4-c:

  • Calcium oxalate stone:
    • Kidney stones can develop when there is dehydration and a high concentration of calcium, oxalate, cystine, or phosphate.
    • Kidney stones can be of various types. The most common kidney stones are calcium oxalate stones.
  • Uric acid stone:
    • A kidney stone is generated from substances present in the urine.
    • After forming, the stone may remain in the kidney or pass through the ureter and into the lower urinary system.
  • Struvite stone:
    • Due to their close ties to urea-splitting urinary tract infections (UTIs), struvite (magnesium ammonium phosphate) stones are frequently referred to as "infection stones.”
  • Cystine stone:
    • Cystine stones are formed due to inherited defects in the transport of the amino acid cystine, leading to excessive excretion and causing cystinuria.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, C and D are incorrect

questions.text: An intern has his first day of rotation in the operation room; he asks a resident about the type of sutures and their preferred uses. Which of the following is true regarding sutures?

choices.text: Catgut is a natural absorbable suture
Monocryl is used for sternotomy closure
Vicryl is the preferred suture for vascular anastomosis
Prolene suture is preferred for bile duct and urinary bladder

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Catgut is a natural absorbable suture:

  • This statement is correct; catgut is a natural absorbable suture

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Monocryl is used for sternotomy closure:

  • Monocryl is a synthetic suture. It is most commonly used for subcuticular suturing.
  • Stainless steel is used for sternotomy closure.
  • Therefore, this statement is incorrect.

Option C - Vicryl is the preferred suture for vascular anastomosis:

  • Vicryl is a synthetic, absorbable suture.
  • Preferred suture for vascular anastomosis is prolene.

Option D - Prolene suture is preferred for bile duct and urinary bladder:

  • Vicryl is the preferred suture for bile duct and urinary bladder.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents to a community health center with a persistent cough, weight loss, and night sweats. On further evaluation, he is diagnosed with pulmonary tuberculosis. As part of his management, the healthcare provider educates him about the importance of the national initiative for tuberculosis control. Which year was the "End TB Strategy" launched by the World Health Organization (WHO)?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 2015:

  • The World Health Organization launched the "End TB Strategy" in 2015.
  • The strategy aims to end the global tuberculosis epidemic, with targets set for reductions in TB deaths and incidence rates.
  • It focuses on integrated patient-centered care and prevention, bold policies and supportive systems, and intensified research and innovation.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, C and D are incorrect.

questions.text: A young patient developed hyperpigmentation of distal fingers after being hospitalized post adrenalectomy. What could be the possible cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Nelson syndrome:

  • Post adrenalectomy ACTH values will rise.
  • Since ACTH has partial MSH like activity it will cause hyperpigmentation over palms, finger and sole creases.
  • Option A is seen due to autoimmunity.
  • Option C has Hypertension with hypokalemic alkalosis.
  • Option D leads to lemon on sticks appearance.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is implicated in the development of methemoglobinemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Prilocaine:

  • Methemoglobinemia is a condition in which diminution of the oxygen-carrying capacity of circulating hemoglobin occurs due to the conversion of some or all of the four iron species from the reduced ferrous (Fe2+) state to the oxidized ferric (Fe3+) state.
  • Ferric iron is unable to bind and transport oxygen.
  • Acquired methemoglobinemia occurs due to exposure to direct oxidizing agents such as a few local anesthetics, particularly prilocaine and benzocaine.
  • Other mechanisms of causation include:
    • Indirect oxidation (nitrates)
    • Metabolic activation (anilines and dapsone)

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and C: Lidocaine, bupivacaine, and mepivacaine are also local anesthetics but are not known to cause methemoglobinemia.

questions.text:
Below is a list of statements about carcinoma gallbladder. Identify the correct statements.


	Risk factors are obesity, smoking, porcelain gallbladder
	Clinical features include repeated biliary colic, hard mass in RUQ, ascites
	Investigation of choice is CECT
	Management for stage T2A is with laparoscopic cholecystectomy
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Statements 2 and 3:

Statement 2

  • Patients with carcinoma gallbladder have a long history of repeated episodes of biliary colic. They experience an increased frequency of episodes, increased pain severity, and sudden changes in pain character.
  • Late signs on examination are a hard mass in RUQ, jaundice, and ascites.

Statement 3

  • Ultrasound is the first investigation that is ordered, and CECT is the investigation of choice.
  • Findings are:
    • Thickened gallbladder wall with gallstones
    • Gallbladder replaced by a mass arising from fundus and protruding into the lumen
    • Lymph nodes at porta hepatis

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D:

Statement 1

  • Smoking is a risk factor for all GI, hepatobiliary, and pancreatic malignancies, except carcinoma gallbladder.
  • Risk factors for Ca gallbladder are choledochal cyst, obesity, gallstone >3cm, PSC, adenomatous polyp, chronic typhoid carrier state, and porcelain gallbladder.

Statement 4

  • Management for stage IIA or T2A includes extended cholecystectomy.
    • Port site excision is also performed
    • Not an isolated procedure
    • No survival advantages and only prognostic importance
  • Laparoscopic cholecystectomy is limited to stage IA or T1A.

questions.text: Which of the following is the dosage of MgSO4 given as a loading dose under the Pritchard regimen?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A -14 grams of MgSO4:

  • The loading dose of MgSO4 given under the Pritchard regimen is 14 grams of MgSO4
  • 4 grams of 20% MgSO4 by slow i.v
  • 10 grams of MgSO4 IM + 1 ml lidocaine (to reduce pain on injection site)
  • 5 grams -I.M. in each buttock.
  • 2 grams of MgSO4 IV if there is no control in convulsions
  • Maintenance dose: 5 grams of 50% MgSO4 i.m in the alternate buttock every 4 hours.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, & D:

  • These are not the dosages of MgSO4 given as a loading dose under the Pritchard regimen.

questions.text:
Match the following organisms with their intermediate hosts.


	
		
			
			Organisms
			
			
			Host
			
		
		
			
			1. Taenia solium
			
			
			a. Snail
			
		
		
			
			2. Echinococcus granulosus
			
			
			b. Pig
			
		
		
			
			3. Fasciola hepatica
			
			
			c. Sheep
			
		
		
			
			4. Schistosoma
			
			
			d. Snail
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 1-b, 2-c, 3-d, 4-a:

1. Taenia solium:

  • Definitive host: Man
  • Intermediate host: Pig.

2. Echinococcus granulosus:

  • Definitive host: Dog
  • Intermediate host: Sheep
  • Accidental host: Man

3. Fasciola hepatica:

  • Definitive host: Man
  • Intermediate host: 1st – snail, 2nd – fresh aquatic plants

4. Schistosoma:

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option C for an explanation.

questions.text:
Match the given images to their descriptions:


	
		
			
			1.

			
			
			
			a) Sunflower cataract
			
		
		
			
			2.

			
			
			
			b) Morgagnian cataract
			
		
		
			
			3.

			
			
			
			c) Snowflake cataract
			
		
		
			
			4.

			
			
			
			d) Posterior subcapsular cataract
questions.solution:
Correct Option C- 1-d, 2-a, 3-b, 4-c:

Posterior Subcapsular Cataract:

  • PSC is the lenticular opacity that causes maximum diminution of vision because this opacity is in proximity to the nodal point of the eye i.e., the first focal point/optical center of the eye where light rays are focused. It is just behind the lens.

  • PSC forms due to dysplasia of E cells that migrate posteriorly. Wedl cells/Bladder cells are E cells that are responsible for formation of PSC.

Sunflower Cataract:

  • The image below depicts a Sunflower cataract: It is associated with chalcosis condition characterized by accumulation of copper or copper alloy in the eye.
  • It is caused by foreign copper body or Wilson’s disease.

Morgagnian Cataract:

  • It is a type of hyper mature cataract

  • Liquefaction of the cortex causes the nucleus to float, Wrinkling of the capsule are observed.

Snowflake/ Snowstorm cataract:

  • It is associated with diabetes mellitus
  • It occurs due to sorbitol accumulation. Sorbitol is hyperosmotic, and any hydration will lead to cataracts.
  • The enzyme responsible for the Sorbitol pathway is NADPH-dependent Aldose Reductase.

questions.text: The labor and delivery process involves certain movements that the fetal presenting part undergoes while traversing the birth canal in response to uterine contractions. These Cardinal movements in sequence in labor are;

choices.text: Engagement→ flexion→ descent→ internal rotation→ extension→ ext. rotation
Engagement→ flexion→ descent→ external rotation→ expulsion
Engagement→ descent→ flexion→ internal rotation→ extension→ external rotation→ expulsion

questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option C: 

Correct sequence of cardinal movements during labor:

  1. Engagement: The fetal presenting part enters the pelvic inlet.
  2. Descent: The presenting part moves downward through the birth canal.
  3. Flexion: The fetal head flexes as it encounters resistance from the pelvic floor, allowing the smallest fetal diameter to present to the maternal pelvis.
  4. Internal rotation: The fetal head rotates to accommodate the shape of the maternal pelvis.
  5. Extension: The fetal head extends as it passes under the pubic symphysis.
  6. External rotation: After the head is delivered, it rotates to realign with the shoulders for optimal delivery.
  7. Expulsion: The rest of the body is delivered.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are incorrect, and the correct option is explained above.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with severe headaches, palpitations, and sweating for the past few weeks. His blood pressure is markedly elevated (160/90 mmHg). Plasma fractionated-metanephrines are high. Initial imaging is suspicious for metastatic disease. What is the best next investigation for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - MIBG scan:

  • In a patient with clinic features suggestive of pheochromocytoma such as this one, the next step in evaluation after biochemical tests is to locate the tumor using imaging studies.
  • CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis is the recommended initial imaging test to locate the tumor. MRI is an acceptable alternative.
  • For metastatic disease, PET scanning or MIBG scan are recommended.
  • MIBG (metaiodobenzylguanidine) is a radiopharmaceutical used to detect and localize neuroendocrine tumors, particularly those arising from the adrenal medulla (such as pheochromocytoma) or sympathetic nervous system (such as neuroblastoma).
  • It works by being taken up by neuroendocrine cells and emitting gamma radiation, which can be detected by imaging.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Tc-99m pertechnetate:

  • This is primarily used in nuclear medicine for thyroid imaging, parathyroid imaging, and evaluating salivary gland function.

Option B - HIDA scan:

  • This scan is used to evaluate the liver, gallbladder, bile ducts, and upper part of the small intestine.

Option D -HMPAO SPECT:

  • This is a nuclear medicine imaging technique used primarily for brain imaging, especially in assessing cerebral blood flow and identifying areas of brain activity.

questions.text: Which of the following symptoms are commonly associated with discontinuation syndrome?

choices.text: Dry mouth, blurred vision, and urinary retention

questions.solution:
Correct Option is D: Flu-like symptoms, insomnia, and nausea

  • Discontinuation syndrome refers to a set of symptoms that can occur when a person abruptly stops or significantly reduces the dosage of certain medications. It is particularly associated with medications that affect the central nervous system, such as antidepressants, antipsychotics, and benzodiazepines.

Common Features:

  • Timing: Symptoms typically emerge shortly after the reduction or cessation of medication.
  • Duration: The duration of symptoms can vary, but they often resolve within a few weeks to a month.
  • The mnemonic FINISH is commonly used to summarize the symptoms of antidepressant discontinuation syndrome.
    • Flu-like symptoms: Including lethargy, fatigue, headache, achiness, and sweating.
    • Insomnia: Often accompanied by vivid dreams or nightmares.
    • Nausea: Sometimes leading to vomiting.
    • Imbalance: Manifested as dizziness, vertigo, or light-headedness.
    • Sensory disturbances: Such as "burning," "tingling," "electric-like," or "shock-like" sensations.
    • Hyperarousal: Characterized by anxiety, irritability, agitation, aggression, mania, or jerkiness.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Dry mouth, blurred vision, and urinary retention: These symptoms are commonly associated with anticholinergic side effects of certain medications, but they are not characteristic of discontinuation syndrome.

Option B - Diarrhoea, restlessness, and hyperreflexia: These symptoms are more characteristic of serotonin syndrome, which is a potentially life-threatening condition caused by excessive serotonin activity. They are not typically observed in discontinuation syndrome.

Option C - Agitation, seizures, and hyperthermia: These symptoms are also indicative of serotonin syndrome, which is a severe and potentially life-threatening condition. They are not typical of discontinuation syndrome.

questions.text: Which vector is involved in causing flu-like illness, headache, maculopapular rash, eschar formation, and lymphadenopathy in a 46-year-old man who was accidentally infected by 6-legged larvae?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Trombiculid mite:

  • The vector involved in causing the flu-like illness, headache, maculopapular rash, eschar formation, and lymphadenopathy in the 46-year-old man who was accidentally infected by 6-legged larvae (trombiculid mites larvae - chiggers)) is likely responsible for transmitting scrub typhus.

Scrub Typhus:

  • Orientia tsutsugamushi causes scrub typhus.
  • Transmitted by Chiggerosis larvae.
  • Clinical manifestations: Triad of black Eschar at the site of mite attachment, regional lymphadenopathy, maculopapular rash (which starts from the trunk up to extremities). The symptoms start with fever, headache, and conjunctival injection. Encephalitis and pneumonia may be seen in severe cases.
  • In India, it's confined to hilly regions.
  • Five antigenic types have been identified: Boryong, Gilliam, Karp, Kato, and Kangwon.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Hard tick (Ixodidae):

  • Hard tick have one, two, or three host life cycles.
  • It causes Rocky Mountain spotted fever, Lyme disease, and American babesiosis.

Option B - Soft tick (Argasidae):

  • Soft tick transmits B. duttonii, B. hermsii and causes tick-borne relapsing fever.

Option C - Louse (Pleural lice):

  • These are parasites present in human hair that feed on human blood.
  • The louse can transmit epidemic relapsing fever, Bartonella Quintana, and epidemic typhus diseases.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male presents with severe watery diarrhea after recent travel to an area with poor sanitation. Stool sample examination reveals comma or curved-shaped, Gram-negative organisms. Culture on a selective medium shows yellow colonies. Which organism is the likely cause of the patient's gastrointestinal infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Option  C - Vibrio cholerae:

  • The correct answer is Vibrio cholerae. The use of Thiosulfate Citrate Bile Salt Sucrose (TCBS) agar is a selective and differential medium commonly used to isolate and identify Vibrio cholerae, the causative agent of cholera. As vibrio cholerae is a sucrose fermenter, it turns TCBS agar yellow.

Incorrect Option:

Option A - Escherichia coli: Escherichia coli is a Gram-negative, straight rod bacteria associated with gastrointestinal infections. It grows on a selective medium like MacConkey agar (smooth pink colonies due to lactose fermentation), Deoxycholate citrate agar (DCA), and Xylose lysine deoxycholate (XLD).

Option B - Shigella spp.: Shigella spp. are Gram-negative rod bacteria. These bacteria also grow on selective mediums like MacConkey agar (colorless colonies), Deoxycholate citrate agar (DCA), and Xylose lysine deoxycholate (XLD).

Option D - Vibrio parahaemolyticus: Vibrio parahaemolyticus does not ferment sucrose, so colonies on TCBS (Thiosulphate-citrate-bile salt-sucrose) agar are green, with an opaque, raised center and flat translucent periphery.

questions.text:
Match the following salivary gland tumors with their diagnostic modalities and treatment of choice.


	
		
			
			1. Pleomorphic adenoma
			
			
			a. Total parotidectomy ± radical neck dissection
			
		
		
			
			2. Papillary cystadenoma lymphomatosis
			
			
			b. FNAC, MRI, excision with widest cuff of normal tissue with postoperative radiotherapy
			
		
		
			
			3. Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
			
			
			c. Tc-99m pertechnetate scan, superficial parotidectomy
			
		
		
			
			4. Adenoid cystic carcinoma
			
			
			d. FNAC, superficial parotidectomy
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 1-d, 2-c, 3-a, 4-b:

Pleomorphic adenoma

  • It is the most common benign salivary gland tumor.
  • FNAC is the investigation of choice.
  • Treatment of choice is superficial parotidectomy.
  • Pleomorphic adenoma involving sublingual or submandibular or minor salivary gland is treated with excision of the involved gland.

Papillary cystadenoma lymphomatosis

  • It is derived from salivary inclusion tissue of lymph nodes and is exclusively seen in the parotid gland. Also called Warthin tumor.
  • FNAC is the IOC. It appears as a hot spot on Tc-99m pertechnetate scan.
  • Treatment of choice is superficial parotidectomy.

Mucoepidermoid carcinoma

  • It is composed of epidermoid (squamous) cells and mucin-secreting cells.
  • Low-grade is treated with superficial/total parotidectomy.
  • High-grade is treated with total parotidectomy ± radical neck dissection.

Adenoid cystic carcinoma

  • It has perineural invasion with skip lesions, involving most commonly facial nerve > trigeminal nerve.
  • FNAC is the IOC. MRI helps detect early perineural spread & intracranial extension.
  • Treatment:
    • Excision with the widest cuff of normal tissue around the tumor, as it has skip lesions
    • Post-operative radiotherapy to prevent recurrence

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A, C & D are incorrect

questions.text: Reflex responsible for tachycardia during right atrial distension is?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Bain bridge reflex:

  • The Bainbridge reflex is a cardiovascular reflex that increases heart rate in response to increased blood volume in the right atrium.
  • Special pressure sensors called baroreceptors (or veno-atrial stretch receptors) located in the right atrium of the heart detect increases in the volume and pressure of blood returned to the heart.
  • These receptors transmit information along the vagus nerve (10th cranial nerve) to the central nervous system.
  • This response activates sympathetic nerve pathways that increase the strength of contraction of the heart muscle and heart rate (tachycardia).

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Bezold-Jarisch reflex:

  • The Bezold-Jarisch reflex is an inhibitory reflex usually denoted as a cardioinhibitory reflex defined as bradycardia, vasodilation, and hypotension resulting from the stimulation of cardiac receptors.
  • The Bezold-Jarisch reflex originates from inhibitory mechanoreceptors in the left ventricle (particularly the infero-posterior wall).

Option C - Cushing reflex:

  • The Cushing reflex is a physiological nervous system response to acute elevations of intracranial pressure (ICP), resulting in Cushing’s triad of widened pulse pressure (increasing systolic, decreasing diastolic), hypertension, bradycardia, and irregular respirations.

Option D - Baroreceptor reflex:

  • Baroreceptors are present in the carotid sinus, arch of aorta, and adventitial layer of blood vessels.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy with large calves has difficulty in standing up from sitting position on ground. Which of the following tests is best for confirmation of diagnosis of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Peripheral blood leucocyte DNA​​:

Laboratory Features:

  • Serum CK levels are usually elevated.
  • Muscle biopsies demonstrate dystrophic features.
  • Western blot analysis of muscle biopsy samples demonstrates absent dystrophin in DMD or reduction in levels or size of dystrophin in BMD.
  • In both disorders, mutations can be established using DNA from peripheral blood leukocytes.
  • In most cases, muscle biopsies are no longer performed when DMD or BMD is suspected, as genetic testing is less invasive, less costly, and routinely available.
  • Deletions within or duplications of the dystrophin gene are common in both DMD and BMD; in ~95% of cases, the mutation does not alter the translational reading frame of messenger RNA.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B, C & D are Incorrect.

questions.text:
The given table shows various ages and treatment modalities for the deformity shown below:



 Match them accordingly.


	
		
			
			1) 0 to 2 weeks
			
			
			a) Dilwyn Evans procedure
			
		
		
			
			2) 2 to 8 weeks
			
			
			b) Turco procedure
			
		
		
			
			3) 8 weeks to 5 yrs
			
			
			c) Triple arthrodesis
			
		
		
			
			4) 5 to 10 yrs
			
			
			d) Manipulation
			
		
		
			
			5) >10 years
			
			
			e) Ponseti method
questions.solution:
Correct Option B- 1-d,2-e,3-b,4-a,5-c:

The deformity demonstrated in the image is CTEV

1. 0 to 2 weeks d) Manipulation
2. 2 to 8 weeks e) Ponseti method
3. 8 weeks to 5 yrs b) Turco procedure
4. 5 to 10 yrs a) Dilwyn Evans procedure
5. >10 years c) Triple arthrodesis

questions.text:
Which of the following are examples of Synchondrosis joints?


	Xiphisternal joint
	Spheno-occipital joint
	Epiphysio-diaphyseal joint
	Manubrio-sternal joint
	Costo-Sternal joints
questions.solution:
Option A: Only 1, 2 and 3 are correct

  • Synchondroses are primary cartilaginous unions between bones composed entirely of hyaline cartilage.
  • These joints are immovable and mostly temporary. As the growth ceases, they undergo synostosis (i.e., the hyaline cartilage plate is completely replaced by bone).
    • The xiphisternal joint is a synchondrosis joint. Some authors mention it as symphysis.
    • The spheno-occipital joint is a synchondrosis joint between the basisphenoid and basiocciput bones, which, together, when joined, form the clivus. When fused, the synchondrosis is often called the spheno-occipital suture - this is a misnomer - as anatomically, it is not a suture.
    • The epiphysis-diaphyseal joint between the epiphyses and diaphysis of a growing long bone is a synchondrosis, which later undergoes synostosis.

Incorrect Options B, C and D: 

  • The manubrio-sternal joint is a secondary cartilaginous (symphysis) joint.
  • Costo-sternal joints are plane synovial joints of the costal cartilages of the true ribs with the sternum.

questions.text: In a community medicine study assessing the efficacy of a new vaccination program, researchers aim to determine if the program reduces the incidence of a specific infectious disease in a population. They set the significance level (α) at 0.05. During analysis, they discover a statistically significant decrease in disease incidence among vaccinated individuals compared to the control group. However, upon further investigation, it is found that the decrease in disease incidence is not actually attributable to the vaccination program. Which of the following is not true about Type 1 error?

choices.text: The null hypothesis is false but rejected

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - The null hypothesis is false but rejected:

  • The correct statement would be: “The null hypothesis is true but rejected.”
  • Type 1 error means stating that there is an effect or difference when none exists (H0 incorrectly rejected in favor of H1).

 

Reality

H1

H0

Study rejects H0

Power (1-β)

Type 1 error (α)

Study does not reject H0

Type 2 error (β)

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - α error:

  • α error refers to the probability of rejecting the null hypothesis when it is actually true. In this case, the researchers set the significance level (α) at 0.05, indicating the threshold for accepting or rejecting the null hypothesis. Therefore, α error is related to this scenario.

Option B - False positive trial:

  • A false positive trial occurs when the intervention appears effective, but in reality, it does not have the intended effect. In this scenario, the apparent decrease in disease incidence among vaccinated individuals constitutes a false positive result because the vaccination program is not the cause of the observed reduction.

Option C - Serious error:

  • Type 1 is a serious error in hypothesis testing as it can lead to incorrect conclusions and potentially harmful decisions, such as implementing an ineffective intervention or treatment.

questions.text: Lung cancer patient is having hyperpigmentation of palmar and sole creases. Which of the following is responsible for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - P.O.M.C:

  • Ectopic ACTH production leads to excess production of P.O.M.C (pro-opiomelanocortin also called Pro-Gamma-MSH) is a precursor molecule to MSH that leads to hyperpigmentation of palmar and sole creases seen in Cushing syndrome.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B, C & D are incorrect.

questions.text:
A 1-month-old male infant presents with poor feeding, vomiting, and jaundice. Physical examination reveals hepatomegaly and cataracts. Enzyme deficiency is suspected. The lab technician analyzes the infant’s urine using the following test.



What is this test called?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Benedict’s Test:

  • This infant's likely diagnosis is classic galactosemia, an inborn error of galactose metabolism resulting from galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase deficiency.
  • Levels of galactose-1-phosphate reach toxic levels, and galactose may be alternatively reduced to its sugar alcohol form, galactitol, which causes tissue damage.

  • Benedict’s test detects the presence/absence of a reducing substance in a given solution.
  • Color change from blue → green → yellow/orange → red indicates the presence of a reducing sugar.
  • The resulting color depends on the concentration of the reducing sugar in the solution. Therefore, it is called a semi-quantitative test.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Mucic Acid Test: The mucic acid test is highly specific and detects the presence of galactose and lactose. The formation of white crystals indicates the presence of galactose.

Option B - Barfoed’s Test: Barfoed's test detects the presence of reducing monosaccharides. It is based on the reduction of copper(II) acetate to copper(I) oxide (Cu2O), which forms a brick-red precipitate.

Option C - Seliwanoff's Test: Seliwanoff's test distinguishes between aldose and ketose sugars. If the sugar contains a ketone group, it is a ketose. If a sugar contains an aldehyde group, it is an aldose. This test relies on the principle that, when heated, ketoses are more rapidly dehydrated than aldoses.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman was previously diagnosed with leukemia, and her blood smear is shown below.  The flow cytometry test results revealed that the sample was positive for CD 5, CD 23, and CD 200. She is on treatment, and now she complains of feeling feverish every day and experiencing rapid unintentional weight loss. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for her current symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Richter transformation:

This patient’s symptoms are suggestive of Richter's transformation.

  • Richter transformation or Richter syndrome is a rare complication of chronic lymphocytic leukemia.
  • This syndrome is characterized by the sudden transformation of CLL into a significantly aggressive form of large-cell lymphoma.
  • The most common symptoms include sudden clinical deterioration, characterized by an increase in lymphadenopathy, usually painless areas of swelling in the neck, axilla, spleen, and groin.
  • Worsening B symptoms (unexplained weight loss, fever, night sweats).
  • The gold standard for diagnosing Richter transformation is histological documentation with open biopsy.
  • Diagnosis by flow cytometry positive for CD19/20, CD 5/23.
  • Fludarabine is the drug of choice for management.
  • The image below demonstrates enlarged cells with pleomorphic nuclei, less condensed chromatin, prominent nucleoli, and scant cytoplasm.

(The image shows the findings consistent with Richter transformation)

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the OPD of a nearby medical college for a routine check-up. An intern takes up the case. His blood pressure is recorded as 140/90 mmHg. The patient mentions that his blood pressure has always been on the higher side. This reminds the intern of a blood pressure-related phenomenon. Which of the following is true regarding this phenomenon?

choices.text: Individuals with higher blood pressures tend to maintain those higher levels as they age
Individuals with lower blood pressures do not continue to have lower levels as they age

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Individuals with higher blood pressures tend to maintain those higher levels as they age :

  • This option is accurate in the context of the blood pressure tracking phenomenon.
  • Blood pressure tracking refers to the tendency for individuals to maintain their relative position in the blood pressure distribution over time.
  • It does not imply that hypertensive individuals will always remain hypertensive; rather, it suggests that individuals with higher blood pressure levels tend to maintain those higher levels as they age.
  • This knowledge can be applied in identifying children and adolescents “at risk” of developing hypertension in the future

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Blood pressure increases with age:
