  • Blood pressure tends to increase with age due to factors such as decreased elasticity of blood vessels and changes in vascular structure. However, this is not the essence of the phenomenon of blood pressure tracking.

Option B - Blood pressure decreases with age:

  • This option is not consistent with the phenomenon of blood pressure tracking.
  • While there may be individual cases where blood pressure decreases with age, the general trend observed in populations is an increase in blood pressure with age.

Option D - Individuals with lower blood pressures do not continue to have lower levels as they age:

  • For Individuals with lower blood pressure at a younger age, blood pressure tracking suggests that they are likely to maintain those lower levels over time.

questions.text: Choose the option that accurately describes the cardiac defects (in green) represented in the given image:

choices.text: VSD + Pulmonary stenosis + Overriding of aorta + Right ventricular hypertrophy
VSD + Pulmonary stenosis + Overriding of aorta + Right ventricular hypertrophy + Atrial Septal defect
VSD + Pulmonary stenosis + Overriding of aorta + Right ventricular hypertrophy + Transposition of great vessels
VSD + Pulmonary stenosis + Overriding of aorta + Right ventricular hypertrophy + Patent ductus arteriosus

questions.solution:
Option A: VSD + Pulmonary stenosis + Overriding of aorta + Right ventricular hypertrophy

Tetralogy of Fallot: 

  • Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is the most common cyanotic heart disease in children; it includes a combination of four heart defects that commonly occur together. The four defects are:
  1. Ventricular septal defect (VSD): A VSD is due to a defect in the interventricular septum and is usually large and unrestricted. A loud and harsh holosystolic murmur is heard at the left lower sternal border.
  2. Pulmonary stenosis: The narrowing of the pulmonic valve restricts the blood flow to the lungs. This, in turn, leads to right ventricular hypertrophy. This presents a systolic ejection murmur best heard at the left second intercostal space.
  3. Overriding of the aorta: An overriding aorta is a congenital cardiac defect where the aorta is mispositioned directly over a ventricular septal defect instead of over the left ventricle.
  4. Right ventricular hypertrophy: Physiologically, pulmonic stenosis causes concentric hypertrophy of the right ventricle without cardiac enlargement and increased pressure in the right ventricle. The right ventricular pressure is as high as the left ventricular or the aortic pressure, and a right-to-left shunt appears to decompress the right ventricle

 

  • The most common symptom is a bluish discoloration of the skin, lips, and nail beds. -This may come on in sudden spells, called Tet spells
  • During the spell, babies may have difficulty breathing and trouble feeding.

Incorrect Options:
Options B, C, D:

  • The Tetralogy of Fallot + atrial septal defect constitutes the Pentalogy of Fallot.
  • TOF has no association with transposition of great vessels and patent ductus arteriosus.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old male presents with complaints of gradual hearing loss over the past few years. His medical history includes hypertension and type 2 diabetes. During the pure-tone audiometry, the following findings can be seen:



What is the most likely type of hearing loss?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B- Sensorineural hearing loss:

  • The given scenario, with pure tone audiometry showing a downward-sloping graph, is suggestive of presbycusis. Presbyacusis is an age-related Sensory Neural Hearing Loss.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- Conductive hearing loss: The downward-sloping graph on PTA and the clinical findings suggest a diagnosis of Presbycusis, which is a sensory-neural type of hearing loss, not conductive hearing loss.

Option C- Mixed hearing loss: The downward-sloping graph on PTA and the clinical findings suggest a diagnosis of Presbycusis, which is a sensory-neural type of hearing loss, not a mixed hearing loss.

Option D- Normal hearing: The patient's complaint of gradual hearing loss and the findings on pure-tone audiometry do not support normal hearing.

questions.text: A child was brought to the clinic for MMR vaccination. The doctor in the clinic asked one of the students about the strain used for the Mumps vaccine. Which of the following is the strain of this vaccine?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Jeryl Lynn strain:

  • This is the strain of the mumps vaccine.
  • Vaccine strains used only on a limited scale are Hoshino, Torii, and NKM-46.
  • Rubini strain is discontinued because of its low efficacy. 

 

Incorrect Options:

Options B - RA27/3:

  • This is the strain of the Rubella vaccine

Option C - Edmonston Zagreb:

  • This is the strain of the Measles vaccine

Option D - Ty21a:

  • This is the strain of the Typhoid vaccine

questions.text:
Match the following health management methods with their correct descriptions.


	
		
			
			1. Cost Accounting
			
			
			
				Analyze the appropriateness of the current staff and job description, and standardize performance
			
			
		
		
			
			2. Network Analysis
			
			
			b. Helps choose the best alternative and decide the best course based on cost-effectiveness
			
		
		
			
			3. System Analysis
			
			
			c. Cost structure of a program
			
		
		
			
			4. Planning, Programming, and Budgeting System
			
			
			d. A graphic plan of all events to be completed in order to reach an end objective
questions.solution:
Correct Option D. 1-c, 2-d, 3-b, 4-a:

 

1. Cost Accounting

c. Cost structure of a program

2. Network Analysis

d. A graphic plan of all events to be completed in order to reach an end objective.

3. System Analysis

b. Helps choose the best alternative and decide the best course based on cost-effectiveness

4. Planning, Programming, and Budgeting System

a. Analyze the appropriateness of the current staff and job description, and standardize performance


 

  • Health management techniques are of two types - qualitative and quantitative.
  • The table given in the question comprises several quantitative management methods.

Cost accounting: It refers to the cost structure of a program, considering all expenses.

  • Recurring cost structure
  • Non-recurring cost structure
  • Purpose:
    • Helps to know the expenses to control costs.
    • Planning and allocation of resources.
    • Pricing of cost reimbursement.

Network Analysis: It is a graphic plan of all events to be completed in order to reach an end objective. It consists of:

  • PERT - Program, Evaluation, and Review Technique
  • CPM - Critical Path Method

System Analysis: It helps choose the best alternative and decide the best course based on cost-effectiveness.

Planning, Programming, and Budgeting System: It is the budget framework of a program.

  • PPBS analyzes the appropriateness of the current staff and job description and standardizes performance.
  • Determines manpower needs.

questions.text: Which of the following serological markers represent chronic hepatitis?

choices.text: HBsAg positive, IgM anti-HBc positive, and anti-HBs negative
HBsAg positive, IgG anti-HBc positive, and anti-HBs negative
HBsAg negative, anti-HBc positive, and anti-HBs positive
HBsAg negative, anti-HBc negative, and anti-HBs negative

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - HBsAg positive, IgG anti-HBc positive, and anti-HBs negative:

  • HBsAg positive, IgG anti-HBc positive, and anti-HBs negative indicate chronic infection. The presence of IgG anti-HBc positive suggests a chronic infection.
  • Hepatitis B is also called a silent killer due to its very late symptoms despite the onset of infection. Blood tests are mostly performed to detect this virus.
  • It affects the hepatic system and causes inflammation. It targets the hepatocytes and replicates inside them to make multiple copies. These copies infect the other cells, and the infection spreads in the body.

Incorrect Options:
Option A - HBsAg positive, IgM anti-HBc positive, and anti-HBs negative:

  • This scenario suggests that the patient is suffering from early acute hepatitis B infection. The presence of IgM anti-HBc suggests an acute infection 

Option C - HBsAg negative, anti-HBc positive, and anti-HBs positive:

  • This scenario suggests that the patient had an infection and is now recovering from it. The presence of anti-HBs positive suggests the patient had an infection and is in recovery.

Option D - HBsAg negative, anti-HBc negative, and anti-HBs positive:

  • This scenario suggests that the patient never had an infection and is immunised against hepatitis B infection.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a history of alcohol use disorder is brought to the ED with confusion following a motor vehicle accident. A CT scan of the head is performed. The patient is subsequently diagnosed with a pathology resulting from the rupture of intracranial bridging veins. Which of the following is the most likely CT scan finding in this patient?

choices.text: Hyperdense lesion with surrounding hypodense edema

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Hyperdense, crescent-shaped lesion:

  • Rupture of bridging veins results in a type of intracranial hemorrhage called subdural hematoma. It occurs most often in patients of older age and chronic alcohol use disorder.
  • It is mostly caused by trauma, even mild. Boxing injuries are also implicated.
  • Clinical features may include confusion, drowsiness, ipsilateral pupil dilatation, and contralateral hemiparesis.
  • In acute SDH caused by high-energy traumatic impact, CT scan shows a hyperdense, crescent-shaped lesion.
  • In chronic SDH, the lesion is hypodense and often crosses the suture lines.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Hyperdense, biconvex lesion: This is characteristic of epidural hematoma that most commonly follows a coup injury. The lesion does not cross the suture lines. Patients present with similar symptoms but also display lucid interval. It results from the rupture of the middle meningeal artery.

Option C - Hyperdense subarachnoid space: Hyperdense collection of blood in the subarachnoid space is a finding seen in subarachnoid hemorrhage. Patients present with acute onset severe thunderclap headache. It most often results from trauma. Rupture of berry aneurysm is a non-traumatic cause.

Option D - Hyperdense lesion with surrounding hypodense edema: These findings are seen in intracerebral hemorrhage. It is frequently seen in patients with hypertension and is a result of a rupture of the middle cerebral artery.

questions.text: Which of the following special stains is used for connective tissue staining?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Massons Trichrome:

  • Massons trichrome is a special connective tissue stain.
  • The trichrome stain helps to highlight the supporting collagenous stroma in sections from a variety of organs.
  • This helps to determine the pattern of tissue injury.
  • Trichrome will also aid in identifying normal structures, such as connective tissue capsules of organs, the lamina propria of the gastrointestinal tract, and the bronchovascular structures in the lung.
  • Other connective tissue stains:
    • Verhoff’s elastic stain
    • Reticulin stain
    • Giemsa stain

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Periodic Acid-Schiff:

  • PAS is a stain for microorganisms. It stains glycogen, mucin, mucoprotein, glycoprotein, as well as fungi. A predigestion step with amylase will remove staining for glycogen.
  • PAS is useful for outlining tissue structures–basement membranes, capsules, blood vessels, etc.

Option C - Oil Red O:

  • It is a special fat stain. It Identifies neutral lipids and fatty acids in smears and tissues.
  • Fresh smears or cryostat sections of tissue are necessary because fixatives containing alcohol or routine tissue processing with clearing will remove lipids.
  • ORO is a rapid and simple stain. It can be useful in identifying fat emboli in lung tissue or clot sections of peripheral blood.

Option D - Fontana-Masson:

  • It is a special stain used for melanin.
  • The method relies upon the melanin granules to reduce ammoniacal silver nitrate (but argentaffin, chromaffin, and some lipochrome pigments also will stain black as well).

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to your clinic with complaints of progressive dyspnea, cough, and chest pain. He has been working in a factory for the past 20 years. Physical examination reveals crackles on auscultation and digital clubbing. The chest X-ray is shown below. After confirming the diagnosis, the patient is advised that his condition does not require notification to the authorities. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Bagassosis:

  • The most probable diagnosis is Bagassosis, which is caused by inhalation of fibrous cane-sugar residue and occurs in workers in sugarcane factories. This disease is not a notifiable disease under the Factory Act.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C and D are all notifiable diseases under the Factory Act.

Option A - Silicosis:

  • Silicosis is caused by inhaling silica dust, commonly found in materials like sand, rock, and quartz. It is associated with occupations such as mining and sandblasting.

Option C - Byssinosis:

  • Byssinosis, or cotton worker's lung, is caused by inhaling dust from hemp, flax, and cotton processing. It primarily affects workers in textile mills.

Option D - Asbestosis:

  • Asbestosis is caused by prolonged exposure to asbestos fibers and is associated with industries like shipbuilding and roofing.

questions.text: A 47-year-old patient presents with an altered taste sensation on the anterior tongue following middle ear surgery. On examination, chorda tympani nerve dysfunction is noted. Which of the following is the embryonic origin of the nerves of the pharyngeal clefts?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Neural crest cells:

  • The chorda tympani nerve is a pretrematic nerve and carries the taste sensations from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. It is one of the nerves of the pharyngeal clefts.
  • The neuron bodies of the pretrematic nerves are located in the ganglia.
  • Specifically, the neuron body of the chorda tympani nerve is located in the geniculate ganglion.
  • The ganglia originate from the neural crest cells. This is the reason why nerves of the pharyngeal cleft have their origin in the neural crest cells.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Mesoderm: Mesoderm gives rise to structures such as muscles, bones, blood vessels, and connective tissues. Nerves of the pharyngeal clefts do not originate from mesoderm.

Option B - Endoderm: The endoderm primarily gives rise to the epithelial lining of the respiratory and digestive tracts, as well as associated glands such as the thyroid, parathyroid, liver, and pancreas.

Option D - Neuroectoderm: It forms the central nervous system, such as the brain and spinal cord.

questions.text: A 9-month-old infant is brought to the emergency department by his parents due to episodes of severe abdominal pain and inconsolable crying. The parents report that the child has been having episodes of drawing up his legs to his chest and passing currant jelly stool. On physical examination, a sausage-shaped mass is palpable in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen. The infant appears distressed, and his vital signs are stable. Abdominal ultrasound reveals a characteristic radiological sign given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Intussusception

  • Intussusception is a condition in which a segment of the intestine invaginates into the adjacent segment, leading to bowel obstruction. It commonly affects infants and presents with episodes of severe abdominal pain, drawing up of legs, and "currant jelly" stool (blood and mucus in the stool). On physical examination, a palpable sausage-shaped mass may be present. The radiological findings of the "donut sign" on abdominal ultrasound is characteristic of intussusception (it is also seen in IHPS). Barium enema shows a “claw sign.”USG shows target sign, sign of bowel within bowel

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Gastroenteritis: Gastroenteritis refers to inflammation of the stomach and intestines, commonly caused by viral or bacterial infections. It presents with symptoms such as vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal pain. It can cause abdominal discomfort.Target sign is not seen in gastroenteritis

Option B - Hirschsprung's disease: Hirschsprung's disease is a congenital condition characterized by the absence of ganglion cells in the distal part of the large intestine, leading to functional obstruction. It typically presents in the neonatal period with failure to pass meconium and abdominal distension. Zone of transition is seen in barium enema

The annotated image demonstrates the transition zone with a small caliber rectum and dilated sigmoid colon (rectosigmoid ratio less than 1.0). - second image

Option D - Meckel's diverticulum: Meckel's diverticulum is a congenital outpouching of the small intestine located near the ileocecal valve. It is typically asymptomatic but can present with complications such as bleeding, intestinal obstruction, or inflammation. Meckel's diverticulum is seen on the antimesenteric side of the small intestine. It is considered a true diverticulum, as it contains all layers of the intestinal wall.

questions.text: Which muscle remains unaffected in a patient with unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Cricothyroid muscle:

  • Unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy results in paralysis of all intrinsic muscles of the larynx on the affected side except for the cricothyroid muscle, which is innervated by the superior laryngeal nerve.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Posterior cricoarytenoid muscle: Is affected by unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy.

Option B - Thyroarytenoid muscle: Is affected by unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy.

Option D - Lateral cricoarytenoid muscle: Is affected by unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male has been admitted for the resection of a breast mass under general anaesthesia. The surgery has been successful, but the patient complains of severe abdominal pain and vomiting postoperatively. The investigations significantly elevated SGOT, SGPT, alkaline phosphatase, and serum bilirubin levels. Ultrasonogram shows massive hepatic necrosis. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Halothane

Explanation:

 

  • This patient developed massive hepatic necrosis after general anesthesia, with:
     
    • Severe abdominal pain and vomiting
       
    • Markedly elevated liver enzymes (SGOT, SGPT, ALP, bilirubin)
       
    • Ultrasound showing hepatic necrosis
       
  • These findings are classic for halothane-induced hepatitis, a rare but potentially fatal idiosyncratic reaction.
     

Comparison of Inhalational Anaesthetic Agents

Agent

Hepatotoxicity

Nephrotoxicity

Metabolism (%)

Key Points

Halothane

Yes – Can cause halothane hepatitis (idiosyncratic)

No significant renal toxicity

~20%

Causes immune-mediated hepatic necrosis, especially with repeated exposure

Enflurane

Mild hepatotoxicity (rare)

Yes – due to fluoride ions

~2-5%

Risk of seizures, fluoride nephrotoxicity

Isoflurane

Very rare hepatotoxicity

Minimal

~0.2%

Stable, widely used, safest among older agents for liver/kidney

Desflurane

Negligible hepatotoxicity

Negligible

~0.02%

Least metabolism, rapid induction and recovery

Sevoflurane

Minimal hepatotoxicity

Yes – can cause nephrotoxicity (via Compound A)

~3-5%

Pleasant odor, preferred in pediatrics, nephrotoxicity in prolonged use

Methoxyflurane

No significant hepatotoxicity

Yes – severe nephrotoxicity (fluoride ions)

~50-70%

Highest metabolism, obsolete due to nephrotoxicity

Nitrous Oxide

No

No

Not metabolized

Diffusion hypoxia, megaloblastic anemia with prolonged use

Desflurane (Option B):
Incorrect- has very low metabolism and is not hepatotoxic.
 

Methoxyflurane (Option C):
Incorrect- known for nephrotoxicity, not hepatotoxicity.
 

Enflurane (Option D):
Incorrect - may have mild nephrotoxicity but not associated with massive hepatic necrosis.

questions.text: Which of the following hernias could have the caecum/ sigmoid colon as a part of the wall of the hernia sac?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Sliding hernia:

  • The question describes the cecum as constituting a part of the wall of the sac rather than as content, and the cecum is the most common content in right-side sliding hernia.
  • Sliding hernia, is due to weakening in the abdominal wall. It occurs at the deep inguinal ring lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels.
  • On the left side, the sigmoid colon may be pulled into a sliding hernia, and on the right side, the cecum.

 

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Richter’s hernia:

  • In a Richter hernia, a small portion or circumference of the antimesenteric wall of the intestine is trapped within the hernia.

Option B - Spigelian hernia:

  • A Spigelian hernia occurs in the linea semilunaris, which extends along the lateral border of each rectus abdominis muscle.

Option D - Epigastric hernia:

  • Any hernia from the xiphoid process till 2cm of umbilicus

questions.text:
A 40-year-old gardener presents to the dermatology clinic with painless, nodular skin lesions on his leg. He recalls being pricked by a thorn while working in the garden a few weeks ago. Examination findings are shown below:



There is no evidence of surrounding redness or inflammation. Based on the clinical scenario, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A- Sporotrichosis:

  • The clinical scenario describes a gardener with painless, nodular skin lesions on the leg following a thorn prick. The presence of a firm, raised nodule with an ulcerated center suggests a diagnosis of sporotrichosis.
  • Sporotrichosis is a fungal infection caused by the dimorphic fungus Sporothrix schenckii. It commonly occurs after traumatic inoculation of the organism into the skin, often through thorn pricks or plant material. The initial skin lesion typically appears as a painless, firm nodule that may ulcerate over time. The lesion is usually localized but may be accompanied by a chain of smaller nodules along the lymphatic vessels (lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis).
  • If a biopsy is done on these patients, they show asteroid bodies.
  • In the PAS stain, a cigar-shaped body is seen:

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Cutaneous tuberculosis: It presents as a painless, non-ulcerated, indurated skin lesion with an undermined border.

It is not typically associated with thorn pricks or plant material exposure.

Option C - Ecthyma gangrenosum: It is a cutaneous manifestation of Pseudomonas aeruginosa infection, commonly seen in immunocompromised individuals.

It presents as a rapidly progressing, painful, necrotic ulcer with surrounding erythema and systemic symptoms.

Option D - Pyoderma gangrenosum: It is a rare neutrophilic dermatosis characterized by rapidly progressing, painful, necrotic ulcers.

It is not typically associated with a history of thorn prick or plant material exposure.

questions.text: Which of the following anti diabetic drug is to be used in patients with history of previous Myocardial infarction?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Tirzepatide:

  • Anti-diabetic drug reducing CV mortality is GLP1RA and SGLT2i

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B, C are incorrect.

questions.text: An obstetrician is performing a spontaneous vaginal delivery and opts for regional general anesthesia to alleviate the patient's pain. She introduces a spinal needle transvaginally to administer a nerve block while explaining the procedure to her junior doctors. Which statement accurately describes this nerve?

choices.text: Leave the pelvis through the lesser sciatic foramen
It provides motor fibres to the coccygeus
It can be blocked by injecting an anesthetic near the inferior margin of the ischial spine

questions.solution:
Correct Option D: It can be blocked by injecting an anesthetic near the inferior margin of the ischial spine

  • The examiner is talking about pudendal nerve block here, as it passes in close approximation to the ischial spine.
  • The pudendal nerve is both a sensory and motor nerve. It arises from the sacral plexus and forms from the ventral spinal roots S2-S4.
  • The areas affected by the sensory distribution of the pudendal nerve include the perineum, the lower buttocks, the anus, and the genitalia.
  • Hence, a pudendal nerve block is performed for the regional anesthesia in this patient to minimize pain during labor.
  • It is done during the second stage of labor to minimize pain via a transvaginal approach. The ischial spine is palpated with the index finger, and the spinal needle with the local anaesthetic is introduced. It is injected inferior to the ischial spine.

 

Incorrect Opitons:

Option A: Root values S3, S4, S5

  • The pudendal nerve is a mixed nerve mainly in charge of the sensory and motor supply of the perineum and external genitalia in both sexes.
  • The nerve arises in the pelvic cavity from the sacral plexus, specifically from the anterior rami of spinal nerves S2, S3, and S4.

Option B: Leave the pelvis through the lesser sciatic foramen

  • It leaves the pelvic activity through the greater sciatic foramen, encircles the ischial spine, and then enters the perineum through the lesser sciatic foramen.

Option C: It provides motor fibers to the coccygeus

  • The pudendal nerve gives off three branches:
    • The inferior rectal nerve provides motor supply to the external anal sphincter.
    • The perineal nerve supplies the muscles of the urogenital triangles (bulbospongiosus, ischiocavernosus, and superficial transverse perineal muscles), the external urethral sphincter, and the levator ani.
    • Dorsal nerve of the penis/clitoris. It supplies the skin of the body of the penis or clitoris and of the glans.
  • The coccygeus is primarily innervated by the anterior ramus of spinal nerve S4 and receives minor contributions from spinal nerve S5.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is considered an absolute indication of tonsillectomy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Obstructive sleep apnea:

  • Obstructive sleep apnea is an absolute indication of tonsillectomy. Enlarged tonsils and adenoids can block the airway. Furthermore, when asleep, the tongue falls back as the muscles lose their tone during sleep.

Indications for Tonsillectomy:

Absolute indications

Relative indications
  • Obstructive sleep apnea
    • Enlarged tonsils and enlarged adenoids usually coexist in children which leads to airway obstruction. When the child goes to sleep, the tongue falls back (loss of tone during sleep) leading to further airway obstruction & cessation of breathing for 10 seconds or more (apnea)
    • This condition predisposes the child to chronic hypoxia, leading to pulmonary artery hypertension which in turn leads to right ventricular hypertrophy.
  • Malignancy of the tonsil
  • Recurrent tonsillitis
  • 2nd attack of quinsy / peritonsillar abscess
  • Chronic tonsillitis
  • Tonsillitis causing febrile seizures, cardiac disease, IgA nephropathy
  • Non – tonsillar indications (The tonsil is removed as a part of another surgery): Excision of the styloid process and UPPP (uvulopalatopharyngoplasty).

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and C are relative indications for tonsillectomy.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man has been arrested by the police after 3 women filed charges against him for harassing them by indulging in Frotteurism at the park. The police have made the arrest after questioning multiple witnesses from the park that evening. Which act is the man being charged for?

choices.text: Sexual pleasure is obtained by witnessing the act of urination
Sexual gratification by touching or rubbing one’s genitals against another non-consenting individual
Sexual gratification by wearing clothes of opposite sex
Sexual gratification by acts of physical cruelty

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Sexual gratification by touching or rubbing one’s genitals against another non-consenting individual

  •  It is the act of obtaining sexual arousal and gratification by rubbing of one’s genitals against a non-consenting person in public places : Frotteurism 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Sexual pleasure is obtained by witnessing the act of urination:

  • This describes urolagnia. Urolagnia involves sexual arousal or gratification from urine or urination-related activities, such as watching someone urinate or being urinated on.

Option C - Sexual gratification by wearing clothes of the opposite sex:

  • This refers to transvestism or cross-dressing. Transvestism involves deriving sexual gratification from wearing clothing typically associated with the opposite sex.

Option D - Sexual gratification by acts of physical cruelty:

  • This describes sadism. Sadism involves deriving sexual pleasure from inflicting pain, humiliation, or suffering on others. ​​​​​​​

questions.text: A 54-year-old man presents with vague abdominal discomfort and early satiety for 5 months. On examination, there is a palpable mass in the upper abdomen. CECT shows a solid, contrast-enhancing mass with smooth margins arising from the stomach wall. Biopsy confirms the diagnosis, and the tumor is determined to arise from the interstitial cells of Cajal. What is the best treatment for unresectable form?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Imatinib:

  • The most likely diagnosis in this patient is a gastrointestinal stromal tumor. It is a highly vascular tumor arising from the GI pacemaker cells (interstitial cells of Cajal).
  • For patients presenting with an abdominal mass, contrast-enhanced CT using oral and IV contrast is the preferred modality for assessment.
    • GISTs will be viewed as a solid, contrast-enhancing mass with smooth margins.
  • Endoscopy is the preferred method of evaluation for patients presenting with gastrointestinal bleeding.
    • On the endoscopic exam, GISTs most commonly appear similar to other sub-epithelial lesions with a smooth bulge covered with normal-appearing mucosa.
  • For unresectable tumors, imatinib (tyrosine kinase inhibitor) is the drug of choice.
  • For resectable tumors, segmental resection or wedge-shaped excision with a 2 cm margin is carried out.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Regorafenib: Regorafenib is the third-line agent for the treatment of GISTs. Sunitinib is the second-line agent and is also used for imatinib-resistant GISTs.

Option C - Vincristine: Vincristine is mostly used for ALL, Burkitt lymphoma, lymphoid blast crisis of CML, Hodgkin, and non-Hodgkin lymphomas. It has no role in treating GISTs.

Option D - Gemcitabine: It is used for pancreatic malignancy and not GISTs.

questions.text: Which type of cells in the epidermis are responsible for providing protection against harmful UV radiation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A- Melanocytes:

  • Melanocytes are specialized cells located in the basal layer of the epidermis.
  • Melanocytes produce melanin, which is transferred to nearby keratinocytes, providing a shield against UV radiation by absorbing and dissipating its energy. This protective mechanism helps to prevent DNA damage and reduces the risk of skin cancer.

Incorrect Options:

Option B—Langerhans cells: Langerhans cells are specialized immune cells present in the epidermis.

They recognize and present antigens to the immune system. While they are important in immune surveillance, they are not directly responsible for protecting against UV radiation. They are found in the Stratum spinosum of the epidermis.

Option C - Merkel cells: Merkel cells are found in the basal layer of the epidermis and are associated with sensory nerve endings. They play a role in touch sensation and sensory perception but are not directly involved in protecting against UV radiation. found in Stratum basale of epidermis.

Option D - Basal cells: Basal cells, also known as basal keratinocytes, are the deepest layer of cells in the epidermis. They are responsible for the continuous production of new skin cells and are involved in skin regeneration. While basal cells contribute to the overall integrity and function of the epidermis, they are not primarily responsible for protecting against UV radiation.

questions.text: The body of a 28-year-old man has been discovered in the hostel premises with his throat cut. On immediate observation, there were no signs of a struggle inside the room. A half-empty bottle of whisky and a couple of burnt cigarette butts were seen lying next to the body. Information gathered from friends revealed that the man had been on medication for depression and had also gotten into arguments with some of the other students in recent times. All of the following may be seen on the autopsy of this case except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer:  D) Defence wounds

 

Explanation:

 

  • This is most likely a case of the suicidal cutthroat, and it is unlikely to see defense wounds in this case.
  • Defence wounds like cuts, lacerations, bruises, etc. on or in-between the fingers and palms, back of hands, wrists, and inner aspects of forearms if present, are strongly suggestive of homicide as these are produced during attempts by the victim to grasp the weapon in instinctively defending himself or toward off the attack on the head or some other vital part of the body.

Ragged edges (Option A): Edges are likely to be toothed or may show some irregularity of the margins at places because the skin is thrown into folds before severance (ragged edges).

Hesitation cuts (Option B): Multiple superficial tentative or hesitational cuts may be present around the commencement of the main wound (shows the divided state of mind of a person as it is usual human nature to preserve life).

Tailing (Option C): Depth and direction: Usually deeper at the commencement, except in case of suicidal cut-throat injuries, with hesitation cuts at the beginning. This is known as the head of the wound. Towards termination, the cut becomes progressively shallow, known as the tailing of the wound. Consequently, the depth of the incised wound with tailing will suggest the direction in which the force was applied.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about acute pancreatitis are accurate?


	Macrolides, fluoroquinolones, tricyclic antidepressants are associated with the condition
	Presents with pain in the epigastrium that worsens with sitting or forward bending
	Cullen, Grey Turner, and Fox’s signs may be present
	CECT is routinely indicated in all patients as it is the investigation of choice
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Statement 3 only:

  • In some cases of acute pancreatitis, there is a retroperitoneal bleed into the surrounding fascial planes. This bleeding gives rise to the following clinical signs.
    • Cullen sign: ecchymosis around the umbilicus
    • Grey Turner sign: ecchymosis around the flank
    • Fox’s sign: ecchymosis around the inguinal region

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and C:

Statement 1

  • This statement is incorrect because macrolides, fluoroquinolones, and tricyclic antidepressants are not associated with AP. They are implicated in long QT syndrome.
  • Drugs often associated with AP are azathioprine, 6-mercaptopurine, 5-aminosalicylic acid, thiazides, loop diuretics, valproate, sulfonamides, tetracyclines, and anti-HIV medications.

Statement 2

  • Patients with AP present with severe abdominal pain in the epigastrium, radiating to the left side of the back.
  • This pain is partially relieved by sitting or bending forward.

Statement 4

  • Although CECT is the IOC, it is not routinely indicated for all patients with AP.
  • It is reserved for those with clinical and/or biological worsening despite supportive therapy.
  • Diagnosis of AP only requires 2 of the 3 following criteria:
    • A lipase or amylase level is three times the normal's upper limit
    • Abdominal pain is consistent with pancreatitis
    • Abdominal imaging is consistent with AP

questions.text: 30-year-old patient presents with high grade fever for past one week. On examination neck stiffness and kerning’s sign was positive. CSF analysis showed lymphocytosis protein – 80 mg/dl, glucose -20 mg/dl while RBS = 140 mg/dl. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Tubercular meningitis:

  • CSF sugar/ Blood sugar is 40/140 = 0.28 with elevated CSF protein.
  • This along with CSF lymphocytosis favors diagnosis as TBM.
  • Option B and D are ruled as CSF sugar is normal in viral meningitis/encephalitis.
  • Bacterial meningitis has presence of PMN Cells.

questions.text: 70-year-old diabetic man presents after a fall. He is having high fever, cough and breathing difficulty and appears confused. CXR shows lobar consolidation. Labs shows elevated BUN and creatinine. Which is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: Send home of amoxicillin with clavulanic acid
In- patient management with amoxicillin with azithromycin

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - ICU management with levofloxacin:

  • Parameters to be considered for CURB -65 score in this case are: Age, elevated BUN, presence of confusion.
  • The total score is 3 which means patient needs hospitalization.
  • Since comorbidity is present in this patient (diabetes mellitus) he needs to be started on either of following:
  1. Respiratory Fluoroquinolones
  2. Amoxicillin + Clavulanic acid and Azithromycin
  3. Cephalosporin + Azithromycin
  4. Doxycycline

Treatment Strategies for Outpatients with Community-Acquired Pneumonia

No comorbidities or risk factors for antibiotic resistance

Combination therapy with amoxicillin + either a macrolide or doxycycline

Or

Monotherapy with doxycycline

Or

Monotherapy with a macrolide

With comorbidities ± risk factors for antibiotic resistance

Combination therapy with

Amoxicillin/clavulanate or a cephalosporin + either a macrolide or doxycycline

Or

Monotherapy with a respiratory fluoroquinolone

questions.text: Mark, a 35-year-old man, has been referred to a psychiatrist by his family due to his increasingly unusual behavior and beliefs. His family reports that Mark has become convinced that his co-workers, neighbors, and even random strangers he encounters on the street are all the same person in disguise. He believes that this individual is stalking him and trying to harm him. Mark's family is concerned about his safety and well-being and wants to understand his condition better.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A:  Fregoli syndrome

  • Mark's belief that multiple different individuals are actually the same person in disguise and stalking him aligns with Fregoli syndrome. In Fregoli syndrome, a person holds the delusional belief that different people are actually a single person who changes appearance to deceive and persecute them.

Incorrect Options:

Option B- Capgras syndrome

  • Capgras syndrome is characterized by the delusional belief that a person, usually someone close to the individual, has been replaced by an imposter. Mark's beliefs are more consistent with Fregoli syndrome, where he believes multiple individuals are the same person in disguise.

Option C- Paranoid personality disorder

  • Paranoid personality disorder involves a pervasive pattern of distrust and suspicion toward others, but it does not involve the specific delusion of multiple individuals being the same person in disguise. Mark's symptoms suggest a delusional disorder rather than a personality disorder.

Option D- Dissociative identity disorder

  • Dissociative identity disorder, formerly known as multiple personality disorder, involves the presence of two or more distinct personality states. Mark's symptoms do not align with the characteristic features of dissociative identity disorder. His belief of individuals being the same person in disguise is more indicative of a delusional disorder.

questions.text: Which one of the following is the most dreadful complication caused by Neisseria meningitidis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Waterhouse Friderichsen syndrome:

  • Meningococci spreads by droplet infections in which the lungs are involved.
  • It also has a hematogenous spread leading to meningococcal septicemia. It is a the gram-negative encapsulated bacteria
  • The Most common severe complication of Meningococcal infection is Waterhouse Friderichsen syndrome, causing bilateral adrenal hemorrhagic necrosis. In this syndrome, adrenal glands fail to function normally.

Incorrect Option:

Option A - Water-can perineum:

  • It is a condition that results in the multiple fistulae extending from the urethra to open inside the perineum.
  • They are primarily seen in gonorrheal infections.

Option B - Fitz Hugh Curtis syndrome:

  • It is a syndrome in which inflammation of the liver capsule and peritoneal surface occurs associated with adhesion formation, resulting in pain in the right upper quadrant.
  • It is seen in Pelvic Inflammatory Disease.

Option C – Polyarthritis:

  • It is used when at least five or more joints are involved with pain and discomfort. Swelling, warmth, and redness are typical physical presentations.
  • This condition is mainly caused by an auto-immune disease such as rheumatoid arthritis or systemic lupus erythematous. But it can also be caused due to alphavirus.

questions.text: A researcher plots a graph to calculate the bioavailability of a particular drug. Which of the following routes of drug administration does the graph shown in the image correspond to?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Intravenous:

  • The graph shown in the image is a concentration-time graph used to calculate the bioavailability of a drug.

  • The Area Under the Curve is divided into different segments. Each segment has a particular shape.
  • If a drug is given in intravenous route, the concentration-time graph has a downward straight line, which means that the concentration decreases with time.
  • AUC is higher (all of the drug administered reaches the blood).

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Oral::

  • If a drug is taken orally, the concentration in the blood increases slowly with time and then decreases.
  • In this graph, the AUC shows the total amount of drug that entered into circulation with time.
  • The segments of AUC are in the shape of a trapezium.

Options C and D: These routes of administration do not have the concentration-time graph shown in the image.

questions.text: A 39-year-old man with a long history of smoking is evaluated for intermittent claudication and pain in his hands, feet, and digits at rest. He mentions that the pain is worse in the right calf. ABI is 0.7. A radiological investigation is performed and is shown below. What does the management comprise?

choices.text: Nicotine replacement therapy and surgical revascularization
NSAIDs for pain control and amputation of the affected distal limb

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Smoking cessation and amlodipine:

  • Buerger disease is a nonatherosclerotic, progressive, segmental inflammatory disease affecting the small and medium-sized arteries of the upper and lower limbs.
  • ABI 0.5 to 0.9 corresponds to intermittent claudication.
  • IOC for diagnosis is four-limb angiography, as shown in the image. There are characteristic collaterals known as corkscrew collaterals. However, corkscrew arteries are not specific for this disease.
  • Treatment:
    • Smoking cessation is the mainstay.
    • Symptomatic management with CCBs (amlodipine) or other vasodilators can be implemented, especially if there is a concurrent Raynaud phenomenon.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Nicotine replacement therapy and surgical revascularization:

  • The use of nicotine replacement therapy can keep the disease active.
  • Surgical revascularization is not advisable because Buerger disease involves the diffuse segmental arteries and has a propensity to affect small and medium-sized arteries.

Option B - NSAIDs for pain control and amputation of the affected distal limb:

  • NSAIDs and narcotic analgesia can be prescribed to palliate pain secondary to ischemia. They do not slow the progression.
  • Distal limb amputation is reserved for patients who do not quit smoking and have non-resolving ulcers, gangrene, or persistent pain.

Option C - Smoking cessation, aspirin, and atorvastatin:

  • These measures are advised for patients with peripheral artery disease.
  • Although PAD manifests with claudication, it is seen in elderly patients with other disorders such as hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and dyslipidemias.

questions.text: Which antihypertensive is suitable for a 55-year-old female with type 2 diabetes, currently on insulin lispro and insulin glargine injection, presenting with headache, nausea, BMI of 32.1kg/m2, blood pressure of 140/100mmHg, pulse rate of 110 bpm, respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, and ECG findings of supraventricular tachycardia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Verapamil:

  • Based on the clinical features and examination findings, the patient likely suffers from supraventricular tachycardia and Stage-1 hypertension.
  • Verapamil is a L-type Ca++ channel blocker.
  • Treats supraventricular tachycardia and Stage-1 hypertension.
  • Decreases heart rate by antagonizing Ca++ channels at SA node.
  • Reduces afterload, aiding heart function.
  • Lowers blood pressure by relaxing vascular smooth muscle.

Incorrect Options:

 

Option A - Nifedipine:

  • Used for hypertension in pregnancy and uterine relaxation in pre-term delivery.
  • Not typically used for supraventricular tachycardia.

Option B - Amlodipine:

  • Reduces blood pressure by decreasing peripheral vascular resistance.
  • Does not affect heart rate.

Option C - Ethosuximide:

  • T-type Ca++ channel blocker used for seizures.
  • No role in controlling heart rate.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with a blow to the lateral aspect of his left knee during football. He now complains of pain and weakness in the ankle region. Physical examination reveals mild soft-tissue swelling of the left knee with weakness of foot dorsiflexion and eversion. Sensory loss is noted on the lateral aspect of the left leg and 1st web space of the left foot. Which muscle damage is responsible for the inability to evert the foot in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Peroneus longus

  • The muscles that lead to the eversion of the foot include the peroneus longus, brevis, and tertius.
  • The peroneus longus muscle arises from the fibula's head and upper lateral side and inserts on the base of the first metatarsal, medial cuneiform.
  • It is supplied by the superficial peroneal nerve, a branch of the common peroneal nerve.
  • This patient had a sensory loss on the lateral aspect of the leg and 1st web space of the left foot with weakness of foot dorsiflexion and eversion showing damage to the common peroneal nerve due to fibular neck fracture.

Muscles of the ankle joint

 

 

Movement

Prime mover

Nerve supply

Dorsiflexion

Tibialis anterior

Deep peroneal nerve (L4-L5)

 

Extensor digitorum longus

Deep peroneal nerve (L4-L5)

 

Peroneus tertius

Deep peroneal nerve (L4-L5)

 

Extensor hallucis longus

Deep peroneal nerve (L4-L5)

Plantarflexion

Soleus

Tibial nerve (S1-S2)

 

Gastrocnemius

Tibial nerve (S1-S2)

 

Tibialis posterior

Tibial nerve (L4-L5)

 

Peroneus longus

Superficial peroneal nerve (L5-S1)

 

Peroneus brevis

Superficial peroneal nerve (L5-S1)

 

Flexor digitorum longus

Flexor hallucis longus

Tibial nerve (L5-S1)

Tibial nerve (S2-S3)

Inversion

Tibialis posterior

 

 

Tibialis anterior

 

 

Gastrocnemius

 

 

Soleus

 

Eversion

Peroneus longus

 

 

Peroneus brevis

 

 

Peroneus tertius

 

 

Incorrect options

Option A: Extensor digitorum brevis

  • Extensor digitorum brevis originates from the superolateral surface of the calcaneus bone and inserts into the middle phalanges of the second to fourth toes.
  • The deep fibular nerve innervates it.
  • It is responsible for the extension of the 2nd to 4th toe.
  • It has no role in the dorsiflexion and eversion of the foot.

Option C: Soleus

  • Soleus originates from the lateral surface of the tibia and interosseous muscle.
  • It is inserted into posterior surface of calcaneus (via calcaneal tendon)
  • It is responsible for foot plantar flexion.

Option D: Tibialis posterior

  • Tibialis posterior originates from soleal line, medial border of tibia, head of fibula, posterior border of fibula
  • It is inserted into the tuberosity of the navicular bone, all cuneiform bones, cuboid bone, and bases of metatarsals.
  • It is responsible for foot plantarflexion and inversion.

questions.text: A high school study was conducted to compare the effectiveness of two different health education methods in improving students' knowledge about vector-borne diseases. A sample of 100 students was divided into two groups: Group A received pamphlets containing information about the prevention and management of vector-borne diseases, while Group B attended interactive sessions conducted by healthcare professionals. After the intervention, the knowledge levels of both groups were assessed using a questionnaire. Which of the following tests will not be used to analyze the data?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Fischer’s test:

  • In this scenario, Fisher's test would not be appropriate because the data involves comparing means or examining relationships between continuous variables rather than comparing frequencies or associations between categorical variables.
  • Fisher's test, also known as Fisher's exact test, is a non-parametric statistical test used to determine if there are nonrandom associations between two categorical (qualitative) variables.
  • It is typically used when sample sizes are small or when the assumptions of other tests, like the chi-square test, are not met.
  • Fisher's test is non-parametric because it does not rely on assumptions about the distribution of the data.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Student's T-Test:

  • Student's T-Test is a parametric statistical test used to determine if there is a significant difference between the means of two groups.
  • In this scenario, it could be employed to compare the effectiveness of the two different methods of health education (pamphlets vs. interactive sessions) on knowledge levels about vector-borne diseases among students.
  • Since the data involves comparing means, this test is parametric.

Option B - ANOVA:

  • ANOVA, or Analysis of Variance, is a parametric statistical test used to compare the means of three or more groups to determine if there are statistically significant differences between them.
  • In this scenario, ANOVA could be used if there were more than two groups (e.g., comparing the effectiveness of pamphlets, interactive sessions, and video presentations on knowledge levels about vector-borne diseases).
  • Like the Student's T-Test, ANOVA is a parametric test because it assumes that the data are normally distributed and the groups have equal variances.

Option C - Pearson's Correlation Coefficient:

  • Pearson's correlation coefficient, often denoted as "r," is a parametric measure of the strength and direction of the linear relationship between two continuous variables.
  • It ranges from -1 to 1, where 1 indicates a perfect positive linear relationship, -1 indicates a perfect negative linear relationship, and 0 indicates no linear relationship.
  • In this scenario, Pearson's correlation coefficient could be used to examine the relationship between variables such as knowledge levels about vector-borne diseases and factors like age or education level.
  • Pearson's correlation coefficient is parametric because it assumes that the variables are normally distributed and have a linear relationship.

questions.text: Lady presents with worst headache of her life and nuchal rigidity. GCS is 12/15 and NCCT head is planned. Which of the following findings will match her clinical condition?

choices.text: Punctuate hyper-densities at gray matter white matter interface

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Hyper density in basal cisterns:

  • Diagnosis is SAH.
  • The blood can gravitate to basal cisterns producing star sign

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B, C are incorrect.

questions.text: All of the following structures are derivatives of the embryological ventral mesogastrium, except?
questions.solution:
Option D: Gastrosplenic ligament

  • Ventral mesogastrium is the primitive midline mesentery extending between the stomach and proximal duodenum and the anterior abdominal wall superior to the umbilicus.
  • Gastrosplenic ligament develops in the dorsal mesogastrium.

Incorrect options

Option A: Falciform ligament

  • It attaches the liver to the anterior abdominal wall
  • It is derived from the ventral mesogastrium

Option B: Coronary ligament

  • It attaches the liver to the diaphragm and is a derivative of ventral mesogastrium

Option C: Lesser omentum

  • It is attached to the lesser curvature of the stomach and liver
  • It is also a derivative of ventral mesogastrium

questions.text: Blood pressure changes in the radial artery were measured while performing a valsalva maneuver. Which of the following is the reason for the initial rise in blood pressure?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Increase in aortic pressure:

  • The Valsalva maneuver is a technique used to assess autonomic nervous system function and cardiovascular response.

  • Valsalva maneuver has four phases:
    • Phase I (onset of strain): In this phase, there is a transient increase in blood pressure that lasts for a few seconds. This occurs due to increased intrathoracic pressure adding to the aortic pressure.
    • Phase II (phase of straining): In this phase, venous return initially decreases, lowering cardiac output and blood pressure for 4 seconds. Later, blood pressure returns to normal due to increased peripheral resistance from sympathetic vasoconstriction. Heart rate steadily increases due to vagal withdrawal and sympathetic activation.
    • Phase III: This phase occurs following the release of strain characterized by a transient decrease in blood pressure lasting for a few seconds. This is caused by the mechanical displacement of blood to the pulmonary vascular bed, which was under increased intrathoracic pressure. There is little change in heart rate.
    • Phase IV: Occurs after further release of strain; blood pressure slowly increases, and heart rate decreases for about a minute. This is due to an increase in venous return, stroke volume, and cardiac output.

Incorrect Options: 

Options A, B, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option C for an explanation.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old patient presents with a history of foul-smelling, purulent nasal discharge, and nasal obstruction for several months. On examination, the following finding is seen  : 



A biopsy showed Mikulicz cells and Russell bodies. The patient is started on streptomycin and tetracycline. When is it appropriate to discontinue this treatment?

choices.text: When two subsequent cultures are negative

questions.solution:
Correct Option C- When two subsequent cultures are negative:

  • The treatment for rhinoscleroma with streptomycin and tetracycline is typically continued until two subsequent cultures are negative. If the cultures remain positive, indicating the persistence of the bacterial infection, the treatment should be continued.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- After one week of treatment: The minimum treatment duration is approximately 4-6 weeks and is continued till two subsequent cultures are negative.

Option B- When symptoms improve: The minimum treatment duration is approximately 4-6 weeks and is continued till two subsequent cultures are negative.

Option D - After 15 days of treatment: The minimum treatment duration is approximately 4-6 weeks and is continued till two subsequent cultures are negative.

questions.text:
Identify the correct adverse effects of antiparkinsonian drugs from the list of drugs provided below?

a. Levodopa can result in the On-Off phenomenon in late Parkinsonism

b. Bromocriptine can result in peripheral gangrene of limbs

c. Pramipexole is associated with impulse control disorders

d. Amantadine can cause dyskinesia

choices.text: a, b, and c are correct
all four (a, b, c, & d) are correct

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - a, b, c are correct:

  • Although Levodopa is the most effective symptomatic treatment at all stages of Parkinsonian. Levodopa's main drawback is that it usually results in treatment-induced fluctuations in motor control ('on–off' phenomena)
  • It also causes dyskinesia (i.e., excessive purposeless movements appearing as restlessness or rocking) when taken for about 5–10 years
  • Bromocriptine may rarely cause peripheral vasoconstriction of the arteries may result in hypothermia or tissue necrosis, which may lead to gangrene
  • In treating Parkinson's disease with dopaminergic agonists, such as pramipexole, it has been observed that a significant number of patients develop impulse-control disorders

Incorrect Options

Option B, C, and D: refer to explanation of option A

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the Haldane effect?

choices.text: Effect of O2 on CO2 carriage in blood
Effect of CO2 on O2 carriage in blood
Effect of PCO2 on CO2 carriage in blood
Effect of pH on oxygen carriage in blood

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Effect of O2 on CO2 carriage in blood:

Haldane effect:

  • The Haldane effect refers to the influence of oxygen (O2) binding with hemoglobin on the displacement of carbon dioxide (CO2) from the blood. This effect enhances CO2 transport by reducing the tendency of hemoglobin to bind with CO2 and by prompting the release of excess H+ ions, facilitating the release of CO2 from the blood into the alveoli.

Incorrect Options:

Options B and C - Effect of CO2 on O2 carriage in blood and Effect of PCO2 on CO2 carriage in blood: The Haldane effect is the effect of O2 on CO2.

Option D - Effect of pH on oxygen carriage in blood: The decrease in O2 affinity of hemoglobin when the pH of blood falls is called the Bohr effect.

questions.text:
Match the following types of brain tumors with their corresponding radiological features.


	
		
			
			1. Hemangioblastoma
			
			
			a. Mass arising from the vermis, resulting in effacement of the fourth ventricle / basal cisterns and obstructive hydrocephalus
			
		
		
			
			2. Glioblastoma
			
			
			b. Mixed-density tumors with high-attenuation
			
		
		
			
			3. Oligodendroglioma
			
			
			c. Tumor crossing midline with an intense irregular, heterogeneous enhancement of the margins
			
		
		
			
			4. Medulloblastoma
			
			
			d. Sharply demarcated homogeneous masses composed of a cyst with non-enhancing walls
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 1-d, 2-c, 3-b, 4-a:

Hemangioblastoma

  • Typically, hemangioblastomas are sharply demarcated homogeneous masses composed of a cyst with non-enhancing walls, except for a mural nodule, which vividly enhances and often has prominent serpentine flow voids.
  • The cyst walls usually do not enhance, and calcification is not present.

Glioblastoma

  • They often have thick, irregularly enhancing margins and a central necrotic core, which may also have a hemorrhagic component. They cross the midline and are surrounded by vasogenic-type edema.
  • Intense irregular, heterogeneous enhancement of the margins is almost always present.
  • Hemorrhage and calcification are uncommon.

Oligodendroglioma

  • Tumors are of mixed density (hypodense to isodense).
  • High-attenuation areas within the tumor are likely from calcification (70-90% of oligodendrogliomas are calcified) or, less commonly, hemorrhage.
  • Calcification can be located centrally, peripherally, or can be ribbon-like.

Medulloblastoma

  • On CT, medulloblastomas often appear as a mass arising from the vermis, resulting in effacement of the fourth ventricle / basal cisterns and obstructive hydrocephalus. They can also occur more laterally in the cerebellum.
  • They are usually hyperdense.

 

Incorrect Options: 

  • Option B, C & D are incorrect

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with a limp and pain in his right midfoot. His parents report that the symptoms started a few weeks ago and have been progressively worsening. X-rays reveal sclerosis and fragmentation of the affected tarsal bone. Which bone is primarily involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - A:

  • The bone labeled A in the image is navicular.
  • The most likely diagnosis for this child is Kohler disease. It is a disease only seen in pediatric patients and is caused by the compression of the navicular bone prior to ossification.

  • This leads to blood flow abnormalities, resulting in avascular necrosis.
  • Patients present with medial-sided foot pain, swelling of the medial foot, and/or a limp.
  • On plain films, the navicular will have standard avascular necrosis characteristics, including sclerosis, fragmentation, and flattening.
  • Kohler disease is a self-limiting condition with an excellent prognosis.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D: These bones are not affected by Kohler disease.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman with a history of chronic excessive alcohol use is brought to the emergency department by her family. They report that she has been confused and has had difficulty walking for the past few days. On examination, you note global confusion, horizontal nystagmus, and ataxia. Laboratory tests reveal thiamine deficiency. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B: Wernicke's Encephalopathy

  • The patient's history of chronic alcoholism, along with the symptoms of confusion, abnormal eye movements (horizontal nystagmus), and ataxia, are classic features of Wernicke's Encephalopathy. The presence of thiamine deficiency on laboratory tests further supports this diagnosis.

  • Wernicke's Encephalopathy

     

    Onset

     

    Acute

    Symptoms

    G: Global Confusion

    O: Ophthalmoplegia, Horizontal Nystagmus Gaze Palsy

    • 6th nerve Palsy is the most common & 3rd nerve Palsy is the second most common.

    A: Ataxia

     

    Cause

    Thiamine (Vitamin B1) Deficiency

    • Due to poor nutrition.
    • Due to poor absorption of nutrition in chronic alcoholics.

    Thiamine is an important cofactor for several enzymes required in

    body:

    • Thiamine Pyrophosphate
    • Pyruvate Dehydrogenase
    • Alpha-ketoglutarate Dehydrogenase
    • Transketolase
    • Required for axon potential and transmission in the synapse.

     

    Neuropathologic Lesions with symmetrical involving

    · Mammillary bodies

    · Thalamus, Hypothalamus

    · Midbrain

    · Pons

    · Medulla

    · Fornix

    · Cerebellum

    Treatment
    • Thiamine Supplementation- Rapid response to parenteral Thiamine.
    • Initial dose: 100mg (oral- 2-3 times a day) for 1-2 weeks

    Reversible condition

    • Ophthalmoplegia reversed within hours of Thiamine supplementation.
    • Residual ataxia remains despite treatment in a small percentage of cases.
    • For patients with alcohol-related disorders, receiving IV- Glucose solution, it is always a good practice to add 100 mg of Thiamine in each liter of glucose.
    • In alcohol disorder-related patients receiving IV glucose, glucose is utilized against Thiamine as a cofactor and those enzymes are utilized and may precipitate Wernicke's Encephalopathy.

     

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Alcohol intoxication: While alcohol intoxication can cause confusion and impaired coordination, the presence of nystagmus and the classical triad is characteristic of Wernicke's Encephalopathy. Additionally, the presence of thiamine deficiency points towards Wernicke's Encephalopathy rather than acute intoxication.

Option C - Alzheimer's disease: Alzheimer's disease is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder that primarily affects the brain, leading to a decline in cognitive function and memory and behavioral changes. It is not associated with the acute onset of confusion, eye movement abnormalities, and ataxia seen in this case.

Option D - Multiple sclerosis: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a chronic autoimmune disease that affects the central nervous system, which includes the brain and spinal cord.While multiple sclerosis can present with neurological symptoms such as impaired coordination and abnormal eye movements, the history of chronic alcoholism and the presence of thiamine deficiency point towards Wernicke's Encephalopathy as the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 17-year-old woman presents to the emergency department after a sexual assault. She is distressed and expresses concerns about the possibility of pregnancy. After a thorough evaluation, the physician informs her about the Medical Termination of Pregnancy. Identify the incorrect statement about the MTP Act from the options listed below.

choices.text: Risk to mother’s life due to the presence of physical or mental conditions is an indication
Consent is taken from the mother only if her age is ≥ 18 years
In the case of rape or incest, MTP can be done up to 20 weeks only

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - In the case of rape or incest, MTP can be done up to 20 weeks only:

  • This statement is inaccurate as per the Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act.
  • According to the recent amendment, the termination may be allowed beyond 20 weeks and up to 24 weeks in the following cases or for the following persons:
    • Survivors of sexual assault or rape or incest
    • Minors
    • Change of marital status during the ongoing pregnancy (widowhood and divorce)
    • Women with physical disabilities with a major disability
    • Mentally ill women, including mental retardation
    • Women with pregnancy in humanitarian settings or disaster or emergency situations as may be declared by the Government

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Risk to mother’s life due to the presence of physical or mental conditions is an indication:

  • This statement is correct and is a therapeutic indication for MTP.
  • Other indications are contraceptive failure (social), fetal abnormalities (eugenic), and rape (humanitarian).

Option B - Consent is taken from the mother only if her age is ≥ 18 years: This statement is also true. Consent for MTP is obtained from the mother, provided she is ≥ 18. If she is under 18, consent can be obtained from a parent or legal guardian.

Option C - Breach of confidentiality is punishable: Throughout the process of MTP, confidentiality must be maintained. If there is a breach of confidentiality, punishment can be imposed in the form of a fine, 1 year of imprisonment, or both.

questions.text: Which machine from the provided image is used for the further management of a 60-year-old man with acute shortness of breath and respiratory acidosis due to COPD?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - BiPAP Machine:

  • BiPAP (Bilevel Positive Airway Pressure is technically a CPAP that alternates between two pressure levels (inspiratory positive airway pressure (IPAP) higher pressure and expiratory positive airway pressure (EPAP) lower pressure).
  • The principal effect is to increase functional residual capacity and has an added advantage of alveolar recruitment.
  • BiPAP therapy is best for short-term use and in patients with the ability to cough and protect their airways.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Portable Ventilator:

  • A portable ventilator provides invasive ventilatory support and is connected via an endotracheal tube or a tracheostomy tube, not a face mask.
  • It is used to transport patients who require ventilatory support.

Option C - Mechanical Ventilator:

  • An invasive ventilator provides invasive ventilatory support and is connected via an endotracheal tube or a tracheostomy tube, not a face mask.
  • It provides respiratory support to patients who cannot breathe independently.
  • It has 3 modes of ventilation
    • Pressure Controlled Ventilation
    • Volume Controlled Ventilation
    • Pressure Support Ventilation

Option D - ECMO:

  • ECMO stands for extracorporeal membrane oxygenation. The ECMO machine is similar to the heart-lung bypass machine used in open-heart surgery.
  • It pumps and oxygenates a patient's blood outside the body, allowing the heart and lungs to rest.
  • The main advantage of ECMO is that it can maintain the supply of oxygen to the body while resting the lungs.

questions.text:
Below is a list of various uses of epinephrine. Match the clinical conditions with the recommended dose and route of administration of epinephrine.


	
		
			
			1. During local anesthesia
			
			
			a. 0.5 ml of 1:1000, intramuscular
			
		
		
			
			2. Brittle asthma
			
			
			b. 1 ml of 1:10000, intravenous/intraosseous (or) 1 ml of 1:1000, endotracheal
			
		
		
			
			3. Cardiac arrest
			
			
			c. 1:50000 to 1:200000
			
		
		
			
			4. Anaphylaxis
			
			
			d. 0.5 ml of 1:1000, intramuscular (or) subcutaneous
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 1-c, 2-d, 3-b, 4-a:

Epinephrine use

Dose and route

Rationale

Anaphylaxis (DOC)

0.5 ml of 1:1000 – IM route (Vastus lateralis)
  • Epinephrine stimulates b2 receptors – causing bronchodilation
  • Inhibits histamine release from muscles

Brittle asthma (sudden emergency in asthma)

0.5 ml of 1:1000-IM or SC
  • Epinephrine stimulates b2 receptors – causing bronchodilation
  • Inhibits histamine release from muscles

Cardiac arrest (CPR)

1 ml of 1:1000 – IV or IO or 1 ml of 1:1000 - ET
  • Epinephrine stimulates a1 receptor – produces vasoconstriction and increases venous return to the heart
  • Norepinephrine, dopamine, and vasopressin-also are given in cardiac arrest

During or along with local anesthetics

1:50000 to 1:200000
  • Epinephrine when given locally stimulates a1 receptor – produces vasoconstriction and reduces the absorption of the local anesthetic into blood

questions.text: In the given plot, what does a diamond represent?

choices.text: The overall effect size of the studies
The publication status of the studies
The precision of the study results
The type of statistical analysis used

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - The overall effect size of the studies:

  • In a blobbogram (forest plot), the diamond represents the overall effect size calculated from pooled estimates of individual study results, indicating the precision of findings. The vertical line at 0 denotes no effect.

Incorrect Options:

Option B, C & D are incorrect.

  • Is not represented by the diamond in a forest plot.

questions.text:
Observe the images and select the proper order of sample collection into the tubes.


	
		
			
			1.
			
			
			
			
		
		
			
			2.
			
			
			
			
		
		
			
			3.

Correct Options C - 4,2,1,3:

Following a standardized order of draw reduces the risk of contamination between tubes and ensures that additives do not interfere with subsequent tests.
