questions.text: A 44-year-old female diagnosed with osteoarthritis of both knees has been taking indomethacin for the same. She comes to your clinic, and you notice that she is hypertensive. You consider prescribing a diuretic as the patient also has mild swelling of the feet, but decide not to as the patient is taking indomethacin. Indomethacin antagonizes the action of diuretics by which of the following mechanisms?

choices.text: Blocking the action in ascending limb of the loop of Henle
Enhancing salt and water reabsorption in distal tubules

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Preventing prostaglandin-mediated intrarenal-hemodynamic actions:

  • Loop diuretics release prostaglandins, altering intrarenal hemodynamics and salt output.
  • NSAIDs inhibit prostaglandin formation, blunting loop diuretic action.
  • This interaction diminishes diuretic effect, potentially causing fluid retention and kidney injury.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Blocking the action in ascending limb of the loop of Henle:

  • NSAIDs do not block the action of loop diuretics on ascending loop of Henle
  • However, they enhance the antidiuretic effect of ADH on distal convoluted tubules,

Option C - Enhancing salt and water reabsorption in distal tubules:

  • NSAIDs primarily block prostaglandin production, affecting loop diuretics' action on afferent arterioles, not distal tubules.

Option D - Increasing aldosterone secretion:

  • NSAIDs decrease aldosterone release by blocking prostaglandin-induced renin secretion.

questions.text:
Match the following drugs with their corresponding mechanisms of action.


	
		
			
			1. Nalmefene
			
			
			a. Pure kappa agonist
			
		
		
			
			2. Buprenorphine
			
			
			b. Partial kappa agonist + mu antagonist
			
		
		
			
			3. Nalorphine
			
			
			c. Partial mu agonist + kappa antagonist
			
		
		
			
			4. Nalfurafine
			
			
			d. Pure mu/kappa/delta antagonist
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 1-d, 2-c, 3-b, 4-a:

Pure mu/kappa/delta antagonists

  • Competitive blockers of mu/kappa/delta receptors.
    • Naloxone (antidote for morphine or opioid poisoning)
    • Naltrexone (oral drug to prevent relapse in those who were opioid-addicted)
    • Nalmefene

Partial mu agonist + kappa antagonists

  • Buprenorphine
    • Binds to the mu receptor irreversibly
    • Used for opioid deaddiction
  • Dezocine
    • IV analgesic
    • Lesser risk of respiratory depression/addiction due to partial agonism at mu-receptors

Partial kappa agonist + mu antagonists

  • Pentazocine
  • Nalorphine
  • Butorphanol

Pure kappa agonist

  • Nalfurafine
    • Indicated for the treatment of pruritus in hemodialysis patients who have not responded to conventional therapies.

questions.text:
Identify the following histology images and match them with their appropriate locations.


	
		
			
			1.
			
			
			a. Islets of Langerhans in the pancreas
			
		
		
			
			2.
			
			
			b. Glomerulus of the kidney
			
		
		
			
			3.
			
			
			c. Lymph node
			
		
		
			
			4.
			
			
			d. Serous demilune of the parotid gland
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 1-d, 2-c, 3-a, 4-b:

  • Serous demilune of the parotid gland: Serous demilunes are the serous cells at the distal end of the mucous tubuloalveolar secretory unit of certain salivary glands.
    • Darkly stained cuboidal serous cells.
    • These serous cells have a central spherical nucleus, and secretions will be present in the lumen.
  • Lymph node: It is a secondary lymphoid organ where B and T cells proliferate in response to exogenous antigens.
    • It is histologically identified by the outer cortex, paracortex, and inner medulla.
    • Lymphocytes appear as blue dots on the slide, as they are basophilic.
    • Lymph node can be easily identified by the presence of a large subcapsular sinus.
  • Islets of Langerhans in the pancreas: Comprises the hormone-secreting endocrine pancreas.
    • The islets are clumps of secretory cells supported by reticulin fibers and contain numerous fenestrated capillaries.
    • There is a delicate capsule around each islet.
    • They are paler than the surrounding exocrine cells, as they have less rER.
  • Glomerulus of the kidney:
    • Glomeruli are clusters of capillaries that are surrounded by Bowman's capsules and lined with a single layer of epithelial cells called the parietal epithelium.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male smoker presents with coughing up blood for six weeks. After an aggressive investigation, he was diagnosed with a non-small cell carcinoma of the lung. Which EGFR antagonist might be prescribed to a patient if EGFR mutations are detected in the tumor cells?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: Option C: Erlotinib

  • Erlotinib is an EGFR (epidermal growth factor receptor) antagonist used to treat non-small cell carcinoma of the lung.
  • It is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor that targets the EGFR pathway, which is frequently dysregulated in non-small cell lung cancer.
  • Erlotinib is particularly effective in patients with certain EGFR mutations, such as exon 19 deletions or exon 21 L858R mutations.
  • It is often used as a first-line or second-line therapy for advanced or metastatic non-small-cell lung cancer, either alone or in combination with other chemotherapeutic agents.
  • It is also used for metastatic pancreatic cancer.
  • Common side effects of erlotinib include rash, diarrhea, and fatigue.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Sorafenib

  • Sorafenib is a multi-targeted kinase inhibitor primarily used to treat advanced renal cell carcinoma and hepatocellular carcinoma. It is not commonly used to treat non-small cell lung cancer.
  • Sorafenib targets RAF kinases, VEGFR, and PDGFR, among others.

Option B: Sunitinib

  • Sunitinib is also a multi-targeted kinase inhibitor used to treat renal cell carcinoma, gastrointestinal stromal tumors, and pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors. It is not typically used to treat small cell lung cancer.
  • Sunitinib inhibits VEGFR, PDGFR, KIT, and other kinases.

Option D: Pazopanib

  • Pazopanib is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor primarily used in the treatment of advanced renal cell carcinoma and soft tissue sarcoma. It is not a standard treatment for small cell lung cancer.
  • Pazopanib inhibits VEGFR, PDGFR, and KIT, among others.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female presents with palpitations weight loss, tremors, sweating and diarrhea. What is the next test that will help in establishing the diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - TSH and free T4:

  • The clinical features of sympathetic stimulation and weight loss points to diagnosis of hyperthyroidism.
  • The test to confirm diagnosis and find etiology would be TSH and unbound T4.

Incorrect Options:

Option B, C & D are incorrect.

questions.text: A 33-year-old otherwise healthy male presents with fever, dry cough, and shortness of breath for one week. Decreased breath sounds are noted in the lower lobes of both lungs. A nasopharyngeal swab is collected and sent for electron microscopy analysis, whose image is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B. SARS-CoV-2 infection:

  • The electron microscopy image depicts the characteristic morphology of the SARS-CoV-2 virus, which causes COVID-19.
  • The image typically shows a spherical or pleomorphic shape with spike-like projections on the surface, resembling a "crown" (corona in Latin) specific to coronaviruses.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Tuberculosis: Tuberculosis is caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, which appears as acid-fast bacilli on staining rather than as the viral particles seen in the electron microscopy image.

Option C - Influenza A: Influenza viruses are generally more spherical with a less pronounced crown-like appearance.

Option D - Adenovirus: Adenoviruses are icosahedral in shape and do not have the characteristic spike proteins seen in coronaviruses.

questions.text: Two sets of capillary systems are present in which of the following circulations?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A. Pituitary:

  • A portal venous system is one in which veins connect two capillary beds; in other words, it drains one organ/organ system and passes into another organ/organ system rather than directly returning it to the heart.
  • Therefore, portal circulation is a capillary network that lies between two veins.
  • The hepatic portal vein is the only portal system that is well-known.
  • However, there is also a hypophyseal portal system that passes blood from the hypothalamus to the anterior pituitary.
  • Additionally, renal circulation also has two sets of capillary systems.

Incorrect Options:

Option B, C, and D: Unlike portal circulation, these circulations do not have two sets of capillary systems.

questions.text: The image below illustrates the contraction of the cardiac muscle. Which protein should fill in the question mark?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - RyR2:

  • The protein filling in the question mark should be RyR2, as it is the primary isoform responsible for releasing calcium ions from the sarcoplasmic reticulum during excitation-contraction coupling in cardiac muscle.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are incorrect. While RyR1, RyR3, and other proteins may have roles in calcium handling in various tissues, RyR2 is specifically responsible for calcium release in cardiac muscle contraction

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presents to the clinic with visual disturbances. During the eye examination, the ophthalmologist observes a characteristic finding as shown in the image. What is this characteristic finding known as?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Bayoneting sign:

  • The sign seen in the image is the Bayoneting sign. Retinal vessels can disappear as they turn sharply into the cup in severe cases of glaucoma with loss of retinal tissue.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Splinter Hemorrhage:

  • A splinter hemorrhage in the eye, also known as a retinal splinter hemorrhage, is a small area of bleeding or hemorrhage in the retina of the eye. It appears as a thin, linear, red, or dark streak resembling a splinter.

Option B - Cupping of disc:

  • Cupping of the disc, also known as optic disc cupping or cupped optic disc, is a clinical finding refers to the excavation or hollowing out of the optic nerve head. Cupping of the disc occurs when there is damage to the optic nerve fibers, often as a result of elevated intraocular pressure, which is a characteristic feature of glaucoma. The increased pressure in the eye can lead to compression and loss of the nerve fibers, resulting in an indentation or "cup" forming in the center of the optic disc

Option D - Cherry Red Spot:

  • A "cherry-red spot" is a bright red spot in the center of the retina, often seen in the context of central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO) or other conditions like trauma involving the retina and its blood supply.

questions.text: In a 2-year-old child, the presence of strabismus and features shown in the image given below are noted. Among the given options, the most likely condition is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Retinoblastoma:

  • Leukocoria refers to the abnormal appearance of a white reflex in the eye. Retinoblastoma arises from the immature neuroectodermal cells called retinoblasts in the eye. It often presents in children under the age of 3, with the peak incidence around 18 months.
  • Strabismus, or mis-alignment of the eyes, is another common finding in retinoblastoma. The combination of leukocoria and strabismus should raise strong suspicion for this condition in a young child.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Congenital cataract: It is another possible cause of leukocoria in children. It is characterized by clouding of the lens of the eye present at birth or shortly thereafter. Even though strabismus can present with cataracts, the incidence of strabismus is higher with retinoblastoma and, given the severity of the disease, should be ruled out first.

Option C - Coats disease: It is characterized by abnormal blood vessel development in the retina, leading to leaks and subsequent retinal detachment. While it can present with leukocoria, it is typically seen in small male children and is associated with multiple microaneurysms. but the most common is retinoblastoma 

Option D - Central retinal detachment: Refers to the separation of the neurosensory retina from the underlying retinal pigment epithelium. Although it can present with leukocoria, it is not the most common cause .

questions.text: A certain syndicate has acquired the rights to excavate a part of a forest area for the construction of a factory. During the excavation, the remains of a couple of bodies have been recovered. It has been sent to the forensic lab for the determination of its identity. The forensic team would use all of the following formulae to determine the sex of the bone. Which among them is not the right method?

choices.text: Sciatic notch index - Width of notch/ Depth of notch x 100
Washburn ischiopubic index - Pubic length/ Ischial length x 100
Corporobasal index - Length of 1st sacral vertebra/ Length of base of sacrum x 100
Sternal index - Manubrial length/ Body length x 100

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Corporobasal index - Length of 1st sacral vertebra/ Length of base of sacrum x 100:

  • Corporobasal index - Length of 1st sacral vertebra/ Length of base of sacrum x 100 is WRONG as In the FORMULA BREADTH is used.

Incorrect options.

Option A - Sciatic notch index - Width of notch/ Depth of notch x 100: Sciatic notch index - Width of notch/ Depth of notch x 100 is the correct formula.

Option B - Washburn ischiopubic index - Pubic length/ Ischial length x 100: Washburn ischiopubic index - Pubic length/ Ischial length x 100 is the correct formula.

Option D - Sternal index - Manubrial length/ Body length x 100: Sternal index - Manubrial length/ Body length x 100 is the correct formula.

questions.text: A known RA patient presented to ER with hypotension. She was on medication for RA treatment but abruptly stopped medications. HR =110 bpm BP is 80/40 mm Hg, blood sugar =50 mg/dl, Na=130 meq/L and K=6.0 meq/L. What should be the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Hydrocortisone:

  • The clinical presentation is of Addisonian crisis that is managed with hydrocortisone.
  • Initial management requires immediate rehydration with fluids@1L/ hr with continuous cardiac monitoring.
  • This is followed by hydrocortisone 100 mg bolus and 200 mg over the next 24 hours by infusion.

Othe options are irrelevant.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female was diagnosed with Keloid and was advised for excision. However, the patient deferred surgery and opted for medical treatment. Which drug can be used as an intralesional injection in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Triamcinolone:

  • Keloids are firm, rubbery lesions that occur due to the abnormal proliferation of scar tissue at the site of cutaneous injury.
  • It grows beyond the original margins of the scar.
  • A hypertrophic scar is a thick, raised scar resulting from an abnormal response to wound healing.
  • Hypertrophic scars, which are raised scars, do not grow beyond the boundaries.
  • Both of these lesions occur due to an overgrowth of granulation collagen type 3 at the site of a healed skin injury. Collagen type 3  is then slowly replaced by collagen type 1.
  • Treatment of Hypertrophic and Keloid scars
    • Pressure – Local molds or elasticated garments
    • Silicone gel sheeting
    • Intralesional steroid injection (triamcinolone). The benefit of this procedure is that the injection attains a high drug concentration at the disease site with minimal systemic absorption. It is the initial step taken for the management of keloids.
    • Excision and steroid injections (for keloids only)
    • Excision and postoperative radiation (external beam or brachytherapy)
    • Intralesional excision (keloids only)
    • Laser – to reduce redness (which may resolve in any event)
    • Vitamin E or palm oil massage

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Betamethasone:

  • Betamethasone is a corticosteroid and can be used to treat keloids and other forms of abnormal scars.
  • However, triamcinolone acetonide is the most common steroid that is used intralesionally.

Option C - Androgen:

  • Anti-androgen medicine is often recommended for keloid patients with hormonal disorder symptoms.
  • However, it has yet to be officially included in keloid treatment regimens.

Option D - Hydrocortisone:

  • 0.5% hydrocortisone can be applied topically over keloids and hypertrophic scars.
  • It is an over-the-counter treatment for keloids and hypertrophic scars.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presented to the surgery OPD with complaints of swelling in front of her neck. She gives a history of irradiation to her neck during her childhood for Hodgkin lymphoma, which was cured. Her neck examination reveals a hard mass in front of her neck. A FNAC of the thyroid lump is done, which confirms a thyroid carcinoma with no lymph node involvement. Her biopsy picture is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Papillary carcinoma:

  • The patient's clinical features of swelling in the front of the neck associated with hoarseness of voice and biopsy findings suggest Papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC).
  • Pathology of papillary thyroid carcinoma:
    • Papillary projections
    • Optically clear nuclei aka Orphan Annie Eye Nuclei
    • Pseudo-inclusion bodies
    • Dystrophic calcification- Psammoma bodies

  • Papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC) is the most common thyroid malignancy and usually is associated with an excellent prognosis, particularly in young patients.
  • Prognostic risk classification for PTC includes the AGES and AMES scoring systems.
    • The absence of distant metastasis at initial treatment and size less than 4cm are other important positive predictors.
    • Total Thyroidectomy is recommended for all PTCs 1cm or larger
    • PTCs less than 1 cm in diameter are defined as microcarcinomas.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Follicular carcinoma:

  • Follicular thyroid cancer is the second most common type, making up about 10 to 15% of all thyroid cancers.

Option C - Medullary carcinoma:

  • Medullary thyroid cancer (MTC) arises from parafollicular C cells and is a part of MEN syndrome
  • The tumor secretes various tumor markers, including calcitonin and carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA).

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman with dysmenorrhea for the past 4 menstrual cycles with USG, shown below, was prescribed a drug. After use for 6 months, an increase in hepatic enzyme and an adverse lipid profile is noted. Which is the most probable drug used?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option A:

  • This patient has presented with congestive type dysmenorrhea and an ovarian cyst with a ground glass appearance suggestive of endometriosis. Out of the mentioned drugs, only OCP and GnRH analogues are used for endometriosis.
  • OC pills (progesterone components) are associated with increased LDL and decreased HDL cholesterol, but estrogens have the opposite effect. Cholestasis and cholestatic jaundice are occasional side effects of OC pills.

Incorrect Options:

Option B:

  • Rifampicin is an anti-tubercular drug that is known to cause hepatotoxicity but has no role in the management of endometriosis

Option C:

  • GnRH analogues are used to manage endometriosis by causing down-regulation of pituitary receptors and GnRH activity, resulting in low LH and FSH. This suppresses ovarian steroid production, causing a medically induced reversible state of menopause. Their side effects include hypoestrogenic symptoms of hot flashes, headache, loss of libido, vaginal dryness, and osteoporosis. These are not hepatotoxic.

Option D:

  • Methotrexate is a chemotherapeutic agent used to treat cancers, autoimmune diseases, ectopic pregnancy, and medical abortions. They have no role in the management of endometriosis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with progressive hoarseness of voice and difficulty breathing for the past few months. He reports a history of chronic smoking for the past 40 years. On examination, there is evidence of stridor and a palpable mass in the neck. Further evaluation reveals multiple enlarged lymph nodes, each measuring 3-6 cm in size. What is the stage of the disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Stage IV A:

  • The patient’s presentation is suggestive of subglottic carcinoma along with multiple ipsilateral lymph node involvement, each node measuring between 3-6 cm in size.
  • According to the TNM classification, this corresponds to T4a N2 M0, which falls under stage IVA.
  • This indicates a locally advanced disease with extensive lymph node involvement but no distant metastasis.

Incorrect Options: Options A, B, and C are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.text: A 53-year-old male is being evaluated for refractory diffuse large B-cell lymphoma despite multiple lines of chemotherapy. He has undergone autologous stem cell transplantation with no sustained response. The oncologist proposes treatment with CAR-T therapy. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of this therapy?

choices.text: Specifically target CD19 on lymphoma cells, leading to their destruction
Release cytotoxic chemicals that induce apoptosis in lymphoma cells
Stimulate the immune system to produce antibodies against lymphoma cells

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Specifically target CD19 on lymphoma cells, leading to their destruction:

  • CAR-T cells are genetically modified to express chimeric antigen receptors (CARs) that recognize specific antigens on cancer cells, such as CD19 in B-cell lymphomas.
  • Upon binding to CD19, CAR T-cell become activated, leading to the destruction of lymphoma cells through various mechanisms, including cytotoxicity and cytokine release.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Release cytotoxic chemicals that induce apoptosis in lymphoma cells: CAR T-cells do not release cytotoxic chemicals directly; instead, they rely on their engineered receptors to recognize and target cancer cells.

Option C - Stimulate the immune system to produce antibodies against lymphoma cells: While CAR-T therapy does involve immune cells (T cells) that can stimulate antibody production, the primary mechanism of action is the direct targeting and destruction of cancer cells by CAR T-cells themselves, rather than through antibody-mediated mechanisms.

Option D - Targeting cell cycle regulators: CAR T-cells primarily exert their effects by targeting specific antigens on cancer cells rather than directly inhibiting cell cycle regulators. Their mechanism of action is more related to cytotoxicity and immune-mediated killing.

questions.text: A 45-year-old hospitalized patient with a history of chronic alcoholism is being evaluated for altered mental status. Several electrolyte derangements were present on admission. MRI of the brain is shown in the image. Which electrolyte abnormality is involved in the development of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Hyponatremia:

  • Rapid correction of severe hyponatremia can lead to ODS due to the sudden shift in osmolarity, causing damage to the myelin sheaths.
  • Osmotic demyelination syndrome (or central pontine myelinolysis) is a neurological disorder characterized by the destruction of myelin sheaths in the central pontine and extrapontine regions of the brain.
  • Patients most often have a history of alcohol use disorder.
  • The trident sign describes the typical appearances of the pons in ODS, whereby there is symmetrical T2 hyperintensity centrally in the pons, with sparing of peripheral pontine fibers.

 

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D: These electrolyte disturbances are not associated with the development of ODS.

questions.text:
During a routine eye examination, a 40-year-old patient is asked to read letters on the chart shown below. The patient struggles to read the smaller letters and reports blurred vision.



Which aspect of the patient's visual perceptions is assessed through this chart?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Form sense:

  • The Snellen chart is commonly used to assess visual acuity, which is a measure of the eye's ability to distinguish the details and form of objects. Form sense is measured by visual acuity. In this scenario, the patient's struggle to read the smaller letters and reporting blurred vision suggests a difficulty in perceiving the form or details of the letters, indicating an issue with form sense or visual acuity.

Incorrect Options:

Option A – Light sense:

  • Light sense, also known as photopic vision, refers to the ability to perceive and differentiate levels of brightness or light intensity. The Snellen chart primarily assesses visual acuity (form sense) rather than sensitivity to light.

Option C – Color sense:

  • Color sense, or color vision, is the ability to perceive and differentiate between different colors. The Snellen chart is not designed to assess color vision; it focuses on form sense and visual acuity.

Option D – Contrast sense:

  • Contrast sense involves the ability to distinguish any object from its background. While visual acuity is related to contrast sensitivity, the Snellen chart primarily assesses the clarity and resolution of the visual image (form sense) rather than contrast sensitivity.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman diagnosed with an unruptured left tubal ectopic was admitted to the gynecology ward and is planned for medical management. What is the dose and route of methotrexate to be used?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C:

  • Methotrexate for medical management of unruptured ectopic pregnancy is used as 50 mg/m2 intramuscular.

  • Single dose regime (Methotrexate)

    Multi-dose regime (Methotrexate & Leucovorin)

    · 1 mg/kg on day 0

    · 1 mg/kg on days 1, 3, 5 and 7

    · Measure β-hCG on days 4 and 7

    · Leucovorin rescue: 0.1 mg/kg on alternate days

    · If the levels do not drop by 15% then repeat the dose

     

    · Measure β-hCG on days 1,3,5 and 7 till a 15% drop is seen between 2 values

     

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the sterilization of equipment is true?

choices.text: Dry heat is the best method of sterilization for liquid paraffin
Glasswares are best sterilized by boiling at 100º C
Bacterial vaccines are best sterilized by ethylene oxide
Pasteurization of milk by the flash method is done by heating at 63 degree C for 30 minutes.

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Dry heat is the best method of sterilization of liquid paraffin:

Dry heat is the best method for sterilizing liquid paraffin. Dry heat sterilization is done by three methods:

  1. Flaming: Sterilized by holding the material over a Bunsen flame till it becomes red hot, used for sterilizing inoculating loop or wire, the tip of forceps, and searing spatulas.
  2. Incineration: Used for terminal sterilization of biomedical waste.
  3. Hot air oven: Sterilization is achieved by conduction. A holding period of 160oC for 2 hours is necessary for sterilization. Materials sterilized are glassware (syringes, petri dishes, flasks, pipettes), surgical instruments (scalpels & scissors), and chemicals (dusting powder, grease, paraffin, and oils).​​​​​​​

Incorrect Options:

Option B - All glasswares are best sterilized by boiling at 100º C:

  • Glasswares are best sterilized by boiling at 160oC for 2 hours in a hot air oven.

Option C - Bacterial vaccines are best sterilized by ethylene oxide:

  • Filtration (Membrane filters) are used for the sterilization of the heat-labile materials like vaccines, antibiotics, toxins, serum, and sugar solution.

Option D - Pasteurization of milk by the flash method is done by heating at 63 degree C for 30 minutes:

  • Pasteurization of milk by the flash method is done at 72°C for 15-20 sec, followed by rapid cooling to 13°C.

questions.text: Which study design is shown in the image given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Cross-over trial:

  • The study design layout involves participants progressing through trial phases, receiving multiple interventions in sequence with a washout period to minimize carryover effects.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Concurrent parallel trial:

  • Two randomly assigned study and control groups are compared. Study subjects remain in the same group (study or control group) for the total duration of the investigation

Option C - Two-by-two factorial design:

  • The subjects are first randomized to treatment arm A or B to address one hypothesis and thereafter within each group, there is further randomization to treatments X or Y for evaluation of the second hypothesis.

Option D - Two-by-two-by-two factorial design:

  • It is an extension of the two-by-two study design in which each subgroup is further randomized into two more groups.

questions.text:
Match the following congenital heart diseases with the characteristic appearances on chest X-ray.


	
		
			
			1. Tetralogy of Fallot
			
			
			a. 
			
		
		
			
			2. Transposition of great arteries
			
			
			b. 
			
		
		
			
			3. Total anomalous pulmonary venous return
			
			
			c. 
			
		
		
			
			4. Ebstein anomaly
			
			
			d.
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 1-c, 2-d, 3-b, 4-a:

1 - Tetralogy of Fallot: Boot-shaped heart due to right ventricular hypertrophy.

 

2- Transposition of great arteries: Egg-on-side or egg-on-string appearance of the heart due to abnormal positioning of the great vessels.

 

3- Total anomalous pulmonary venous return: Snowman or cottage loaf or figure-eight appearance of the heart.

 

4- Ebstein anomaly: Enlarged right atrium with a "box-like" appearance.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl comes to the office with severe acne on her face and back. She is extremely concerned about her acne as treatment with Benzyl peroxide and oral Doxycycline has proven ineffective. She is not sexually active. Physical examination reveals comedones, inflammatory papules, pustules, and scarring on her face. Which of the following is the next best treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 13 cis-retinoic acid:

  • Used for nodulocystic acne
  • Mechanism:
    • Inhibits sebum production
    • Inhibits keratinocyte proliferation
  • Contraindications: Pregnancy, Liver disease
  • Precautions:
    • Negative pregnancy test
    • Two contraception methods
  • Adverse effects: Dry skin, Headache, Alopecia, Idiopathic intracranial hypertension, Teratogenic effect

Incorrect Options:

Option A - All trans-retinoic acid:

  • Used for acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL)
  • Mechanism: Binds to retinoic acid receptors, inducing cell differentiation

Option B - Tocopherol:

  • Antioxidant, prevents free radical damage
  • Used in nonalcoholic steatohepatitis

Option C - Phylloquinone:

  • Cofactor for gamma-carboxylation of coagulation factors
  • Deficiency leads to bleeding disorders

questions.text:
Match the following common names of glycerophospholipids with their chemical names.


	
		
			
			1. Cephalin
			
			
			a. Diphosphatidyl glycerol
			
		
		
			
			2. Lecithin
			
			
			b. Phosphatidyl ethanolamine
			
		
		
			
			3. Cardiolipin
			
			
			c. Phosphatidylcholine
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 1-b, 2-c, 3-a:

  • Glycerophospholipids are esters containing fatty acids, phosphates, and glycerol. They are derivatives of phosphatidate.
  • Cephalin is chemically called phosphatidyl ethanolamine.
    • Composition: Free phosphate group + Ethanolamine
  • Lecithin is chemically called phosphatidylcholine. It is a major chemical component of surfactant.
    • Composition: Free phosphate group + Choline
    • If 1st two fatty acids in phosphatidylcholine are palmitic acid, it is called dipalmitoyl phosphatidylcholine
  • Cardiolipin is chemically called diphosphatidyl glycerol.
    • Composition: Free phosphate group of 2 phosphatidate.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A, C & D are incorrect.

questions.text: Identify the set of secondary vertebral curvatures.
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Lumbar lordosis, cervical lordosis:

  • Vertebral curvatures are of two types: primary and secondary.
  • Secondary vertebral curvatures are also known as acquired curvatures or secondarily acquired lordosis, as they are acquired after birth. They include:
    • Cervical lordosis: formed after a few months of birth when the baby starts to hold the neck straight.
    • Lumbar lordosis: appears because of sitting, standing, and walking.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D:

  • Thoracic kyphosis and sacral kyphosis are primary vertebral curvatures.
  • Primary curvatures, also known as fetal curvatures, primary degree curvatures, or kyphosis, are present from birth.
  • Both the primary curvatures are concave anteriorly and convex posteriorly.

questions.text: Which of the following bags is designated for the disposal of the waste shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Red color:

  • Red color bags are designated for the disposal of infectious materials and medical waste such as Foley urinary catheters. They require no pretreatment and are often recycled.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Yellow color:

  • Yellow color bags are for infectious waste but not suitable for disposing of Foley urinary catheters, which are typically made of rubber or plastic.

Option C - White color:

  • White color bags are for sharps like needles and scalpels, not for Foley catheters.

Option D - Blue color:

  • Blue color bags are for glass and metallic implants, not appropriate for Foley catheters, which are predominantly made of rubber or plastic.

questions.text:
Match the following developmental milestones.


	
		
			
			1. Transfers objects

			2. Social smile

			3. Pincer grasp

			4. Walks 1-2 steps
			
			
			a. 1-2 months

			b. 6-7 months

			c. 12-15 months

			d. 9-12 months
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 1-b, 2-a, 3-d, 4-c:

Transfers objects 6-7 months
Social smile 1-2 months
Pincer grasp 9-12 months
Walks 1-2 steps 12-15 months

Incorrect Options: 

  • Options A, C and D are incorrect.

questions.text:
Match the following structures with their corresponding blood oxygen saturation.


	
		
			
			1. Umbilical vein
			
			
			a. 60%
			
		
		
			
			2. Hepatocardiac inferior vena cava
			
			
			b. 50%
			
		
		
			
			3. Superior vena cava
			
			
			c. 80%
			
		
		
			
			4. Pulmonary artery
			
			
			d. 67%
			
		
		
			
			5. Umbilical arteries
			
			
			e. 40%
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 1-c, 2-d, 3-e, 4-b, 5-a:

  • Fetal circulation is clearly different from adult circulation. In the fetus, gas exchange does not occur in the lungs but in the placenta.
  • The placenta must, therefore, receive deoxygenated blood from the fetal systemic organs and return its oxygen-rich venous drainage to the fetal systemic arterial circulation.

  • Oxygen saturations:
    • Umbilical vein: 80%
    • Hepatocardiac inferior vena cava: 67%
    • Superior vena cava: 40%
    • Pulmonary artery: 50%
    • Umbilical arteries: 60%

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, G2P2, presents to the emergency department with intense, sudden onset pelvic pain and profuse bleeding after giving birth at home. Examination reveals a tender, mass protruding from the vagina. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B

Uterine inversion 

  • Uterine inversion occurs when the uterus turns inside out. This typically presents as intense pelvic pain, profuse bleeding, and a palpable mass. Fundus of the uterus will be absent on abdominal palpation. 

Causes:

  • Mismanaged 3rd stage of labor (m/c cause)
  • Fundal implantation of placenta
  • Sudden cord traction

Management:

  • Rapid infusion of fluids
  • Reposition as soon as possible
    • Manual Reposition: 
      • Johnson maneuver: Manually applying pressure to the top of the uterus through the vaginal wall towards the umbilicus.
    • Hydrostatic Reposition
    • Surgical Methods
      • Huntington's Method →Atraumatic clamps
      • Haultian Method →Resection of the constricting Bands

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Uterine rupture 

  • Uterine rupture involves a tear in the uterine wall, typically during labor. This can result in severe abdominal pain, changes in fetal heart rate, and signs of shock.

Option C: Placental abruption

  • Placental abruption involves the separation of the placenta from the uterine wall before delivery. This can lead to severe abdominal pain and bleeding.

Option D:

  • Cervical lacerations involve tears in the cervix, and they can cause bleeding.

questions.text:
60-year-old diabetic male presents with central chest pain, SOB and palpitations came to the ER. ECG was done. Which of the following are used in management of this patient?



a. Aspirin

b. Ticagrelor

c. Nitrates

d. LMWH
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - a,b,c,d:

  • ECG shows NSTEMI has a platelet heart rate of 75bpm with ST depression in lead II, III, aVF. NSTEMI has a platelet rich clot and hence needs dual antiplatelet therapy and LMWH will prevent further clot propagation. If patient is very high risk and needs PCI then IV gp IIB/IIIa inhibitors will be started like Cangrelor or Eptibatide or Tirofiban.

  • First line management in NSTE-ACS is anti-ischemia agents like nitrates, beta blockers and morphine. Then D.A.P.T and anticoagulants are used.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A, B & C are incorrect

questions.text: After receiving fresh frozen plasma, a patient suddenly starts coughing. She rapidly develops fever and severe dyspnea, with Spo2 of 60% on room air. Her blood pressure fell to 90/40mmHg. The patient’s D-dimer levels were within normal limits. Plain radiographs of the chest and echocardiogram reveal features of noncardiogenic pulmonary edema. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI):

  • Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI) is a serious blood transfusion complication characterized by the sudden onset of non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema accompanied by hypoxia following the transfusion of blood products.
  • Signs and symptoms are sudden development of dyspnea, severe hypoxemia (O2 saturation <90% in room air), hypotension and fever that develops within 6 hours after transfusion and usually resolves with supportive care within 48 to 96 hours.
  • Antibodies directed toward human leukocyte antigens (HLA) or human neutrophil antigens (HNA) have been implicated.
  • Multiparous women develop these antibodies through exposure to fetal blood; transfusion of blood components obtained from these donors is thought to carry a higher risk of inducing immune-mediated TRALI.
  • TRALI is more commonly associated with plasma products such as fresh frozen plasma (FFP). However, it can also occur in recipients of PRBC, both in adult and pediatric patients.
  • Supportive care is the mainstay of therapy in TRALI.
    • Oxygen supplementation is employed in all reported cases of TRALI, and aggressive respiratory support is needed in 72 percent of patients.
    • Intravenous administration of fluids, as well as vasopressors, are essential for blood pressure support.
    • The use of diuretics is indicated in transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO) and should be avoided in TRALI.
    • Corticosteroids can be beneficial.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction:

  • It is caused by cytokines created by donor white blood cells (WBCs) accumulating during the storage of blood products.
  • It is more common in children.
  • Fever develops within 1–6 hours (due to preformed cytokines) headaches, chills, and flushing.
  • The reactions are prevented by the leukoreduction of blood products.

Option C - Transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO):

  • The distinguishing feature between transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO) and transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI) lies in their clinical presentations. Specifically, TACO typically lacks hypotension and fever, whereas TRALI may manifest with these symptoms.
  • TACO is a common transfusion reaction in which pulmonary edema develops primarily due to volume excess or circulatory overload.
  • TACO typically occurs in patients who receive a large volume of a transfused product over a short period, especially those with underlying cardiovascular or renal disease.
  • TACO is characterized by pulmonary hydrostatic (cardiogenic) edema, whereas TRALI presents as pulmonary permeability edema (noncardiogenic).

Option D - Pulmonary embolism:

  • In pulmonary embolism patient presents with symptoms such as substernal or lateral pain, pleuritic nature, hemoptysis, tachycardia, and hypoxemia.
  • History of recent immobilization/surgeries is mostly present.
  • However, given this patient's normal D dimer, PE is unlikely. Further, her recent transfusion makes TRALI more likely.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old male presents to the surgical ER after a road traffic accident 30 minutes ago. His ECG is shown below:



 Which of the following is the dose of shock energy to be delivered for the biphasic waveform in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 200 J asynchronous Shock:

  • The ECG shows ventricular fibrillation.
  • For the biphasic form, 200J asynchronous shock is preferred.
  • AHA proposed a summary for the management of cardiac arrest: Activate emergency response system
    • 1a. Initiate CPR and give oxygen when available
    • 1b. Attach monitor/defibrillator/AED as soon as possible
    • 2. If shockable rhythm (VF, pVT), defibrillate (shock) once. Use the manufacturer's device-specific recommendation (e.g., 120-200 J for biphasic waveform and 360 J for monophasic waveform); if unknown, use the maximum available energy setting.
    • 3a. Resume CPR immediately without a pulse check and continue for five cycles. One cycle of CPR equals 30 compressions and two breaths; five cycles of CPR should take roughly 2 minutes (compression rate 100-120 per minute); do not check for rhythm/pulse until five cycles of CPR are completed.
    • 3b. Secure IV (preferred) or IO access. During CPR, minimise interruptions while securing IV access.
    • 3c. After 5 cycles (2 min) of CPR, recheck for a pulse and rhythm.
    • 4. If shockable rhythm (VF, pVT), defibrillate (shock) once. Use an equal or greater energy setting than the previous defibrillation.
    • 5a. Resume CPR immediately without a pulse check and continue for five cycles.
    • 5b. Give epinephrine every 3-5 minutes.
    • 5c. Consider advanced airway. Consider capnography. If intubation is elected, minimise interruptions while performing endotracheal intubation. Once the patient is intubated, continue CPR at 100-120 compressions per minute without pauses for respirations, and ventilate at 10 breaths per minute.
    • 5d. After 5 cycles (2 min) of CPR, recheck for a pulse and rhythm.
    • 6. If shockable rhythm (VF, pVT), defibrillate (shock) once. Use an equal or greater energy setting than the previous defibrillation.
    • 7a. Continue CPR.
    • 7b. Give amiodarone (first dose 300 mg, second dose half that) or lidocaine (first dose 1-1.5 mg/kg, second dose half that).
    • 7c. Treat reversible causes, if present.
  • Go to '3c' above. If there is no shockable rhythm (and no pulse):
    • 7d. Continue CPR.
    • 7e. Treat reversible causes, if present. Go to '9b' below. If no shockable rhythm (PEA, asystole):
    • 9a. Give epinephrine as soon as possible. Then give epinephrine every 3-5 minutes.
    • 9b. Resume CPR immediately without a pulse check and continue for five cycles. One cycle of CPR equals 30
    • compressions and two breaths; five cycles of CPR should take roughly 2 minutes (compression rate 100-120 per minute); do not check for rhythm/pulse until five cycles of CPR are completed.
    • 9c. Secure IV (preferred) or IO access. During CPR, minimise interruptions while securing IV access. Consider advanced airway.
    • Consider capnography. If intubation is elected, minimise interruptions while performing endotracheal intubation. Once the patient is intubated, continue CPR at 100-120 compressions per minute without pauses for respirations, and ventilate at 10 breaths per minute.
    • 9d. After 5 cycles (2 min) of CPR, recheck for a pulse and rhythm. If shockable rhythm (VF, pVT),
  •  Go to '4' above. If no shockable rhythm (and no pulse):
    • 10a. Continue CPR. 10b. Treat reversible causes, if present.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - 360 J unsynchronised shock:

  • 360J shock is used for the monophasic waveform.
  • For the biphasic waveform, a shock of 120-200J is given.

Option C - 200 J Synchronous Shock:

  • The synchronous shock is delivered in the cases of cardioversion, not defibrillation.

Option D - 300 J Synchronous Shock:

  • The synchronized shock delivers the shock when the R wave is at its peak.
  • Unsynchronized shock is given in cases where rhythm is not identified, as in the above case.

questions.text: The image shows the uterine sutures in a woman with PPH. Identify.
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A

  • B-Lynch suture
  • Two sutures are applied longitudinally, which looks like a "brace-suspender,"
  • The b-Lynch suture is referred as the "brace suture."
  • It involves the use of vertical brace sutures, which appose the anterior and posterior wall of the uterus, which leads to compression of the fundus and lower uterine segment, thereby controlling hemorrhage

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Hayman suture

  • Hayman procedure is considered a uterine compression suture using two longitudinal threads and transfixing the entire uterine wall.
  • This suture is simpler than the B-Lynch suture, and is sometimes called the "simple brace."

Option C: Cho suture

  • The Cho suture, or Modified Cho suture, involves placing a series of vertical and horizontal sutures on the uterine fundus to achieve hemostasis.

Option D: Pereira suture

  • The Pereira suture is a type of uterine compression suture, involving placing horizontal and vertical sutures on the uterus.
  • It is different from Cho suture as there is no transfixion of the total uterine wall.

questions.text: A patient currently employed as an accountant presents to the clinic complaining that she is unable to perform simple mathematical calculations. Examination reveals finger agnosia and left-right disorientation. A lesion in which Brodmann’s area is the cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C. Area 39:

  • This patient presents with classic clinical features of Gerstmann’s syndrome.
  • It is a neurological disorder consisting of a tetrad of symptoms, which include impairment in:
    • performing calculations (acalculia)
    • discriminating their own fingers (finger agnosia)
    • writing by hand (agraphia)
    • impairment of distinguishing left from right (left-right disorientation)
  • This disorder results from a lesion in Brodmann’s area 39 (association area) of the parietal lobe. The angular gyrus divides the pathway between the visual association area and the anterior part of Wernicke’s area.
  • On neuroimaging, abnormalities should be seen in the dominant angular gyrus with or without the involvement of the surrounding areas.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Area 43: Area 43 is the taste area present in the parietal lobe. A lesion in this area causes loss of taste sensation.

Option B - Area 22: Area 22 (Wernicke's area) is present in the temporal lobe. It is responsible for language comprehension. A lesion in this area causes receptive aphasia.

Option D - Area 41: Area 41 is the primary auditory cortex located in the temporal lobe. A lesion causes loss of ability to locate sound and deafness.

questions.text: A 30-year-old primigravida presents to the labor room at 34 weeks of gestation with acute abdominal pain in the abdomen and decreased fetal movements for 2 hours. Her blood pressure is 120/80mmHg, her pulse is 90/min, and her temperature is 98F. On examination, the uterus is tender, the cervix is 1cm dilated, with active bleeding per vagina. A fetal cardiac tocograph (CTG) shows no fetal distress. Which of the following is the next best step in managing this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Immediate induction of labor

  • The patient has had a spontaneous placental abruption as suggested by pain abdomen, decreased fetal movements, vaginal bleeding, and uterine tenderness.
  • Placental abruption is the premature separation of the placenta from the endometrium before delivery of the fetus.
  • It can cause concealed or visible external vaginal bleeding.
  • Patients present with abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, and fetal heart rate abnormalities.
  • Placental abruption, when identified, requires immediate termination irrespective of gestation. Conservative management will lead to fetal distress and fetal and maternal mortality.
  • Induction of labor and delivery or C-section is indicated depending on the condition of the fetus and mother.  Abruption is not an absolute indication for LSCS. If associated with fetal distress (FHR) <110 on Doppler/ fetal scalp blood pH is <7.2 → Do LSCS
  • In the absence of fetal distress, the best option is immediate induction of labor.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Immediate lower segment cesarean section (LSCS)

  • Placental abruption is not an absolute indication of LSCS.
  • However, if a placental abruption is associated with fetal distress, immediate LSCS is indicated.
  • Decreased fetal movements (in this patient) are not an indication of the cesarean section.
  • Decreased fetal movements require more intensive intrapartum fetal monitoring.

Option C: Tocolytic therapy

  • Tocolytics are drugs that decrease the uterine contractions of the uterus, causing it to relax.
  • Tocolytics include drugs such as nifedipine, terbutaline, and indomethacin.
  • Tocolytics are generally indicated before 32 weeks of gestation for uncomplicated preterm labor management to delay labor.
  • This patient presented with features of concealed placental abruption, which requires immediate induction and delivery. Tocolytics are contraindicated in abruption.

Option D: Magnesium sulfate therapy

  • Magnesium sulfate (MgSO₄) is commonly used in eclampsia and worsening preeclampsia to prevent seizures. 
  • It may also be used in preterm labor to reduce risk of cerebral palsy. 
  • It also has its use as a tocolytic.
  • No use of MgSO4 is seen in placental abruption.

questions.text: A 12-month-old girl presents with diffuse edema, desquamation, and irritability, previously misdiagnosed as atopic dermatitis. The mother had placed the child on a severely restrictive diet, consisting only of potatoes, gelatin, and juice, as a consequence of her inability to breastfeed. She also has a history of preterm birth. On examination, she has hepatomegaly, pitting edema till mid-thighs, and dermatitis. What is the abnormality in this child's hair, as shown in the picture below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Flag sign:

  • A history of preterm birth and poor intake suggest the diagnosis of protein-energy malnutrition.
  • The presence of edema and hepatomegaly also leads to a diagnosis of Kwashiorkor.
  • Kwashiorkor is often misdiagnosed as eczema and can be harmful if unrecognized or untreated. It is important to consider the diagnosis, recognize the potential risk factors, and accurately assess patients' nutritional status.
  • Alternate bands of pigmented & hypopigmented hairs seen in a child with malnutrition are termed a 'Flag sign.'
  • Hair is red-yellow to grey-white, dry, brittle, sparse, and lost.
  • They appear de-curled and are easily pluckable.
  • The alternating transverse pale bands in dark hair are alternating periods of adequate- and under-nutrition.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Toad sign:

  • The toad sign is dry and flaky skin, seen in essential fatty acid deficiency.
  • It is also called phrynoderma.

Option C - Flaky paint sign:

  • It is a nonspecific scaly dermatitis, often red-brown, and resembles flaking paint, hence called flaky paint dermatitis.
  • It involves the perineum, groin, upper and lower limbs, ears, and axilla.

Option D - Half and half sign:

  • Half and half nails (also known as "Lindsay's nails") show the proximal portion of the nail white and the distal half red or brown.
  • There is a sharp line of demarcation.
  • It is seen in chronic kidney disease.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is inhibited in the Pasteur effect?
questions.solution:
Correct Options C - Phosphofructokinase:

  • The Pasteur effect is a phenomenon that occurs when oxygen slows down glycolysis in cells and suppresses lactate accumulation.
  • It involves the inhibition of anaerobic oxidation by aerobic oxidation products.
  • Citrate and ATP inhibit phosphofructokinase 1 (PFK1).
  • Changes in the concentrations of metabolites that regulate the activity of phosphofructokinase mediate the inhibition of glycolysis in the presence of oxygen.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D: These enzymes are also involved in the glycolysis pathways. However, they are not directly inhibited in the Pasteur effect.

questions.text: A child presents with decreased sweating and episodic burning pain in his hands and feet, particularly exacerbated by exercise or hot weather. Examination reveals skin lesions, as shown in the image. Which of the following substrates accumulates in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Ceramide trihexoside:

  • This child most likely suffers from Fabry disease.
  • Fabry disease is an X-linked recessive lysosomal storage disease caused by decreased activity of α-galactosidase A and results in lysosomal accumulations of ceramide trihexoside (globotriaosylceramide).
  • Angiokeratoma is the typical skin lesion found in affected patients. Angiokeratomas are microvascular lesions that can appear as small petechiae.
  • Clinical manifestations:
    • Early: triad of episodic peripheral neuropathy, angiokeratomas, and hypohidrosis
    • Late: progressive renal failure and cardiovascular disease

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - GM2 ganglioside: In Tay-Sachs disease, GM2 ganglioside accumulates due to deficient hexosaminidase A. Affected children develop progressive neurodegeneration, developmental delay, hyperreflexia, and hyperacusis.

Option B - Cerebroside sulfate: Deficiency of arylsulfatase A leads to accumulation of cerebroside sulfate. This defect causes metachromatic leukodystrophy that presents with central and peripheral demyelination with ataxia and dementia.

Option C - Galactocerebroside and psychosine: Galactocerebrosidase (galactosylceramidase) deficiency leads to the accumulation of these substrates. The resultant lysosomal storage disease is Krabbe disease, manifesting as peripheral neuropathy, developmental delay, and optic atrophy.

questions.text: A group of pharmacists is experimenting with the effect of different types of antagonists. They take a drug and two antagonists for their experiment and draw a graph, as in the image given below, showing the log dose-response curve (DRC) of the drug alone (A) and in the presence of antagonists (B & C). Regarding their experiment, which type of antagonist do the curves B and C represent?

choices.text: B is competitive and C is noncompetitive antagonism
B is noncompetitive, and C is a competitive antagonism

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - B is competitive, and C is non-competitive antagonism:

Competitive and non-competitive antagonist:

  • Competitive antagonists compete to bind the same site on a receptor as an agonist.
  • Non-competitive antagonists bind to an allosteric site of the receptor, i.e., other than the active site.
  • In competitive antagonism, the DRC shifts towards the right, i.e., potency decreases, but efficacy remains the same.
  • On the other hand, in non-competitive antagonism, the curve becomes flat, i.e., potency remains the same, but efficacy decreases.
  • The DRC in the question shows that curve B is on the right side, representing an antagonist with the same efficacy as the drug (curve A) but is less potent.

  • So, curve B must represent a competitive antagonist.
  • On the other hand, curve C represents another antagonist with the same potency as the drug but less efficacy.
  • Therefore, curve C must represent a non-competitive antagonist.

Incorrect Options:

Option B, C and D: Refer to explanation given above

questions.text: A 40-year-old male came to the clinic following a fall from a motorcycle. On examination, the wound is clean. He had taken full TT immunization 11 years back. Which among the following is the Tetanus vaccine that can be given to this patient?

choices.text: Two doses of TT 2 days apart

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - A single dose of TT vaccine:

  • A single dose of the TT vaccine can be given to a person with a clean wound who had taken the last vaccine more than 10 years back (The patient belongs to Category C of Tetanus Management Protocol)
Category Clean Wound Unclean Wound
Category A
  • Full immunization within 5 years.
  • Only wound care.
  • Only wound care.
Category B
  • Full immunization > 5 years ago < 10 years.
  • Wound Care + TT single dose.
  • Wound Care + TT single dose.
Category C
  • Full Immunization > 10 years ago.
  • Wound Care+ TT single dose.
  • Wound Care + TT single dose + Human Tetanus Immunoglobulin.
Category D
  • Unknown, not known, never taken immunization.
  • Wound Care + TT complete
  • Wound Care + TT complete course + Human Tetanus Immunoglobulin.

Incorrect Options:

Options A - TT complete course:

  • If the person has never taken vaccination or is not known, a TT complete course is administered

Option C - Human Tetanus immunoglobulin:

  • If the wound is unclean in a patient who had taken immunization 10 years back or is unknown, human tetanus immunoglobulin is given along with other management options

Option D -Two doses of TT 2 days apart:

  • Tetanus management protocol does not have administration of two doses of TT 2 days apart as a management option

questions.text: All are true about the frequency of Pap smear tests except?

choices.text: From 21 to 29 years, Sexually active women should have cytology every 2 years
After 65 years: No more Pap smear (if 3 cytology are negative or 2 Co-TEST are negative)
Any woman 3 years after 1st sexual exposure (in India)
A pap smear can be done on any woman > 21 years of age (western data)

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - From 21 to 29 years, Sexually active women should have cytology every 2 years:

  • This is an incorrect statement about the frequency of Pap smear test
  • The correct feature is that From 21 to 29 years, Sexually active women should have cytology every 3 years

Other features are as follows:

  • After 65 years: No more Pap smear (if 3 cytology are negative or 2 Co-TEST are negative)
  • Any woman 3 years after 1st sexual exposure (in India)
  • A pap smear can be done on any woman > 21 years of age (western data)

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, D:

  • These are correct about the frequency of Pap smear test

questions.text: A 36-year-old male presents with a complaint of gradual hair thinning and balding over the past few years. He is otherwise healthy and does not use any medications. On examination, there is hair thinning, as shown in the image. Which type of alopecia is this?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Androgenetic alopecia:

  • The image and clinical description are classic for androgenetic alopecia, also known as male-pattern baldness. It is a type of non-cicatricial or non-scarring alopecia.
  • This condition is characterized by progressive male patterned thinning of hair, typically starting at the temples and vertex of the scalp, with preservation of the frontal hairline.
  • The pattern in the image shows diffuse thinning in these areas, consistent with androgenetic alopecia.
  • It is an androgen-dependent condition and is non-genetic.
  • It is graded from I to VII by Norwood-Hamilton classification.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Alopecia areata:

  • Alopecia areata presents with well-defined patches of hair loss that are typically round or oval-shaped.
  • It is an autoimmune T-cell mediated disorder leading to sudden hair loss.
  • There is no scarring or follicular damage in alopecia areata.

Option C - Cicatricial alopecia:

  • Cicatricial alopecia, also known as scarring alopecia, results from the destruction of hair follicles and their replacement with scar tissue.
  • This condition often presents with areas of smooth, shiny skin without hair, and there may be signs of inflammation, such as erythema or scaling.

Option D - Anagen effluvium:

  • Anagen effluvium is characterized by sudden hair loss due to the disruption of the hair growth cycle, often caused by factors such as chemotherapy or toxic exposures.
  • It presents as diffuse hair shedding without specific patterns of baldness.
  • Since the patient in the scenario describes gradual thinning over the years without recent illnesses or exposures, anagen effluvium is not the correct diagnosis.

questions.text: The body of a 45-year-old male with a known history of HIV infection has been sent for postmortem investigations. What is the best method of organ removal in the autopsy of this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Rokinansky method:

  • Rokitansky's technique: It involves in situ dissection in part, combined with en block removal.
  • It is the preferred choice in patients with highly transmissible diseases, such as HIV, and hepatitis B.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Letulle’s method:

  • Lettulle's technique: Cervical, thoracic, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed en masse and dissected as organ blocks.
  • It has the advantage of leaving all attachments intact.

Option B - Ghon’s method:

  • Ghon's Technique: Cervical, thoracic, abdominal organs and urogenital system are removed as organ blocks.
  • The neuronal system is removed as another block.

Option D - Virchow method:

  • Virchow's technique: Individual organs are removed one by one.
  • The cranial cavity is exposed first, followed by the thoracic, cervical, and abdominal organs. The spinal cord is removed from the back.
  • In this, the anatomico-pathologic relations are not preserved.

questions.text: Identify the view in the radiographical image of paranasal sinuses shown below.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Water’s view:

  • The occipitomental (OM), or Water’s view, or parietoacanthial projection, is an angled PA radiograph of the skull, with the patient gazing slightly upwards.
  • It can be used to assess for facial fractures, as well as for acute sinusitis.
  • It is commonly used to get a better view of the maxillary sinuses.
  • The X-ray also reveals the frontal and ethmoid sinuses, while an open-mouth water view can reveal the sphenoidal sinus.
  • An x-ray beam is angled at 45° to the orbitomeatal line.
  • The rays pass from behind the head and are perpendicular to the radiographic plate.

 

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Caldwell view: The Caldwell view is a caudally angled radiograph with a posteroanterior projection allowing for minimal radiation to the orbits. Depending on the clinical indications, this view may be used to image the skull or facial bones. It aids in visualizing the paranasal sinuses, especially the frontal sinus.

Option C - Pierre’s view: Pierre’s view is the occipitomental view with an open mouth. It helps visualize the sphenoid sinus in addition to the sinuses that can be seen in Water’s view.

Option D - Lateral view: The lateral paranasal sinuses and facial bones view is a nonangled lateral radiograph showcasing the facial bones (i.e., mandible, maxilla, zygoma, nasal, and lacrimal bone) and paranasal sinuses. It is an important view for localizing foreign bodies in the trauma setting.

questions.text: A young man is brought to the ED after sustaining a road traffic accident. He complains of severe chest pain. On examination, diminished breath sounds and hyperresonance are noted on the right side of the chest. His heart rate is 139 bpm, blood pressure is 75/50 mmHg, respiratory rate is 28/min, and SpO2 is 82% on room air. What is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Needle decompression:

  • The most likely diagnosis in this patient is tension pneumothorax, in which a large air collection in the pleural space compromises respiration and cardiac function.
  • Tension pneumothorax is a clinical diagnosis.
  • Patients can rapidly deteriorate and go into cardiac arrest if not managed immediately.
  • Administration of 100% oxygen is required, as oxygen supplementation creates a diffusion gradient for nitrogen, accelerating pneumothorax resolution.
  • Treatment consists of immediate needle decompression, initially by rapid insertion of a large-bore cannula into the 2nd ICS in the mid-clavicular line of the affected side, then followed by insertion of a chest tube through the 5th ICS in the anterior axillary line.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Chest tube thoracostomy: Needle decompression should be performed first to rapidly decompress the pleural space and improve hemodynamics. CTT is then performed, and the chest tube can be removed when the lung has fully re-expanded, no air leaks are visible, and the patient has clinically improved.

Option B - Intubation and mechanical ventilation: Any form of positive pressure ventilation is contraindicated in these patients due to the risk of expanding pneumothorax and further worsening of hemodynamics.

Option C - Chest X-ray: Radiographic evaluation with CXR is recommended when the patient is hemodynamically stable. In unstable patients, bedside ultrasound is preferred. However, radiological confirmation is not required for diagnosis, especially when clinical suspicion is high.

questions.text: Emperipolesis is seen in which of the following conditions?

choices.text: Iron deficiency anemia, Diamond Blackfan anemia

questions.solution:
Correct Option A. AIHA, Rosai-Dorfman disease, myeloproliferative disorders:

  • Emperipolesis is a condition, wherein hematopoietic cells in living and intact state are seen in the cytoplasm of host cell without any damage.
  • The cells taken in frequently are neutrophils, lymphocytes, and plasma cells. The host cells may be megakaryocytes, monocytes, endothelial cells, fibroblasts, or malignant cells.
  • Pathological conditions exhibiting emperipolesis:
    • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
    • Rosai-Dorfman disease
    • Myeloproliferative disorders
    • Multiple myeloma
    • Leukemias
    • Malignant lymphomas

 

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D: These conditions are not known to exhibit emperipolesis.

questions.text: In a village in a small district, a Primary Health Center (PHC) is established to provide primary healthcare services. The district has a total of 16 PHCs. Each PHC is responsible for catering to a certain number of villages. Based on the given scenario, what is the average number of villages that are supervised by each PHC?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 29:

  • The primary level of healthcare includes Sub-centers and Primary Health Centers.
  • The Bhore committee in 1946 gave the concept of a primary health center as a basic health unit, to provide, as close to the people as possible, an integrated curative and preventive healthcare to the rural population with emphasis on preventive and promotive aspects.
  • One PHC for every 30,000 rural population in the plains, and one PHC for every 20,000 population in hilly, tribal, and backward areas.
  • Each PHC is entitled to the supervision of 29 villages.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - 4:

  • This option does not align with the typical allocation of villages per PHC in India.
  • Each Sub-center supervises 4 villages.
  • The Sub-center is the peripheral outpost of the existing healthcare delivery system in rural areas.
  • One sub-center for every 5,000 population in plains and one sub-center for every 3,000 population in hilly, tribal, and backward areas.

Option C - 158:

  • Supervising 158 villages per PHC would be overwhelming and unfeasible for effective healthcare delivery. It would lead to stretched resources, inadequate coverage, and compromised quality of care.
  • Each Community Health Center supervises 158 villages.
  • One CHC for every 1,20,000 population in plains and one CHC for every 80,000 population in hilly, tribal, and backward areas.
  • CHCs were established by upgrading the PHCs.

Option D - 100:

  • Similarly, supervising 100 villages per PHC would be unrealistic and unsustainable.
  • It would strain healthcare resources and compromise the accessibility and quality of healthcare services provided to the rural population.

questions.text: A boy was delivered at 30 weeks gestation, with no cry and no breathing. The pediatric resident started with the resuscitation protocol, provided warmth and maintained temperature, positioned the airway, and stimulated the baby. After these steps, a resident noticed that the baby was still apneic and the heart rate was < 100/min. What would be the next single best step of management?
questions.solution:
Option C: Positive pressure ventilation

  • Positive pressure ventilation is the single most effective step in the resuscitation of neonates who fail to breathe at birth.
  • It can be done by using an inflating bag, mask, or T-piece resuscitator.
  • By positive pressure ventilation, we manually deliver air to the baby.
  • This method is used to exchange air between the lungs and the external environment.
  • A device that is used for positive pressure ventilation is known as an 'Ambu bag'.

Option A: Suction of airways

  • Suction is used to clear the airways of mucus or mucous secretions.
  • Suction should be used only in case of mucous or fluid in the mouth or nose.
  • The pressure of the suction machine should not exceed 80-100 mmHg.

Option B: Tactile stimulation

  • It is the gentle stimulation of the newborn to initiate or improve respiratory effort. 
  • It is done by gently drying the baby or by flicking the soles.

Option D: Chest compressions

  • Chest compression is used to ensure adequate blood flow to vital organs.
  • It can be done when the heart rate is absent or when HR is  < 60 bpm

questions.text: Which of the following organisms is not considered in biosafety level III?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C – Hendra virus:

  • Hendra virus is included in biosafety level IV because of its high mortality rate.
  • Various Biosafety levels and organisms included are:

Biosafety level

Characteristics

Pathogens/Disease

Biosafety level I

The level of precaution at this level is minimal and usually involves wearing a face mask and no close contact.

Escherichia coli

Biosafety level 2

Involves organisms responsible for mild infections in humans.

Hepatitis A, B, and C, Lyme disease, Salmonella, measles, mumps, HIV, and dengue.

 

Biosafety level 3

Includes organisms that can be fatal to humans but for which vaccines and other treatments are available.

Mycobacterium tuberculosis, Bacillus anthracis, yersinia, hantavirus, Rift Valley fever, Malaria, Rocky Mountain spotted fever, and Yellow fever.

Biosafety level 4

Includes dangerous viruses that may cause serious or lethal infections with no treatment.

Ebola virus, Marburg virus, Lassa fever, Bolivian hemorrhagic fever, Nipah virus, and Hendra virus.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B, and D are incorrect. They are included in Biosafety level III.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient with a known diagnosis of lepromatous leprosy presents with painful, erythematous nodules on the extremities and trunk. The nodules are tender, warm to touch, and associated with systemic symptoms such as fever, malaise, and joint pain. Skin biopsy reveals a predominantly neutrophilic infiltrate. Based on the clinical presentation and laboratory findings, which type of hypersensitivity reaction is most likely responsible for the observed skin manifestations in this patient ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C- Type III hypersensitivity reaction:

  • The clinical presentation described in the scenario, characterized by painful, erythematous nodules, systemic symptoms, is consistent with erythema nodosum leprosum (ENL). ENL is an immune complex-mediated Type III hypersensitivity reaction that occurs in patients with lepromatous leprosy.

  •  

    Type 2 (Erythema Nodosum Leprosum -ENL)

    Hypersensitivity reaction

    Type III hypersensitivity reaction (In ENL, immune complexes formed by the interaction of circulating antibodies with Mycobacterium leprae antigens deposit in blood vessels and tissues, triggering an inflammatory response. The predominant neutrophilic infiltrate seen in skin biopsies is characteristic of a Type III hypersensitivity reaction.

    Spectrum

    Lower end

    Predisposing factor

    Stress, infections, and pregnancy.

    Clinical features

    New crops of lesions along with fever

    Nerve involvement

    May or may not be seen.

  • Treatment of Leprosy: Multi-drug therapy

    For Adults:

    • Rifampicin: 600 mg monthly
    • Clofazimine: 300 mg monthly
    • Dapsone: 100 mg daily

  • For Children:

    • Rifampicin: 450 mg monthly
    • Clofazimine: 50 mg every other month (alternate months)
    • Dapsone: 50 mg every other day (alternate days)

  • Medication Administration:

    • All medications are to be taken monthly.
    • Dapsone is taken daily for adults and every other day for children.
    • Clofazimine is taken monthly for adults and every other month for children.
    • Rifampicin is taken monthly for both adults and children.

  • Packaging:

    • Common blister packs are used for dispensing the medications.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Type I hypersensitivity reaction: It is an immediate hypersensitivity reaction mediated by IgE antibodies and mast cells. It typically leads to immediate allergic responses, such as urticaria and anaphylaxis, and is not the main mechanism in erythema nodosum leprosum.

Option B - Type II hypersensitivity reaction: It involves antibody-mediated cytotoxicity, such as in autoimmune hemolytic anemia or certain drug reactions. It is not the primary mechanism in the pathogenesis of erythema nodosum leprosum.

Option D - Type IV hypersensitivity reaction: It also known as delayed-type hypersensitivity, involves the activation of T cells and macrophages. While Type IV reactions play a role in the overall immune response to Mycobacterium leprae, they are not the primary mechanism responsible for the manifestations seen in erythema nodosum leprosum.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female from Chennai comes to the Pediatric clinic with her 3-year-old son, reporting that the child has low food intake, periodic episodes of vomiting every month, and no increase in growth. The mother's history is significant for malabsorption syndrome. The child cries excessively even when touched mildly. The child is examined, and positive Macewen and Marfans signs are elicited. On X-ray, the costochondral junction is enlarged and blunted with no tenderness. His blood investigations show high alkaline phosphatase. The following is an image of his X-ray. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C – Rickets:

  • High alkaline phosphatase and painless blunted rib edges with positive Macewen and Marfan sign are hints to establish the diagnosis of rickets.
  • The mother’s history of a malabsorption disease is a likely contributory factor.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Celiac disease: This has nothing to do with the abnormal clinical examination and high alkaline phosphatase

Option B - Marfan's syndrome: Marfan's sign and Marfan's syndrome are not to be confused. Marfan's sign is seen in rickets which is the palpation of double malleoli.

Option D - Scurvy: The question says that the ribs have blunted edges which is not seen in scurvy. In scurvy, the edges of the ribs are sharp and painful.

questions.text: Which of the following is the etiology of Pregnancy Induced Hypertension in twin and molar pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - More exposure to trophoblasts:

  • The etiology of PIH in twin and molar pregnancy is more exposure to trophoblasts

Other etiological factors include:

  • Primigravida - First exposure to trophoblast
  • Grand multigravida - Repeated exposure
  • Twin and molar pregnancy - More exposure to trophoblast
  • Anemia malnutrition

Genetic disease:

  • Thrombophilias - Especially dysfunction of the MTHFR gene and factor V Leiden deficiency
  • APLA syndrome

Pre-existing endothelial damage:

  • Renal disease
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • SLE

Associated with ART pregnancies

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C & D:

  • These are the etiologies of PIH

questions.text:
A 72-year-old man presents with complaints of a 4-month history of fatigue, weight loss, and bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy. His labs show low hemoglobin, platelets, lymphocytosis, and LDH of 350IU/L. His FISH report shows chromosome 14;18 translocations. An excisional biopsy of the right axillary lymph node shows the following findings:

 
Which of the following non-Hodgkin lymphomas is most likely to cause this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Follicular lymphoma:

  • Elevated lymphocytes, LDH, t(14; 18), and centrocytes in the biopsy sample suggest follicular lymphoma, the most typical form of indolent (low-grade) NHL.
  • Chromosome 14;18 translocations are seen in up to 90% of follicular lymphomas that fuse the BCL2 gene on chromosome 18 to the IgH locus on chromosome 14.
  • These tumors immunophenotypically express pan-B cell markers CD19, CD20, CD10, and BCL6.
  • It mainly occurs in adults older than 50 years of age and usually manifests as painless, generalized lymphadenopathy and easy fatigability. It usually involves lymph nodes, bone marrow, and spleen.

  • Histopathologically, small lymphoid cells with irregular or cleaved nuclear outlines (centrocytes) mixed with a population of larger cells with nucleoli (centroblasts) are found. In most follicular lymphomas, centrocytes are in the majority.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Burkitt lymphoma:

  • Burkitt lymphoma is an aggressive (high-grade) non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) that commonly occurs in adolescents and young adults with characteristic jaw lymphadenopathy. 
  • A translocation involving the MYC gene on chromosome 8 is commonly seen, but variant translocations on chromosomes 2, 14, and 22 are also observed.

Option C - Diffuse large B cell lymphoma:

  • 30% of tumors have a 14;18 translocation involving the BCL2 gene.
  • Morphologically, the neoplastic B cells are large with a round or oval nucleus and pale or basophilic cytoplasm unlike the presentation described here.

Option D - Chronic lymphocytic leukemia:

  • Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) are indolent NHLs commonly occurring in older adults with a 2:1 male predominance.
  • CLL's most common genetic anomalies are deletions of 11q, 13q, and 17p and trisomy 12q.
