  • The lymph nodes are diffusely effaced by small lymphocytes, predominantly with irregular nuclei and scant cytoplasm.

questions.text: A public health researcher conducted a study to evaluate the diagnostic accuracy of several screening tests for a particular disease. She plotted a Receiver Operating Characteristic curve. Which of the following tests has the maximum sensitivity and lowest false positive rate?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Test A:

  • ROC curve is a plot of the sensitivity (true positive rate) versus 1 − specificity (false positive rate) of a diagnostic test.
  • The different points on the curve correspond to the different cut points used to determine whether the test results are positive.
  • The better-performing test will have a higher area under the curve (AUC), with the curve closer to the upper left corner.
  • AUC is an effective measure of the inherent validity of a diagnostic test.
  • In the given ROC curve, test A is the most upward and left, indicating that it has maximum sensitivity and the lowest false positive rate.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D:

  • These tests have lesser sensitivity and higher false positive rates than test A.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male was brought to the ED after a road traffic accident. He complains of abdominal pain. His blood pressure is 110/76 mmHg, heart rate is 89 beats per minute, respiratory rate is 17 breaths per minute, and SpO2 is 96% on room air. Physical examination reveals tenderness in the epigastric region. FAST is positive for free fluid. What is the next best step in management?

choices.text: CECT scan of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - CECT scan of the abdomen and pelvis:

  • This patient most likely suffers from blunt abdominal trauma.
  • The first investigation that is ordered in a patient with blunt abdominal trauma is FAST (Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma).
  • This step is common to both stable and unstable patients because FAST is an emergency ultrasound that can be performed in 2-4 minutes and has immediate results.
  • Based on the vital signs, this patient is hemodynamically stable and also has positive FAST. Therefore, the next best step in managing his blunt abdominal trauma is imaging with a contrast-enhanced computed tomography scan of the abdomen and pelvis.
  • It allows for detailed imaging of the abdomen and pelvis, helping to identify internal injuries such as solid organ, bowel, or vascular injuries.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Nasogastric tube insertion: It is used to decompress the stomach and prevent aspiration in patients with suspected abdominal injuries. However, obtaining a CECT scan is of more immediate importance.

Option B - Serial abdominal examinations: In stable patients with blunt abdominal trauma and negative FAST results, serial abdominal examinations are a reasonable approach to detect any signs of deterioration. This patient’s FAST indicates the presence of free fluid in the abdomen.

Option D - Exploratory laparotomy: Laparotomy is indicated only for hemodynamically unstable patients and stable patients with radiological evidence of visceral organ injury. This patient is stable and does not have any indications for exploratory laparotomy.

questions.text: Below are images showing various clinical tests. Identify them and mark the correct option having the names of the tests for assessing ACL injury.
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 1, 2, 3:

  • 1 - Lachman test

    • Lachman Test

      • Patient in the supine position.
      • Knee flexed to 30°
      • The examiner places one hand behind the tibia with the thumb on the tibial tuberosity.
      • More than 2mm of anterior translation associated with a 'soft end feel' is considered positive.
      • Lachman test - More reliable, More sensitive than Anterior Drawers Test. 

    • Superior to Anterior Drawers Test

      • Less hurtful to the patient.
      • No doorstep phenomenon.
      • Gold standard physical test.
  • 2 - Anterior drawer test

    • Anterior Drawer Test

      • Patient in the supine position.
      • Hip flexed to 45°, Knee flexed to 90°
      • Examiner sits on the patient's feet.
      • Thumb of both hands on the tibial tuberosity.
      • This test is considered positive if there is a 'soft end feel.'
      • Less accurate than Lachman Test
      • Associated medial meniscus injury.
      • The doorstep phenomenon is present in ACL injury associated with the posterior horn of medial meniscal tear injury.
  • 3 - Pivot shift test

    • Pivot Shift Test-

      • Pivot Shift Test is a special test used to diagnose the rotatory instability related to injury of the ACL of the knee.
      • The patient is supine.
      • The examiner grasps and immobilizes the lateral femoral condyle with one hand and palpates the proximal tibia or fibula with the thumb.
      • Conversely, the examiner holds the patient's lower leg in internal rotation and abduction (valgus stress).
      • From this starting position, the knee is then moved from extension into flexion.
      • In the presence of a torn anterior cruciate ligament, the valgus stress will cause the tibia to subluxate anteriorly while the knee is still in extension.

Incorrect Options: Options A, C, and D are incorrect.

  • 4 - Godfrey sign in posterior drawer test is done is PCL injury

    • Godfrey sign

      • This is otherwise called the Gravity Sign or Sag Sign.
      • When viewed from the side, there is an abnormal posterior translation of the Tibia, accentuated by the hamstrings' contraction.
  • 5 - Apley’s grinding test done in meniscus injury

    • Apley's Grinding Test

      • Step I - Patient in a prone position with knee flexed to 90°.
      • Step II - The patient's thigh is fixed to the examination table with the examiner's knee.
      • Step III - The examiner medially & laterally rotates the Tibia combined with distraction. If there is
      • pain associated with excessive rotations; it is a ligamentous injury.
      • Step IV - The examiner medially & laterally rotates the Tibia combined with compression. If there is
      • pain associated with the restriction of rotations; it is a meniscal injury.
      • Apley's Grinding Test has 87% specificity & 97% sensitivity.
  • 6 - Mcmurray’s test in meniscus injury

    • McMurray Test

      • Step-I: The patient is in the supine position. The examiner holds the knee and palpates the joint line. The other hand holds the sole.
      • Step II: He is kept in full flexion.
      • Step III: The examiner applies valgus stress to the knee. With the other hand, the foot & leg are externally rotated.
      • Step IV: The knee is gradually extended.
      • Step-V: Audible click & pain denotes medial meniscal tear.

questions.text: Which of the following marked structures is damaged in respiratory distress syndrome in newborn?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 2

  • 2 is labeled as type 2 alveolar epithelial cells.
  • Respiratory distress syndrome in neonates is caused by surfactant deficiency due to inadequate production or inactivation in immature lungs.
  • There is dysfunction of type 2 alveolar epithelial cells,

Incorrect Options:

Option A: 1 is labeled as type I alveolar epithelial cells, which is responsible for gaseous exchange.

Option C: 3 is labeled as blood vessels.

Option D: 4 is labeled as RBC inside the blood vessel.

questions.text: A 23-year-old female came to the clinic with complaints of creamy white discharge per vagina for 1 week. On examination, creamy white discharge per vagina and a fishy odor were present. The doctor advised Whiff test and microscopy and the report showed positive Whiff test and clue cells and absent leukocytes respectively. Which of the following diagnoses the condition mentioned in the scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Bacterial vaginosis:

  • The features of bacterial vaginosis are given in the table below:

 

Bacterial Vaginosis

Causative

Hemophilus vaginalis (Gardnerella vaginalis)

Amsel’s Criteria

Creamy discharge

Whiff Test: positive.

Secretion + 10% KOH: Amines

Fishy odor

Clue cells: Vaginal epithelium with embedded bacteria

 

No pruritis

Treatment

Metronidazole

Treat the women.

No sexual transmission.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Trichomoniasis:

  • Trichomoniasis is characterized by a yellow, frothy discharge
  • Microscopy reveals motile trichomonads
  • So this cannot be the answer

Option C - Candidiasisis:

  • Candidiasis is characterized by a curdy white discharge
  • On microscopy, fungal elements are seen
  • So this cannot be the answer

Option D - Tubercular PID:

  • TB PID is secondary to primary TB focus in the lung or lymph nodes
  • Hematogenous spread is the most common route
  • Most common site: Fallopian tube. HSG findings: Beaded tubes that are calcific and rigid.

questions.text: Histopathology of staging laparotomy done for carcinoma endometrium reveals more than 50% myometrium invasion with vaginal involvement, parametrial involvement but no pelvic and para-aortic lymph node involvement. What is the Stage of Ca Endometrium ?
questions.solution:
Option A: III B

  • Vaginal and parametrial involvement is stage IIIB of Ca endometrium without lymph node involvement.

FIGO staging system for Ca Endometrium
Stage Ia

Tumor contained to the corpus uteri

IA No or less than half myometrial invasion

IB Invasion equal to or more than half of the myometrium
Stage II Tumor invades the cervical stroma but does not extend beyond the uterusb
Stage IIIa

Local and /or regional spread of tumorc

III A Tumor invades the serosa of the corpus uteri and/or adnexas

III B Vaginal and/or parametrial involvement

III C Metastases to pelvis and/or para-aortic lymph nodes

III C1 Positive pelvic nodes

III C2 Positive para-aortic lymph nodes with/ without positive pelvic lymph nodes
Stage IVa

Tumor invades bladder and/or bowel mucosa and/or distant metastases

IVA Tumor invasion of bladder and/or bowel mucosa

IVB Distant metastases, including intra-abdominal metastases and or inguinal lymph nodes

 

  • aInclude grades 1,2, or 3
  • bEndocervical glandular involvement only should be considered as stage I and no longer as stage II.
  • cPositive cytology has to be reported separately without changing the stage.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: IIIA

  • Tumor invades the serosa of the corpus uteri and/or adnexas, and no parametrial involvement is yet present.

Option C: III C1

  • Tumor invasion along with positive pelvic nodes.

Option D: III C2

  • Positive para-aortic lymph nodes with or without positive pelvic lymph nodes.

questions.text: A 4-months-old boy rapidly develops hypoglycemia after moderate activity. Blood examination reveals raised ketone bodies, lactic acid, and triglycerides. On examination, the liver & kidneys were enlarged. Histopathology of the liver shows deposits of normal structure glycogen in excess amounts. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Von Gierke disease:

  • The most common glycogen storage disease type I (GSD-I) presenting with hypoglycemia and normal glycogen structure is Von Gierke’s disease due to deficiency of enzyme glucose-6-phosphatase.
  • Clinical features:
    • Severe hypoglycemia
    • Ketosis
    • Massive hepatomegaly
    • Enlarged kidneys
    • Hypertriglyceridemia
    • Lactic acidosis
    • Hyperuricemia
    • Spleen not enlarged

Incorrect Options:

Option B – Pompe’s disease:

  • It is a type II glycogen storage disease but does not cause fasting hypoglycemia and lactic acidosis.
  • Deficiency of Lysosomal α1 → 4 and α1 → 6 glucosidase (acid maltase) causes Pompe's disease (a glycogen storage disease) with features such as excess glycogen in lysosomes. Normal blood sugar. Enlarged liver and heart muscle weakness and heart problems in severe forms

Option C - McArdle disease:

  • It is also known as type V glycogen storage disease
  • In this disease, muscle glycogen is not mobilized properly in exercising muscle due to a deficiency of the enzyme muscle glycogen phosphorylase, causing exercise intolerance and myoglobinuria.
  • So, increased lactic acid in the blood, enlarged liver, and kidney rule out the possibility of this disease in this patient.

Option D - Forbe’s disease:

  • It is a type III glycogen storage disease
  • It is also known as Cori’s disease or limit dextrinosis due to the accumulation of limit dextrin in the liver under fasting conditions. It occurs as a result of Amylo-α (1→6)-glucosidase/debranching enzyme deficiency.
  • clinical features are enlarged liver, growth delay, fasting hypoglycemia, abnormal glycogen structure, elevated fat in blood, possible muscle weakness.
  • As glycogen deposits have normal structure and no limit dextrins are reported in the patient, so the possibility of Forbe’s disease can be easily ruled out.

questions.text: What is the best treatment approach for a woman with Meckel's diverticulum with an unhealthy base and ulceration?

choices.text: Resection of Meckel's diverticulum with anastomosis
Symptomatic management with proton pump inhibitors

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Resection of Meckel's diverticulum with anastomosis:

  • The patient has Meckel's diverticulum with an unhealthy base and signs of ulceration. In such cases, the appropriate treatment is resection of the diverticulum and a part of the bowel, followed by anastomosis.
  • This approach is necessary to address the unhealthy base and prevent complications associated with Meckel's diverticulum.

Treatment of Meckel’s diverticulum

  • There are two situations:
    • The patient has a Meckel’s diverticulum with healthy base (means, there is no ulceration around).
    • The patient has Meckel’s diverticulum with unhealthy base (There is ulceration present).
  • MD with healthy base: Diverticulectomy (Excision of only diverticulum) + Anastomosis.
  • MD with unhealthy base: Resection (The diverticulum and a part of bowel are removed) + Anastomosis.
  • Incidentally detected Meckel’s diverticulum during elective surgery should be removed in all the patients up to 80 years of age (as there is no added morbidity in performing diverticulectomy).
    • If it is left untreated, there is increased risk of complication in 12 % of the patients.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Diverticulectomy alone: This option is unsuitable for a Meckel's diverticulum with an unhealthy base and ulceration. Diverticulectomy alone (excision of only the diverticulum) is reserved for cases with a healthy base.

Option C - Observation without surgical intervention: Given the presence of an unhealthy base and signs of ulceration, observation without surgical intervention is not appropriate. Meckel's diverticulum with these features carries an increased risk of complications, making surgical resection necessary.

Option D - Symptomatic management with proton pump inhibitors: Symptomatic management with proton pump inhibitors may help in controlling gastric acid secretion but does not address the underlying issue of an unhealthy Meckel's diverticulum. Surgical resection is the definitive treatment in cases with an unhealthy base and ulceration.

questions.text: 40-year-old patient of grade II steatohepatitis of liver presents with regular intake of 2-3 alcohol drinks daily and has BMI of 29. What will be the most appropriate advice to the patient?

choices.text: Lifestyle modification + vitamin E = Ursodeoxycholic acid

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Lifestyle modification + regular exercise:

  • The patient has alcoholic hepatitis and is overweight. Exercise plus lifestyle modification is best recommended for this case. Option B and C are used in NASH.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the basal electrical rhythm (BER) of the gastrointestinal tract is incorrect?

choices.text: Constant fluctuation of RMP from -75 to - 35 mV is known as the BER
cKIT is the marker of Interstitial cells of Cajal
Rate of BER in duodenum is 12/min and is the maximum
Stimulation of BER produces spike potentials

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Constant fluctuation of RMP from -75 to - 35 mV is known as the BER:

  • This statement is inaccurate. Basal electrical rhythm is the resting membrane potential of the GI smooth muscle.
  • Skeletal muscles, myocardium, and neurons have fixed RMP, whereas GI smooth muscles do not.
  • The below image is a plot of the RMP of GI smooth muscle between time and membrane voltage.

  • The membrane voltage rises and falls between -65 and -45 mV.
  • This constant fluctuation of RMP from -65 to - 45 mV is known as the BER.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - cKIT is the marker of Interstitial cells of Cajal:

  • Interstitial cells of Cajal are the pacemaker cells of the GI tract and are located between the smooth muscle layers from the mid-part of the stomach to the anal canal.
  • Origin of BER is due to the presence of these cells.
  • cKIT is the marker of Interstitial cells of Cajal.

Option C - Rate of BER in duodenum is 12/min and is the maximum:

  • Rate of BER is maximum in the duodenum (12/min) and minimum in the cecum (2/min).

Option D - Stimulation of BER produces spike potentials:

  • Spike potentials are multiple action potentials generated by the stimulation of BER by acetylcholine to go above the threshold voltage (-45 mV).
  • It leads to smooth muscle contraction and eventual motility.

questions.text: Which of the following is the fetal anomaly associated with GDM?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - No anomalies:

  • No fetal anomalies are associated with GDM
  • No fetal anomalies in GDM as organogenesis is completed by 10-12 weeks of pregnancy.

Incorrect Options:

Option B and C - Cardiac anomalies and Renal anomalies:

Overt Diabetes Mellitus is associated with Cardiac anomalies and Renal anomalies.

  • CVS anomalies: TGA, VSD, ASD, hypoplastic left heart, coarctation of aorta.
  • Renal anomalies: Renal agenesis, cystic kidney, duplex ureter.

Option D - Neural tube defects:

  • Neural tube defects like spina bifida are seen in the fetuses of overtly diabetic mothers.

questions.text: A 25-year old male presents to ER following a road traffic accident sustaining injuries to the lower abdomen. On examination, there is a pelvic hematoma and fracture. Physical examination shows a palpable bladder, and blood at the external urethral meatus. A digital rectal examination shows impalpable prostate. On the basis of examination, which of the following is true about the patient's diagnosis?

choices.text: The anterior urethra is the most likely place of injury
Retrograde urethrography should be done immediately
A Foley catheter can be carefully passed if the RGU is normal
Rectal examination may not reveal a large pelvic hematoma

questions.solution:
Option C: Foley catheter can be carefully passed if the RGU is normal

  • The most common site injured in the pelvic fracture is the membranous urethra.
  • In this case, blood at the urethral meatus + pelvic hematoma and high-lying prostate are the indications of injuries to the posterior urethra.
  • The presence of blood at the external urethral meatus indicates that Immediate urethrography should be done. The urethra must be imaged first before any kind of urethral instrumentation.
  • Retrograde urethrogram (RGU) is a diagnostic imaging test performed to diagnose urethral injuries.
  • If blood at the urethral meatus is seen after urethral injury, the RGU test is considered to determine the degree and nature of the injury and to plan operatively for urethral reconstruction.
  • If blunt trauma has injured the urethra of the patient and RGU is performed, urine leakage is often seen.
  • RGU: 
    • Inject radiopaque contrast into the urethra via a catheter.
    • Ensure contrast fills both anterior and posterior urethra, jetting into the bladder neck.
    • Remove air bubbles from the catheter before injection.
    • Place a Foley catheter with a radiopaque balloon, ensuring it reaches the fossa navicularis.

Anterior urethral Injuries:

  • The site of injury is the bulbar part of the urethra.
  • External blow/kick, Straddle/manhole injuries are the common causes.
  • Retrograde urethrogram (RGU) should always be the first investigation of suspected urethral injury.
  • SPC (suprapubic cystostomy) is considered to be followed by delayed repair within three months.

Option A: Anterior urethra is the most likely place of injury

  • Blunt or penetrating injuries with bulbar urethra result in Anterior urethral injuries.
  • The most common site affected by anterior injuries is the bulbar urethra.
  • It can be caused due to gunshot wounds or self-inflicted sexual misadventures.

Option B: Retrograde urethrography should be done immediately

  • Retrograde urethrogram (RUG) is the diagnostic imaging test of choice in the case of suspected urethral injury.
  •  It is recommended to do RUG after the stabilization of a patient.

Option D: Rectal examination may not reveal a large pelvic hematoma

  • High-speed motor vehicle accidents and fall from height are the most common mechanism of injury that results in pelvic fracture and urethral injuries.
  • A digital rectal exam reveals pelvic hematoma and obscures the prostate to palpation.
  • Pie-in-the-sky appearance is seen in this case on cystography, which is a floating bladder high in the pelvis due to a large pelvic hematoma

questions.text:
Identify the following pap smear images and match them accordingly:


	
		
			
			1.

			
			
			
			a. Parabasal cells
			
		
		
			
			2.

			
			
			
			b. Endometrial cells
			
		
		
			
			3.

			
			
			
			c. Endocervical cells
			
		
		
			
			4.

			
			
			
			d. Superficial and intermediate cells
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 1-c, 2-b, 3-d, 4-a:

1 - Endocervical cells:

  • These cells are columnar in shape and are found in the endocervical canal.
  • They have a characteristic butterfly-on-fence or picket fence appearance (or) a honeycomb appearance from the top.
  • Endocervical cells have a higher nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio compared to superficial cells and may have mucin-filled cytoplasm.

2 - Endometrial cells:

  • These cells can be seen in Pap smears, especially in samples taken during the 1st day to 5th day of the menstrual cycle.
  • They typically have small, round to oval nuclei and may exhibit vacuolated cytoplasm.
  • Exhibits a 3D ball-like or clustered appearance.

3 - Superficial and intermediate cells:

Superficial cells

Intermediate cells
  • Polygonal cells
  • Pink cytoplasm
  • Pyknotic nuclei
  • Polygonal cells
  • Blue cytoplasm
  • Bigger nuclei

4 - Parabasal cells:

  • These are small, round to oval cells with a high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio.
  • They are typically found in the basal layer of the cervical epithelium and are characterized by dark-staining nuclei and scant cytoplasm.

questions.text: A graph of cell membrane action potential shows ion permeation phases causing a change in potential and propagation. Identify the point with the highest PK+/PNa+.
questions.solution:
Correct Option D – F:

  • The point with the highest PK+/PNa+ ratio typically occurs during hyperpolarization or the after-hyperpolarization phase of the action potential. At this stage, sodium permeability is zero, leading to an infinity ratio of potassium permeability to sodium permeability.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and C are incorrect. Refer to learning outcome.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presented with the finding as shown in the image below. All of the following could be a cause of this finding except?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Chemical fire:

  • The above image shows scald. A chemical fire is going to cause a burn, not a scald.

Scalds

  • The above image shows scald.
  • A scald is a form of thermal injury that results from the application of liquid > 60ºC or from steam and involves only the superficial layers of skin.
  • When a person is exposed to hot liquid or steam the person can have scalds. It could be due to hot oils, molten rubber and other liquid chemicals.

Typical features of scalds

  • No charring is seen.
  • No singeing of hair.
  • Soddening of the skin.
  • Injury is seen at/ below the level of contact [steam exposure can cause injury at & above the level of contact].
  • Signs of splashing.
  • Lines of blisters.
  • Cloths are wet & intact.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A ,B and C

Scalds may be due to hot oils,steam molten rubber, and other liquid chemicals.

questions.text: What is the repair mechanism associated with CRISPR-cas9?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Non-homologous end joining:

  • Non-homologous end joining (NHEJ) is one of the main DNA repair pathways utilized by cells to repair double-stranded breaks (DSBs) in DNA. In the context of CRISPR-Cas9, NHEJ is the repair mechanism that is most commonly used to repair the DNA after Cas9 has induced a double-stranded break at the target site.
  • Example of defective NHEJ: Ataxia telangiectasia (AT).

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Base excision repair: Base excision repair (BER): BER repairs damaged or abnormal bases in DNA, not directly associated with CRISPR-Cas9. Example of a BER-related disorder: Xeroderma pigmentosum (XP).

Option C - Nucleotide excision repair: Nucleotide excision repair (NER): NER removes bulky DNA lesions like UV-induced thymine dimers, unrelated to CRISPR-Cas9 repair. Example of an NER-related disorder: Cockayne syndrome (CS).

Option D - Mismatch repair: Mismatch repair corrects replication errors, not directly involved in CRISPR-Cas9 repair. Example of a mismatch repair-related disorder: Lynch syndrome.me

questions.text:
A 61-year-old male is recently diagnosed with non-Hodgkin lymphoma of B-cell origin. A microtubule inhibitor sourced from the periwinkle plant is being considered for treatment. Identify the incorrect statement(s) about this drug.

1 - Neurotoxicity and SIADH are potential side effects

2 - Act on M phase of the cell cycle

3 - Inhibit depolymerization of microtubules

4 - Most effect in solid tumors
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Statements 3, 4:

  • The microtubule inhibitor that the question is referring to is a vinca alkaloid.
  • Vinca alkaloids are plant products derived from the periwinkle plant.
  • They inhibit the polymerization of microtubules and the formation of spindle fibers.
  • The drugs that inhibit depolymerization of microtubules are taxanes, which are also microtubule inhibitors. They are derived from the Western yew tree.
  • Taxanes stabilize microtubules, which is unique to this class of drugs.
  • Uses of vinca alkaloids:
    • All types of lymphomas
    • Soft tissue tumors
  • They are least effective in solid tumors such as osteosarcoma.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D:

  • Vinca alkaloids are M phase specific drugs and are also called spindle poisons.
  • Chromosomes are separated in the M phase by a protein called spindle fibers made up of microtubules· They also cause cell cycle arrest at metaphase.
  • Neurotoxicity and SIADH are potential side effects of vinca alkaloids.
    • Vincristine is the most neurotoxic.
    • Vinblastine is less neurotoxic.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents with severe abdominal and flank pain after a motor vehicle collision where she was the seatbelt-restrained driver. Her abdomen was distended and showing guarding with rebound tenderness. There is frank blood at the urethral orifice, and the introduction of a bladder catheter yielded no urine. Retrograde cystography is shown below. What is the next step in management?

choices.text: Radical cystectomy has to be performed
Simple catheter drainage + Broad-spectrum antibiotics as a precaution for peritonitis
Conservative management is enough, as the intra-abdominal fluid can be drained

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Requires laparotomy:

  • A ruptured intraperitoneal bladder is depicted in the photograph. Note the extraluminal contrast (red arrows) seeping into the peritoneal cavity from outside the normal bladder's boundaries. There is contrast outside of the intestine, in the left paracolic gutter (yellow arrow) according to the above mentioned clinical scenario and image findings, it is diagnosed to be a case of intraperitoneal bladder injury.
  • The intrarenal collecting system and ureter are visualized because the patient had a contrast-enhanced CT done moments earlier.
  • Intraperitoneal Rupture (20%):
    • Blow, kick or fall on a fully distended bladder.
    • Apart from the classic triad suggestive of bladder rupture (Suprapubic pain and tenderness + Difficulty or inability to pass urine + Hematuria), patients develop peritonitis and abdominal distention.
    • Diagnosis is made by retrograde cystography or CT cystography.
    • Cystography demonstrates a typical sunburst appearance. Laparotomy with peritoneal lavage and bladder repair with Suprapubic catheterization (SPC) should be done.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Radical cystectomy has to be performed:

  • The patient has intraperitoneal bladder rupture, so radical cystectomy is not indicated in this case.
  • A radical cystectomy is done to treat cancer that has invaded muscle tissue of the bladder or recurrent noninvasive bladder cancer.

Option C - Simple catheter drainage + Broad-spectrum antibiotics as a precaution for peritonitis:

  • The patient discussed above has intraperitoneal rupture leading to peritonitis.
  • A simple catheter cannot drain it. However, broad-spectrum antibiotics should be given to treat the peritonitis.

Option D - Conservative management is enough, as the intra-abdominal fluid can be drained:

  • Peritonitis requires immediate drainage by doing laparotomy and giving broad-spectrum antibiotics.
  • Conservative management is not enough in this case.

questions.text:
Match the following toxic substances with their appropriate antidotes.


	
		
			
			1. Datura
			
			
			A. Prussian blue
			
		
		
			
			2. Heroin
			
			
			B. Calcium gluconate
			
		
		
			
			3. Hydrofluoric acid
			
			
			C. Physostigmine
			
		
		
			
			4. Thallium
			
			
			D. Naloxone
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 1-c, 2-d, 3-b, 4-a:

  • Datura poisoning: The active principles are hyoscine (scopolamine), hyoscyamine, and atropine. The symptoms are due to the anticholinergic effects.
    • Physostigmine is the antidote of choice for datura poisoning. It counteracts the anticholinergic effects.
    • Short-acting barbiturates can be used to control delirium.
  • Heroin overdose: Naloxone is the antidote for Heroin poisoning.
    • Heroin is an opioid that acts on mu-opioid receptors in the brain, causing respiratory depression and central nervous system depression.
    • Naloxone is an opioid receptor antagonist that can rapidly reverse these effects and restore normal respiration.
  • Hydrofluoric acid poisoning: Calcium gluconate is the antidote for Hydrofluoric acid poisoning.
    • Hydrofluoric acid is a corrosive substance that causes severe burns and tissue damage.
    • Calcium gluconate works by binding with the fluoride ions, reducing their ability to damage tissues and helping to reverse the toxic effects.
  • Thallium poisoning: Prussian blue is the antidote for Thallium poisoning.
    • Thallium is a heavy metal that can cause severe toxicity, affecting the nervous system, gastrointestinal system, and other organs.
    • Prussian blue works by binding with thallium in the gastrointestinal tract, preventing its absorption and facilitating its elimination from the body.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B & D are incorrect.

questions.text:
A 1-year-old male baby is brought by his parents with a complaint of abdominal distention. The parents also complain of blood in the stool. A barium enema X-ray is ordered after the physical examination, which shows the following findings:



Which of the following findings are indicated in the Abdominal X-ray?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Coiled spring sign:

  • The above-shown picture depicts a coiled spring sign, and the most likely cause is intussusception.
  • Children with classic findings of intussusception need to be investigated with an air enema, which is both diagnostic (the gold standard in the diagnosis of intussusception) and therapeutic.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Meniscus sign:

  • A highly specific X-ray finding for intussusception is called the meniscus sign (or crescent sign).

Option B - Pseudo kidney sign:

  • The pseudo kidney sign is a characteristic ultrasound appearance in some cases of intestinal intussusception.

Option D - Target sign:

  • The diagnosis of a small bowel target sign most commonly correlates with intussusception.

questions.text: A child is brought to ER in an unconscious state after severe vomiting and abdominal pian episodes. HR = 100/min and BP=100/60 mm Hg. work up shows pH=7.2, blood glucose 300 mg/dl, ketone 3+. What should be the best management?

choices.text: Infusion of 0.05 – 0.1 U/kg dose insulin after 1 hour of IVF
0.1 Unit/kg insulin stat followed infusion of 0.5 U- 0.1 U/kg dose insulin and IVF
0.1 U/kg insulin subcutaneous stat followed by IVF
IVF followed by subcutaneous 0.1 U/kg insulin

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Infusion of 0.05 – 0.1 U/kg dose insulin after 1 hour of IVF:

  • Since the patient is acidotic and vomiting, it is implies moderate or greater dehydration without shock.
  • Start on Normal saline and correct fluid deficit over next 24 to 48 hours.
  • Add potassium to provide losses for potassium due to vomiting.
  • Then start continuous IV insulin infusion at 0.05-0.1 unit/kg/hour starting 1 hour after initiation of fluids.

questions.text: The body of the 55-year-old businessman has been found in his beach house. Autopsy findings reveal the presence of Simon's hemorrhage, which provided the forensic team with evidence of the possible cause of death. Which among the following statement is true about Simon's hemorrhage?

choices.text: Bleeding onto outer layers of intervertebral discs

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Bleeding onto outer layers of intervertebral discs:

 

Simon’s hemorrhage

  • Bleeding seen at the Intervertebral disc under the anterior longitudinal ligament is known as Simon's bleed.
  • It occurs due to stretching of the vertebra or convulsions during hanging.
  • The anterior surface of the vertebral column is lined with the anterior longitudinal ligament.
  • It is due to bleeding from the spinal artery, which is confined to the intervertebral area.
  • Hemorrhage in the bowel wall is also one of the indications of antemortem hanging.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Seen in cases of drowning: Simon’s hemorrhages are seen in the case of hanging.

Option C - Seen in the thoracic region: Simon’s hemorrhages are seen in the lumbar region.

Option D - Pathognomic sign of asphyxia: Simon's bleedings, in cases of asphyxiation, most likely occur due to agonal convulsions and forced movements in the lumbosacral part of the spinal column.

questions.text: Which of the following accurately depicts the correct combination of a grassroot level worker and their training duration and responsibilities?

choices.text: ASHA, 23 days, facilitates the development of village health plans
TBA, 3 months, should be able to conduct unsupervised deliveries during training
AWW, 1 month, supports ANM in conducting outreach sessions

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - ASHA, 23 days, facilitates the development of village health plans:

  • Accredited Social Health Activist (ASHA) worker undergoes 23 days of training by ANM or Anganwadi Worker.
  • Some of the roles and responsibilities include:
    • Facilitates the development of a comprehensive village health plan
    • Identifies target beneficiaries and supports ANM in conducting outreach sessions
    • Promotes the formation of women's health groups
    • Facilitates access to health and related services
    • Accompanies pregnant women and children requiring treatment/admission
    • Facilitates construction of community/household toilets
    • Acts as depot holder of things like ORS, contraceptives
    • Maintains necessary information and records

Incorrect Options:

Option B - VHG, 4 months, chlorination of well: The training period of a Village Health Guide is 3 months. The Health Worker (HW) Male is responsible for chlorinating wells.

Option C - TBA, 3 months, should be able to conduct unsupervised deliveries during training: The Trained Birth Attendant undergoes 1 month of training. During this training period, the TBA should conduct at least two supervised deliveries.

Option D - AWW, 1 month, supports ANM in conducting outreach sessions: Anganwadi Worker undergoes 4 months of training. It is the responsibility of an ASHA worker to identify target beneficiaries and support ANM in conducting outreach sessions.

questions.text: Which of the following structures develops the muscles of mastication?
questions.solution:
Option C: C

Paraxial mesoderm/somite

  • The intraembryonic mesoderm divides into paraxial,
    intermediate and lateral plate mesoderm.
  • The paraxial mesoderm extends as a longitudinal column on either
    side of the notochord and the developing neural tube.
  • The developing otic capsules (neuroectodermal thickenings
    that form the membranous labyrinth of internal ear) divide
    the paraxial mesoderm into preotic and postotic parts.
  • The preotic part of paraxial mesoderm is the unsegmented head
    mesoderm (somitomeres).
  • The postotic part of paraxia mesoderm shows 40–45 pairs of segments called somites that appear in craniocaudal sequence.
    • Dermatome [lateral part] forms skin dermis.
    • Myotome [middle part] forms skeletal muscles, including the muscle of mastication.
    • Sclerotome [medial part] forms bone [vertebra].

 

 

 

Option A: A

Notochord

  • It arises from the axial mesoderm and is completely formed by the beginning of the 4th week.
  • The main function of the notochord derived from the mesoderm is the development of the vertebrate and as a midline tissue providing directional signals to surrounding tissue during development.
  • Nucleus pulposus is a vestigial remnant of the notochord found in the intervertebral disc.

 

Option B: B

Intermediate mesoderm

  • A narrow section of the mesoderm lies between the paraxial and the lateral plate mesoderm.
  • Intermediate mesoderm derivatives are:
    • The genitourinary system, smooth muscles [detrusor], and epithelial components of the kidney, testis, and ovary

 

Option D: D

Somatopleuric mesoderm

  • The lateral plate mesoderm has two parts: somatic and visceral mesoderm.
  • The somatopleuric mesoderm forms the parietal layers of pleura, peritoneum & pericardium.

questions.text: 35-year-old woman developed feature of heart failure and expired. Post -mortem cardiac biopsy slide is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - DCM:

  • Notice hypertrophied and atrophied fibers co-existing in slide. Also check out the basophilic intracellular amorphous material.
  • This indicates Dilated Cardiomyopathy.

RCM

Notice pink hyaline material between myocytes seen with Amyloidosis

DCM due to TTN mutations

Ninja star appearance

HCM

Myocardial disarray and fragmented appearance of nuclei

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B, C, D are incorrect.

questions.text: What does the displayed capnography waveform given below likely indicate in a 32-year-old patient undergoing laparotomy for acute intestinal obstruction under general anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Curare cleft:

  • Capnometry is the measurement of expired CO2 and is the confirmation method of choice in anaesthesia for the proper placement of an endotracheal tube.
  • Most CO2 monitors include a waveform known as a capnograph.
  • The shape of the normal waveform is illustrated below.

  • Phase 0: inspiratory phase.
  • Phase 1: It reflects the inspired gas, which is normally devoid of CO2. It is the dead space.
  • Phase 2 (expiratory upstroke): a mixture of alveolar and dead space gas.
  • Phase 3: alveolar plateau, with the peak representing end-expiratory (end-tidal) CO2.
  • Several situations can cause unusual waveforms. One of them is a curare cleft, as asked in this question above.
    • Curare cleft, or notch, is seen during spontaneous ventilation.
    • Patients who are primarily partially paralyzed with muscle relaxants may make respiratory efforts at any time during the respiratory cycle with controlled ventilation.
    • As the muscle relaxant is reversed, the curve becomes normal in shape.
  • The aperture is in the last third of the plateau. It is caused by a lack of synchronous action between the intercostal muscles and the diaphragm, most commonly caused by inadequate muscle relaxant reversal.
    • The depth of the aperture is proportional to the degree of muscle paralysis.
    • The position of the cleft is fairly constant in the same patient but is not necessarily present with every breath.
  • The notch is also seen in patients with transverse cervical lesions, flail chest, hiccups, pneumothorax, and when a patient tries to breathe during mechanical ventilation.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Bisferiens cleft:

  • It is also a biphasic pulse and aortic waveform with two peaks per cardiac cycle. The smaller peak is followed by a strong and broad one.
  • It is a sign of problems with the aorta, including aortic stenosis, aortic regurgitation and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy resulting in aortic stenosis.

Option B - Servo notch:

  • Servo motors, or "servos", as they are known, are electronic devices and rotatory or linear actuators that rotate and push parts of a machine with precision.
  • Servos are mainly used on angular or linear positions and for specific velocity and acceleration.
  • These motors are used in CNS machinery, robotics and automated manufacturing.

Option D - All of the above:

  • The diagram in the question above reveals a “curare cleft”, which is represented by a small dip in the alveolar plateau. It indicated a spontaneous respiratory effort during mechanical ventilation.
  • The other options do not explain this capnograph.

questions.text: A 35-year-old mountaineer presents with shortness of breath, cough, and pink frothy sputum after ascending rapidly to an altitude of 5,000 meters. Chest X-ray demonstrates bilateral infiltrates consistent with pulmonary edema. What is the underlying pathophysiology?

choices.text: Vasodilation of capillaries → ↑ blood flow → ↑ hydrostatic pressure → edema
Vasoconstriction of capillaries → ↑ blood flow → ↑ capillary permeability → edema
Decreased ejection fraction → ↑ blood flow → ↑ hydrostatic pressure → edema
Vasoconstriction of capillaries → ↑ blood flow → ↑ hydrostatic pressure → edema

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Vasoconstriction of capillaries → ↑ blood flow → ↑ capillary permeability → edema:

  • This patient is presenting with signs and systems of high altitude pulmonary edema.
  • Hypoxia causes vasoconstriction in the lungs, and this is known as hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction.
  • In HAPE, the pulmonary vasoconstriction is patchy. Because vasoconstriction is not uniform, increased blood flow in the capillaries renders the endothelial surface susceptible to damage. This is called stress failure of the endothelium.
  • The damaged endothelial cells create gaps, leading to increased permeability.
  • Oozing out of water, protein, RBCs, and a few WBCs causes edema to form. This is the basis of pink frothy sputum in affected patients.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Vasodilation of capillaries → ↑ blood flow → ↑ hydrostatic pressure → edema:

  • This is the sequence of changes that occur in high altitude cerebral edema.
  • In response to hypoxia, system vasculature, including the cerebral vessels, undergoes vasodilation in contrast to pulmonary vasculature.
  • Subsequently, increased blood flow to the brain and hydrostatic will lead to the ejection of only water, resulting in cerebral edema.

Option C - Decreased ejection fraction → ↑ blood flow → ↑ hydrostatic pressure → edema:

  • This sequence occurs in heart failure with reduced ejection fraction.
  • In HFrEF, the blood backs up in the pulmonary veins, leading to increased hydrostatic pressure and pulmonary edema.

Option D - Vasoconstriction of capillaries → ↑ blood flow → ↑ hydrostatic pressure → edema:

  • In HAPE, the pathophysiology involves stress failure of the endothelial cells and increased capillary permeability.
  • This option does not incorporate this change; therefore, it is incorrect.

questions.text: Which of the following is an indication for adjuvant chemotherapy after mastectomy?

choices.text: Presence of malignant cells in biopsy
There is no indication for adjuvant chemotherapy

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Size > 1cm & lymph node-positive:

  • After mastectomy, Chemotherapy may be recommended to destroy undetected cancer cells and reduce the risk of cancer recurring. This is called adjuvant Chemotherapy.
  • Tumour size greater than 1cm, positive lymph nodes, or adverse prognostic factors are some indications for adjuvant Chemotherapy.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Presence of malignant cells in biopsy:

  • The presence of malignant cells in biopsy is indicates neoplasm.
  • It does not provide enough evidence regarding whether the patient will benefit from adjuvant chemotherapy

Option C - Family history of breast cancer:

  • Family history of breast cancer can influence treatment decisions, such as the choice of surgery (e.g., lumpectomy versus mastectomy), the extent of lymph node dissection, and the use of adjuvant therapies (e.g., chemotherapy, hormonal therapy, targeted therapy).

Option D -There is no indication for adjuvant chemotherapy:

  • Adjuvant Chemotherapy is indicated in patients with positive lymph nodes post-surgery.
  • It is also indicated in patients who are at high risk for recurrence.

questions.text: Several cases of waterborne infections have been reported during recent floods in a coastal town. The local authorities are planning to implement disaster management strategies. Which three fundamental aspects of the disaster management cycle should they prioritize?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Impact, Preparedness, Mitigation:

The three fundamental aspects of disaster management are:

  1. Disaster impact: This phase involves assessing the effects of a disaster, such as evaluating the number of casualties and damage to infrastructure.
  2. Disaster preparedness: This phase involves planning and training to respond effectively to disasters, such as developing evacuation plans and stockpiling emergency supplies.
  3. Disaster mitigation: This phase involves taking measures to reduce the impact of future disasters, such as implementing building codes and conducting risk assessments.


 

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and C: These steps are integral to disaster management but are not precisely the three key aspects.

questions.text: Lady with mitral stenosis develops sudden onset respiratory difficulty, bilateral pitting limb edema and pain in calves. Clinical diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Pulmonary edema:

  • The breathing difficulty in patient of mitral stenosis can be explained by pulmonary edema.
  • The involvement of right side of heart in long standing MS can explain Bilateral pitting limb edema and pain in calves.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A, C &  D are incorrect.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man with a travel history to Southeast Asia presents with fever, cough, and skin lesions after encountering bamboo rats. Papules on the face, chest, and extremities are observed on examination. Microscopic analysis of skin lesion samples shows fungi with brush-like conidia on conidiophores. Which fungal species is most likely responsible for the skin lesions?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Talaromyces marneffei:

  • Talaromyces marneffei (penicillium marneffei a dimorphic fungi) is associated with infections in individuals who come into contact with bamboo rats, which serve as a natural reservoir for the fungus. The presence of brush-like conidia on conidiophores is a unique feature of Talaromyces marneffei. 
  • Most patients with talaromycosis present with signs and symptoms related to infection of the reticuloendothelial system, including generalized lymphadenopathy, hepatomegaly, and splenomegaly. Skin lesions are seen in approximately 70 percent of patients, and when present, they are the best clue to diagnosis. Patients may also present with respiratory, gastrointestinal, and neurologic findings.

Incorrect Options-

Option A - Candida albicans: Candida albicans is a yeast known to cause various fungal infections, including oral thrush and vaginal yeast infections. .

Option B - Aspergillus fumigatus: Aspergillus fumigatus is a mold that can cause a range of respiratory infections, including allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis and invasive aspergillosis. Additionally, the skin lesions progressing into ulcers do not align with the common presentations of Aspergillus infections.

Option D - Trichophyton rubrum: Trichophyton rubrum is a dermatophyte fungus that can cause various skin infections, including athlete's foot, and onychomycsis.

questions.text: Spirometry is performed on a 20-year-old man, and the results are plotted as a graph. What will the forced vital capacity be considering the maximum expiratory flow-volume curve below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 4.5:

  • Spirometry is a pulmonary function test. It is performed to check breathing patterns and calculate certain parameters. It is helpful in the diagnosis of obstructive and restrictive lung diseases.
  • Forced Vital Capacity= Total lung Capacity-Residual Volume
  • FVC = TLC-RV
  • TLC and RV are the factors of intersection among the abscissa and flow-volume curve
  • TLC = 5.5 liters
  • RV = 1 liter
  • Therefore, FVC = 5.5 − 1 = 4.5 liters.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and C: Refer to the explanation of Option D

questions.text: A young woman is brought to the emergency room with profuse vomiting and confusion. Examination shows altered mental status. Jamaican vomiting sickness is suspected. Which of the following enzymes is rendered inactive in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Acyl CoA dehydrogenase:

  • Ingestion of the unripened Ackee fruit may result in an acquired fatty acid oxidation defect called "Jamaican vomiting sickness."
  • Clinical manifestations include profuse vomiting, altered mental status, and hypoglycemia.
  • Hypoglycin, present in unripened ackee fruit, inhibits medium-chain acyl CoA dehydrogenase enzyme.

Nonketotic hypoglycemia
  • In hypoglycemia due to a fatty acid oxidation defect, there will be no Acetyl CoA and no ketone bodies.

Hyperammonemia
  • To support fatty acid synthesis, amino acid oxidation takes place, and wherever AAs get oxidized, the amino group will be released as ammonia.

Dicarboxylic aciduria
  • When peroxisomes mediate β-oxidation, they can only oxidize fatty acids up to very short-chain lengths.
  • Consequently, ω-oxidation of very short-chain fatty acids occurs, leading to the production of dicarboxylic acids, which can be detected in urine as dicarboxylic aciduria.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D: Although defects in these fatty acid oxidation enzymes result in the same clinical features and metabolic derangements, they are not involved in the pathogenesis of Jamaican Vomiting Sickness. These enzyme defects often occur as a part of congenital FA oxidation defects.

questions.text: Which of the following is an adverse effect of rifabutin?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option C: Pseudo jaundice

  • Rifabutin causes orange-tan discoloration of the skin, urine, feces, saliva, and tears.
  • This is referred to as pseudo jaundice.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Thyroid dysfunction

  • Thyroid dysfunction is a side effect of Para-aminosalicylic acid (PAS) and Ethionamide.

Option B: Neuropsychiatric

  • Neuropsychiatric disturbances are a side effect of cycloserine.

Option D: Ototoxicity

  • Ototoxicity is seen with ethionamide and aminoglycoside antibiotics.

questions.text: Which of the following cells participates in the process of "efferocytosis"?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A- Macrophages:

  • Efferocytosis is a process of removing apoptotic cells without causing inflammation
  • It is carried about by dendritic cells, macrophages, fibroblasts and epithelial cells, which recognize “find me” and “eat me” signals from apoptotic cells.
  • Production of pro-inflammatory cytokines is reduced in macrophages that have ingested apoptotic cells.

Incorrect Options: 

Options B, C, and D are not involved in this process. Macrophages secrete proteins that bind to apoptotic cells leading to the engulfment of cells.

questions.text:
14-year-old boy is brought by his father who noticed him having agonal respiration at 5 A.M. in sleep in the morning he was rushed to the ER where ECG was performed that show Saddle back pattern of STE in V2 and V3. His father said that the boy has syncopal episodes in school last month. Which of the following is/ are correct about this condition?

a. Loss of function in voltage gated sodium channel

b. RVOT epicardium defe

c. Implantable Cardioverter defibrillator is main treatment

d. SCN4A defect
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - a,b,c:

  • The diagnosis is Brugada syndrome type 2.
  • Type 2 has saddle back STE in contrast to type 1 that has Cove pattern of STE.
  • It is a sodium channel defect with loss of function.
  • It is SCN5A defect not SCN4A
  • ICD is main treatment to prevent mortality.

Characteristic

Type 1

Type 2

Type 3

 

 

 

J wave amplitude

≥2 mm

≥2 mm

≥ 2 mm

T wave

Negative

Positive or biphasic

Positive

ST-T configuration

Cove-type

Saddleback

Saddleback

 

Incorrect Options: 

  • Option A, C & D are incorrect

questions.text:
A 50-year-old male presents with hearing loss, and occasional foul-smelling discharge from the right ear. On examination the following finding is made:



During the surgical management of this condition which incision is made?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A- Wilde's incision:

  • This patient is likely suffering from cholesteatoma

Cholesteatoma:

  • The presence of keratinizing squamous epithelium in the middle ear is cholesteatoma.
  • The external auditory canal is lined by stratified squamous epithelium, and the middle ear is lined by cuboidal epithelium.
  • Gross appearance: pearly-white (due to the presence of keratin).
  • Surgical Management of cholesteatoma: Modified Radical Mastoidectomy

Mastoidectomy

  • A post-aural incision 1cm behind the retroauricular sulcus is taken - Wilde's incision

  • The first landmark is the supra mastoid crest, the second is the imaginary line across the posterior wall of the external auditory canal and the third line is the tangent joining the two.
  • The triangle formed is MacEwen's triangle. It is the surface landmark to identify the mastoid antrum.

Incorrect Options:

Option B- Welchi's incision: There is no incision known as Welchi's incision in cholesteatoma surgery.

Option C- Smith's incision: There is no incision known as Smith's incision for cholesteatoma surgery.

Option D- Davis's incision: There is no incision known as Davis's incision in cholesteatoma surgery.

questions.text: Two lost tourists have been rescued from the desert. The couple had wandered off from the rest of the group while halting to click some pictures in private. Their bodies showed all signs of severe dehydration. All the following are true of hyperthermic anhydrosis that they would have experienced, except?

choices.text: Papular rashes over face and neck

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Complete absence of sweating:

This is not true about hyperthermic anhydrosis.

Hyperthermic Anhydrosis:

  • Also called as desert syndrome.
  • After generalized profuse sweating for days, perspiration stops suddenly in all parts of the body below the neck region but persists in the face and neck.
  • Hyperkeratotic plugging of sweat glands leading to functional failure of sweat apparatus.
  • Papular rashes over the face and neck. It was observed in U.S. soldiers having training in deserts.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C and D are relevant to Hyperthermic anhydrosis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with generalized weakness and other neurological complaints. Upon further inquiry, you discover that he consumes large quantities of a particular legume (shown below) as a staple in his diet. On examination, you notice exaggerated deep tendon reflexes. Which of the following is a clinical feature of this condition?

choices.text: Spastic paralysis of the lower limb
Spastic paralysis of the upper limb
Flaccid paralysis of the upper limb
Flaccid paralysis of the lower limb

questions.solution:
Correct option A - Spastic paralysis of the lower limb:

  • Neurolathyrism is a neurological disorder caused by the consumption of the legume Lathyrus sativus (khesari dal).

  • Clinical features:

    • Spastic paralysis of the lower limb.
    • Stages of Spastic Paralysis of Lower Limb
      • Latent stage
      • One stick stage
      • Two-stick stage
  • It is a consequence of food adulteration (any substance added to a food product that decreases the nutritive value and harms the body).
  • The toxin present is Beta oxalyl amino alanine (BOAA).
  • This disorder primarily affects the lower limbs, resulting in spastic paralysis characterized by increased tone, exaggerated reflexes, and weakness in the lower limbs.
  • The condition typically manifests as a stiff-legged gait due to spasticity in the lower extremities.
  • Interventions include:
    • Vitamin C prophylaxis (500 to 1000 mg in a week)
    • Toxin removal by steeping and parboiling
    • Health education
    • Banning the crop
    • Genetic approach

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Spastic paralysis of the upper limb:

  • Neurolathyrism primarily affects the lower limbs rather than the upper limbs.
  • While spasticity may occur in severe cases, it is more commonly observed in the lower limbs.
  • Therefore, spastic paralysis of the upper limb is not a characteristic feature of neurolathyrism.

Option C - Flaccid paralysis of the upper limb:

  • Flaccid paralysis refers to a condition characterized by weakness and decreased muscle tone.
  • Neurolathyrism does not typically present with flaccid paralysis, as it primarily affects the upper motor neurons, leading to spasticity rather than flaccidity.
  • Therefore, flaccid paralysis of the upper limb is an incorrect clinical feature for neurolathyrism.

Option D: Flaccid paralysis of the lower limb:

  • Similarly, neurolathyrism does not typically manifest as flaccid paralysis in the lower limbs.
  • Flaccid paralysis is more indicative of lower motor neuron lesions rather than upper motor neuron dysfunction, which is characteristic of neurolathyrism.
  • Therefore, flaccid paralysis of the lower limb is not a clinical feature of neurolathyrism.

questions.text: Stroke patient present with inability to identify object but can identify the color texture, shape of objects. Which of the following lobe of brain is involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Temporal lobe:

  • The loss of ability to identify object like bunch of keys but can tell it is a bunch of keys by texture/Holding it in hands and feeling its shape is a feature of visual agnosia. It is seen due to damage to inferior temporal lobe. Do not confuse it with astereognosis where the patient cannot tell an object by touching it. It is seen due to lesion of parietal lobe.
  • Astereognosis is the inability to identify objects by feel only, in the absence of input from the visual system. It is seen in lesions of parietal lobe. The shape, texture, size, and weight of the object are assessed. Usually, this is done with hands. Manual stereognosis requires the dorsal column – medial lemniscus tract (DCMLT) to receive discriminative touch and proprioceptive information, and the parietal cortex to process the information.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B, D are incorrect.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of hypocalcemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Vitamin D toxicity:

  • Calcium balance relies on vitamin D along with two other hormones.
  • Vitamin D toxicity causes high calcium levels in the blood.
  • Symptoms include weakness, fatigue, loss of appetite, and bone pain.
  • Neurological symptoms like confusion, agitation, and in severe cases, ataxia and coma may occur.
  • Renal symptoms include increased urination, thirst, and kidney stones.
  • Severe cases can lead to deadly heart rhythm disturbances.

Vit D

PTH

Calcitonin

↑ Ca+2 in Blood

↑ phosphate in Blood

↑ Ca+2 in Blood

↓ phosphate in Blood (by excretion via kidneys)

↓ Ca+2 in Blood

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Acute pancreatitis:

  • It is associated with dystrophic calcifications leading to hypocalcemia.
  • Hypocalcemia in the setting of acute pancreatitis is associated with a poor prognosis.

Option B - Chronic renal failure:

  • It may lead to secondary hypoparathyroidism, eventually leading to hypocalcemia and associated clinical signs.

Option C - Hypoparathyroidism:

  • Low PTH levels result in decreased calcium levels.
  • Etiology includes primary or secondary hypoparathyroidism, with secondary often linked to chronic kidney disease.

questions.text: A chain of private clinics has initiated a new screening program for a noncommunicable disease. To screen for this disease, sequential testing is done. The test I has a sensitivity of 95% and a specificity of 87%. Test II has a sensitivity of 90% and a specificity of 98%. What happens to these parameters when Test I and Test II are performed in series?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Increased specificity and decreased sensitivity:

  • In sequential testing or series testing, the individual is first subjected to one test. If the first returns positive, then he/she is subjected to the second test.
  • When two tests are used in series, sensitivity decreases while specificity increases compared to using each test individually.
  • In this scenario, Test I, which has higher sensitivity but lower specificity, is followed by Test II, which has higher specificity but lower sensitivity.
  • Test I (high sensitivity test) is used for screening, and if this test is positive, Test II (high specificity test) is used for confirmation.
  • As a result, the combined effect is decreased sensitivity but increased specificity.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and C:

  • These are not the changes seen in parameters when two tests are performed in series.

questions.text: Name the torture method shown:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Chepuwa:

  • The legs and thighs are tied very tightly with bamboo sticks to induce severe pain known as Chepuwa.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Saw horse: The victim would be forced to straddle a triangular-shaped wooden structure, often resembling a sawhorse, with their legs on either side. Their full body weight would be supported by the narrow edge of the triangle, typically causing excruciating pain in the genital area.

Sometimes additional weights, such as cannonballs or rocks, would be tied to the victim's ankles to increase the suffering.  This results in perineal or scrotal hematoma.

Option C - Black slave: Heated metal skewer inserted into the anus.

Option D - Ghotna: A wooden pole is rolled up and down the front of the thighs with one or more individuals standing on it.
